Musgrave	O

Musgrave	O

2.	O

In	O
Aircore	O
(	O
AC	O
)	O
drilling	O
,	O
composite	O
4	O
metre	O
samples	O
were	O
collected	O
with	O
smaller	O
composites	O
if	O
end	O
of	O
hole	O
reached	O
within	O
a	O
4m	O
interval.	O

One	O
metre	O
individual	O
samples	O
are	O
submitted	O
for	O
priority	O
analysis	O
where	O
4m	O
composite	O
assays	O
are	O
greater	O
than	O
100ppb	O
Au.	O

All	O
samples	O
are	O
analysed	O
using	O
a	O
50g	O
fire	O
assay	O
with	O
ICP-MS	O
(	O
inductively	O
coupled	O
plasma	O
-	O

mass	O
spectrometry	O
)	O
finish	O
gold	O
analysis	O
(	O
0.005ppm	O
detection	O
limit	O
)	O
by	O
Genalysis-Intertek	O
in	O
Maddington	O
,	O
Western	O
Australia	O
3.	O

g/t	O
(	O
grams	O
per	O
tonne	O
)	O
,	O
ppm	O
(	O
parts	O
per	O
million	O
)	O
,	O
ppb	O
(	O
parts	O
per	O
billion	O
)	O
,	O
X	O
=	O
below	O
detection	O
limit	O
,	O
NSI	O
=	O
no	O
significant	O
intercept	O
above	O
100ppb	O
Au	O
4.	O

Intersections	O
are	O
generally	O
calculated	O
over	O
intervals	O
>0.1g/t	O
where	O
zones	O
of	O
internal	O
dilution	O
are	O
not	O
weaker	O
than	O
2m	O
<	O
0.1g/t	O
Au.	O

9	O
JORC	O
TABLE	O
1	O
Section	O
1	O
Sampling	O
Techniques	O
and	O
Data	O
Criteria	O
Explanation	O
Commentary	O
Sampling	O
Nature	O
and	O
quality	O
of	O
sampling	O
(	O
e.g.	O

cut	O
channels	O
,	O
The	O
drill	O
hole	O
sampling	O
in	O
this	O
release	O
has	O
been	O
carried	O
out	O
on	O
Lake	O
Austin	O
techniques	O
random	O
chips	O
,	O
or	O
specific	O
specialised	O
industry	O
as	O
part	O
of	O
the	O
Cue	O
Joint	O
Venture	O
with	O
Evolution	O
mining	O
Ltd.	O

The	O
drill	O
standard	O
measurement	O
tools	O
appropriate	O
to	O
the	O
program	O
comprises	O
aircore	O
drill	O
holes	O
(	O
436	O
drill	O
holes	O
for	O
48	O
,	O
895m	O
)	O
varying	O
minerals	O
under	O
investigation	O
,	O
such	O
as	O
down	O
hole	O
in	O
depth	O
from	O
5m	O
to	O
180m.	O

All	O
drill	O
holes	O
were	O
drilled	O
at	O
either	O
-60o	O
,	O
-70o	O
gamma	O
sondes	O
,	O
or	O
handheld	O
XRF	O
instruments	O
,	O
etc	O
)	O
.	O

or	O
-90o	O
and	O
at	O
variable	O
spacing	O
but	O
nominally	O
50m	O
spacings	O
along	O
lines	O
These	O
examples	O
should	O
not	O
be	O
taken	O
as	O
limiting	O
the	O
with	O
traverse	O
lines	O
spaced	O
100m-400m	O
apart.	O

broad	O
meaning	O
of	O
sampling.	O

Sampling	O
is	O
undertaken	O
using	O
standard	O
industry	O
practices	O
including	O
the	O
use	O
of	O
duplicates	O
and	O
standards	O
at	O
regular	O
30m	O
intervals.	O

One	O
metre	O
aircore	O
samples	O
are	O
laid	O
out	O
in	O
rows	O
of	O
20	O
on	O
the	O
ground	O
and	O
composite	O
4m	O
samples	O
collected	O
by	O
scoop	O
sampling	O
the	O
one	O
metre	O
piles	O
to	O
produce	O
a	O
2-3kg	O
composite	O
sample	O
which	O
is	O
sent	O
to	O
the	O
Genalysis	O
laboratory	O
in	O
Maddington	O
,	O
Perth	O
for	O
analysis.	O

Resampling	O
of	O
anomalous	O
aircore	O
samples	O
(	O
>100ppb	O
Au	O
)	O
is	O
undertaken	O
at	O
1m	O
intervals	O
by	O
scoop.	O

A	O
Thermo	O
Scientific	O
Niton	O
GoldD	O
XL3+	O
950	O
Analyser	O
is	O
available	O
on	O
site	O
to	O
aid	O
geological	O
interpretation.	O

No	O
XRF	O
results	O
are	O
reported.	O

Include	O
reference	O
to	O
measures	O
taken	O
to	O
ensure	O
All	O
co-ordinates	O
are	O
in	O
UTM	O
grid	O
(	O
GDA94	O
Z50	O
)	O
and	O
drill	O
hole	O
collars	O
have	O
sample	O
representivity	O
and	O
the	O
appropriate	O
calibration	O
been	O
surveyed	O
by	O
handheld	O
GPS	O
to	O
an	O
accuracy	O
of	O
~1.0m.	O

The	O
accuracy	O
of	O
of	O
any	O
measurement	O
tools	O
or	O
systems	O
used.	O

historical	O
drill	O
collars	O
pre-2009	O
is	O
unknown.	O

.	O

Gold	O
mineralisation	O
at	O
Howards	O
is	O
hosted	O
within	O
a	O
broad	O
,	O
north-south	O
trending	O
,	O
vertical	O
to	O
steep	O
west-	O
dipping	O
shear	O
zone	O
,	O
approximately	O
150m	O
from	O
,	O
and	O
sub-parallel	O
to	O
the	O
east-dipping	O
eastern	O
contact	O
of	O
the	O
Montague	O
granodiorite.	O

Mineralisation	O
is	O
associated	O
with	O
strong	O
quartz	O
veining	O
and	O
intense	O
silica-	O
albite-biotite	O
alteration	O
within	O
a	O
sheared	O
basalt	O
above	O
a	O
footwall	O
dolerite	O
unit.	O

Two	O
sinistral	O
northwest-	O
trending	O
faults	O
offset	O
the	O
northern	O
(	O
northern	O
lode	O
)	O
and	O
southern	O
(	O
southern	O
lode	O
)	O
extensions	O
of	O
the	O
main	O
Howards	O
lode	O
by	O
30m	O
and	O
150m	O
respectively	O
(	O
Figure	O
2	O
)	O
.	O

Drilling	O
has	O
confirmed	O
the	O
presence	O
of	O
broad	O
zones	O
of	O
potentially	O
open	O
pit	O
gold	O
mineralisation	O
that	O
has	O
now	O
been	O
defined	O
over	O
a	O
continuous	O
strike	O
of	O
over	O
1.3km	O
,	O
with	O
mineralisation	O
remaining	O
open	O
to	O
the	O
north	O
,	O
south	O
and	O
at	O
depth	O
within	O
the	O

lodes.	O

3	O
HWRC237	O
and	O
HWRC245	O
are	O
RC	O
pre-collars	O
for	O
planned	O
diamond	O
drill	O
hole	O
tails	O
,	O
designed	O
to	O
intercept	O
gold	O
mineralisation	O
towards	O
the	O

of	O
the	O
central	O
lode	O
and	O
provide	O

information	O
to	O

the	O
controls	O
on	O
mineralisation	O
(	O

2	O
)	O
.	O

will	O

of	O
future	O
depth	O
extension	O
drilling	O
at	O

it	O
is	O

to	O

the	O
Montague	O

at	O
~200m	O
below	O
surface.	O

diamond	O

at	O

and	O

Rawlins	O

Approximately	O

west	O

the	O

of	O
a	O

8.8	O

item	O
8.7	O
is	O
less	O
than	O
2	O
quarters	O
,	O
please	O
provide	O
answers	O
to	O
the	O
following	O
questions	O
:	O
8.8.1	O
Does	O
the	O
entity	O
expect	O
that	O
it	O
will	O
continue	O
to	O

time	O
being	O
and	O
,	O
if	O
not	O
,	O
why	O
not?	O
Answer	O
:	O
N/A	O
8.8.2	O
Has	O
the	O
entity	O
taken	O
any	O
steps	O
,	O
or	O
does	O
it	O

to	O
take	O

steps	O
,	O

and	O
,	O

,	O

are	O

steps	O
and	O
how	O
likely	O
does	O
it	O
believe	O
that	O
they	O
will	O
be	O
successful?	O
Answer	O
:	O
N/A	O
8.8.3	O
Does	O
the	O
entity	O
expect	O
to	O
be	O
able	O
to	O
continue	O
its	O
operations	O
and	O
to	O
meet	O
its	O

and	O
,	O

,	O
on	O
what	O
basis?	O
Answer	O
:	O
N/A	O
Note	O
:	O
where	O
item	O
8.7	O
is	O
less	O
than	O
2	O
quarters	O
,	O

Notes	O
1.	O

This	O
quarterly	O
cash	O
flow	O
report	O
and	O
the	O
accompanying	O
activity	O
report	O
provide	O
a	O

for	O

the	O
market	O
about	O
the	O
entity	O
’	O
s	O
activities	O
for	O

past	O
quarter	O
,	O

have	O
been	O

this	O
has	O

on	O
its	O
cash	O
position.	O

An	O
entity	O
that	O

to	O

information	O
over	O
and	O
above	O
the	O
minimum	O
required	O
under	O
the	O

Rules	O

to	O
do	O
so.	O

2.	O

If	O
this	O
quarterly	O

Dividends	O

may	O

classified	O

41	O
Responsibility	O
of	O
the	O
directors	O
for	O
the	O
financial	O
report	O
The	O
directors	O
of	O
the	O
Company	O
are	O
responsible	O
for	O
the	O
preparation	O
of	O
the	O
half-year	O
financial	O
report	O
that	O
gives	O
a	O
true	O
and	O
fair	O
view	O
in	O
accordance	O
with	O
Australian	O
Accounting	O
Standards	O
and	O
the	O
Corporations	O
Act	O
2001	O
and	O
for	O
such	O
internal	O
control	O
as	O
the	O
directors	O
determine	O
is	O
necessary	O
to	O
enable	O
the	O
preparation	O
of	O
the	O
half-year	O
financial	O
report	O
that	O
gives	O
a	O
true	O
and	O
fair	O
view	O
and	O
is	O
free	O
from	O
material	O
misstatement	O
,	O
whether	O
due	O
to	O
fraud	O
or	O
error.	O

Our	O
responsibility	O
is	O
to	O
express	O
a	O
conclusion	O
on	O
the	O
half-year	O
financial	O
report	O
based	O
on	O
our	O
review.	O

ASRE	O
2410	O
requires	O
us	O
to	O
conclude	O
whether	O
we	O
have	O
become	O
aware	O
of	O
any	O
matter	O
that	O
makes	O
us	O
believe	O
that	O
the	O
half-year	O
financial	O
report	O
is	O
not	O
in	O
accordance	O
with	O
the	O
Corporations	O
Act	O
2001	O
including	O
giving	O
a	O
31	O
December	O
2021	O
and	O
its	O
financial	O
performance	O
for	O
the	O
half-year	O
ended	O
on	O
that	O
date	O
and	O
complying	O
with	O
Accounting	O
Standard	O
AASB	O
134	O
Interim	O
Financial	O
Reporting	O
and	O
the	O
Corporations	O
Regulations	O
2001.	O

A	O
review	O
of	O
a	O
half-year	O
financial	O
report	O
consists	O
of	O
making	O
enquiries	O
,	O
primarily	O
of	O
persons	O
responsible	O
for	O
financial	O
and	O
accounting	O
matters	O
,	O
and	O
applying	O
analytical	O
and	O
other	O
review	O
procedures.	O

A	O
review	O
is	O
substantially	O
less	O
in	O
scope	O
than	O
an	O
audit	O
conducted	O
in	O
accordance	O
with	O
Australian	O
Auditing	O
Standards	O
and	O
consequently	O
does	O
not	O
enable	O
us	O
to	O
obtain	O
assurance	O
that	O
we	O
would	O
become	O
aware	O
of	O
all	O
significant	O
matters	O
that	O
might	O
be	O
identified	O
in	O
an	O
audit.	O

Accordingly	O
,	O
we	O
do	O
not	O
express	O
an	O
audit	O
opinion.	O

BDO	O
Audit	O
(	O
WA	O
)	O
Pty	O
Ltd	O
Jarrad	O
Prue	O
Director	O
Perth	O
,	O
16	O

’	O
Drill	O
type	O
(	O

(	O

core	O

was	O
RC	O

a	O

“	O

,	O

or	O
standard	O

of	O

,	O

)	O
.	O

Drill	O
sample	O
Method	O
recording	O
and	O
assessing	O
core	O
and	O
chip	O
sample	O
Samples	O
were	O
logged	O
and	O
sample	O
recovery	O
estimated	O
on	O
site	O
recovery	O
recoveries	O
and	O
results	O
assessed.	O

by	O
a	O
geologist.	O

Measures	O
taken	O
to	O
maximise	O
sample	O
recovery	O
and	O
ensure	O
Every	O
effort	O
was	O
made	O
to	O
ensure	O
RC	O
samples	O
remained	O
dry	O
to	O
representative	O
nature	O
of	O
the	O
samples.	O

ensure	O
the	O
representative	O
nature	O
of	O
the	O
samples.	O

Whether	O
a	O
relationship	O
exists	O
between	O
sample	O
recovery	O
and	O
grade	O
and	O
whether	O
sample	O
bias	O
may	O
have	O
occurred	O
due	O
to	O
Dry	O
RC	O
samples	O
have	O
a	O
low	O
potential	O
for	O
sample	O
bias.	O

preferential	O
loss/gain	O
of	O
fine/coarse	O
material.	O

Whether	O
core	O
and	O
chip	O
samples	O
have	O
been	O
geologically	O
and	O
Samples	O
were	O
logged	O
by	O
a	O
geologist	O
for	O
recovery	O
,	O
Logging	O
geotechnically	O
logged	O
to	O
a	O
level	O
of	O
detail	O
to	O
support	O
appropriate	O
weathering	O
,	O
moisture	O
,	O
colour	O
,	O
lithology	O
,	O
alteration	O
,	O
texture	O
,	O
Mineral	O
Resource	O
estimation	O
,	O
mining	O
studies	O
and	O
metallurgical	O
mineralogy	O
and	O
mineralisation.	O

studies.	O

Whether	O

Alliance	O
The	O
geology	O
at	O
Weednanna	O
is	O
characterised	O
by	O
a	O
north	O
striking	O
and	O
moderate	O
to	O
steep	O
east-dipping	O
unit	O
of	O
Paleo-	O
Proterozoic	O
Hutchinson	O
Group	O
sediments	O
,	O
consisting	O
of	O
marl	O
and	O
dolomite	O
with	O
lesser	O
sandstone	O
and	O
minor	O
basalt	O
,	O
which	O
have	O
been	O
metamorphosed	O
under	O
upper-amphibolite	O
facies	O
conditions	O
and	O
altered	O
to	O
produce	O
interleaving	O
calc-silicate	O
and	O
magnetite	O
skarn	O
with	O
lesser	O
gneiss	O
and	O
minor	O
amphibolite.	O

This	O
altered	O
meta-sedimentary	O
package	O
is	O
bounded	O
to	O
the	O
east	O
and	O
west	O
by	O
Archaean	O
Sleaford	O
Complex	O
granite	O
and	O
gneiss.	O

The	O
Archaean	O
rocks	O
appear	O
to	O
truncate	O
the	O
meta-	O
sediments	O
at	O
depth	O
at	O
the	O
northern	O
and	O
southern	O
ends	O
of	O
the	O
deposit	O
,	O
with	O
the	O
meta-sediments	O
extending	O
below	O
current	O
drilling	O
in	O
the	O
central	O
area	O
of	O
the	O
deposit.	O

Geology	O
Deposit	O
type	O
,	O
geological	O
setting	O
and	O
style	O
of	O
mineralisation.	O

A	O
keel	O
of	O
north-striking	O
weathered	O
granite	O
of	O
uncertain	O
age	O
occurs	O
near-surface	O
within	O
the	O
Hutchinson	O
Group	O
sediments	O
along	O
most	O
of	O
the	O
deposit	O
area.	O

Pink	O
potassium	O
feldspar-rich	O
granites	O
,	O
potentially	O
of	O
the	O
Hiltaba	O
Granite	O
suite	O
,	O
intrude	O
the	O
Sleaford	O
Complex	O
on	O
the	O
eastern	O
side	O
of	O
the	O
deposit	O
and	O
minor	O
later	O
stage	O
granites	O
cut	O
the	O
metasedimentary	O
package.	O

Gold	O
mineralisation	O
occurs	O
within	O
both	O
the	O
Archaean	O
Sleaford	O
Complex	O
granite	O
and	O
gneiss	O
and	O
Paleo-Proterozoic	O
Hutchinson	O
Group	O
meta-sediments	O
and	O
is	O
associated	O
with	O
the	O
intrusion	O
of	O
Hiltaba	O
Granites	O
and	O
skarn	O
alteration.	O

Gold	O
was	O
deposited	O

Au	O
*Pathfinder	O

for	O

end	O
of	O
hole	O
sample	O
Potential	O
Immediately	O
to	O
the	O
north	O
of	O
the	O
Company	O
’	O
s	O
tenements	O
,	O
gold	O
was	O
mined	O
from	O
north	O
to	O
north-west	O
striking	O
,	O
narrow	O
high-grade	O
quartz	O
veins	O
and	O
stock-work	O
zones	O
hosted	O
within	O
the	O
Payne	O
’	O
s	O
Find	O
“	O
gneiss	O
”	O
(	O
hornblende-biotite-quartz-oligclase	O
tonalite	O
gneiss	O
)	O
and	O
along	O
its	O
contact	O
with	O
mafic	O
volcanic	O
rocks.	O

Notably	O
,	O
gold	O
mineralisation	O
in	O
the	O
Paynes	O
Find	O
Camp	O
has	O
a	O
reported	O
association	O
with	O
Ag	O
,	O
As	O
,	O
Cu	O
,	O
Pb	O
,	O
Sb	O
and	O
W	O
the	O
same	O
as	O
seen	O
in	O
the	O
current	O
AC	O
drilling	O
results	O
(	O
Table	O
1	O
)	O
.	O

Within	O
Oakajee	O
’	O
s	O
tenements	O
at	O
the	O
Matriarch	O
prospect	O
,	O
gold	O
mineralisation	O
is	O
reported	O
to	O
occur	O
in	O
an	O
east-west	O
striking	O
and	O
south	O
dipping	O
quartz	O
stockwork	O
zone	O
hosted	O
in	O
strongly	O
weathered	O
and	O
altered	O
felsic	O
schists.	O

The	O
Matriarch	O
prospect	O
is	O
obscured	O
by	O
shallow	O
cover	O
and	O
the	O
shaft	O
and	O
pits	O
have	O
been	O
filled	O
in	O
and	O
no	O
longer	O
accessible.	O

This	O
zone	O
was	O
not	O
tested	O
by	O
the	O
recent	O
AC	O
drilling.	O

The	O
distribution	O
of	O
gold	O
and	O
pathfinder	O
element	O
results	O
from	O
the	O
wide	O
spaced	O
AC	O
drilling	O
and	O
the	O
association	O
with	O
felsic	O
intrusive	O
rocks	O
manifested	O
as	O
a	O
broad	O
north-north-east	O
striking	O
magnetic	O
low	O
suggest	O
gold	O
mineralisation	O
over	O
a	O
minimum	O
strike	O
of	O
1600m.	O

At	O
the	O
northern	O
end	O
of	O
Oakajee	O
’	O
s	O
tenure	O
,	O
the	O
magnetic	O
low	O
is	O
600m	O
wide	O
tapping	O
to	O
the	O
south	O
in	O
E59/2092	O
where	O
it	O
is	O
approximately	O
200m	O
wide.	O

Only	O
25	O
of	O
the	O
54	O
AC	O
drill	O
holes	O
completed	O
are	O
within	O
this	O
zone.	O

The	O
results	O
are	O
considered	O
encouraging	O
as	O
they	O
show	O
both	O
the	O
felsic	O
rocks	O
and	O
structures	O
that	O
host	O
the	O
high-grade	O
gold	O
veins	O
within	O
the	O
Paynes	O
Find	O
Gold	O
Camp	O
extend	O
south	O
under	O
shallow	O
cover	O
into	O
Oakajee	O
’	O
s	O
tenure.	O

Importantly	O
,	O
these	O
mineralised	O
zones	O
have	O
not	O
previously	O
been	O
effectively	O
targeted	O
by	O
drilling	O
and	O
are	O
expected	O
to	O
host	O
shallow	O
high-grade	O
gold	O
zones	O
similar	O
to	O
that	O
previously	O
mined	O
in	O
the	O
Paynes	O
Find	O
Camp	O
immediately	O
to	O
the	O
north.	O

Next	O
Exploration	O
Steps	O

next	O
exploration	O
stage	O
is	O
to	O
re-sample	O
the	O
anomalous	O
gold	O
zones	O
on	O
1m	O
downhole	O
intervals	O
to	O
better	O
define	O
the	O
target	O
zones.	O

This	O
will	O
be	O
followed	O
by	O
infill	O
AC	O
drilling	O
targeting	O
high	O
grade	O
gold	O
zones	O
as	O
well	O
as	O
step	O
out	O
drilling	O
along	O
strike.	O

About	O

Western	O
Australia	O
The	O
Paynes	O
Find	O
Gold	O
Project	O
is	O
located	O
adjacent	O
to	O
the	O
Paynes	O
Find	O
settlement	O
,	O
approximately	O
455km	O
by	O
road	O
northeast	O
of	O
Perth.	O

The	O
land	O
holding	O
represents	O
the	O
second	O
largest	O
exploration	O
project	O
area	O
within	O
the	O
Paynes	O
Find	O
Greenstone	O
Belt	O
which	O
has	O
produced	O
more	O
than	O
72	O
,	O
000oz	O
of	O
gold.	O

The	O
Paynes	O
Find	O
Gold	O
Project	O
covers	O
mostly	O
greenstone	O
sequences	O
along	O
strike	O
and	O
to	O
the	O
west	O
of	O
the	O
Paynes	O
Find	O
Gold	O
camp.	O

Paynes	O
Find	O

Project	O
has	O
been	O
explored	O
since	O
the	O
1970	O
’	O

little	O
effective	O
testing	O
of	O
the	O
greenstone	O

TABLE	O
1	O
REPORT	O
TEMPLATE	O
1.1	O
Section	O
1	O
Sampling	O
Techniques	O
and	O
Data	O
(	O
Criteria	O
in	O
this	O
section	O
apply	O
to	O
all	O

sections.	O

)	O
Criteria	O
JORC	O
Code	O
explanation	O
Commentary	O
Sampling	O
	O

Nature	O
and	O
quality	O
of	O
sampling	O
(	O
e.g.	O

cut	O
	O

Aircore	O
(	O
AC	O
)	O
drilling	O
was	O
undertaken	O
to	O
techniques	O
channels	O
,	O
random	O
chips	O
,	O
or	O
specific	O
provide	O
the	O
samples.	O

specialised	O
industry	O
standard	O
	O

Samples	O
were	O
collected	O
every	O
1m	O
of	O
measurement	O
tools	O
appropriate	O
to	O
the	O
drilling	O
via	O
a	O
cyclone	O
mounted	O
on	O
the	O
drill	O
minerals	O
under	O
investigation	O
,	O
such	O
as	O
rig.	O

The	O
1m	O
drill	O
samples	O
were	O
laid	O
out	O
on	O
down	O
hole	O
gamma	O
sondes	O
,	O
or	O
handheld	O
the	O
ground	O
next	O
to	O
the	O
rig.	O

Composite	O
XRF	O
instruments	O
,	O
etc.	O

)	O
.	O

These	O
examples	O
samples	O
were	O
then	O
collected	O
over	O
a	O
4m	O
should	O
not	O

2.2	O
Remuneration	O
consultants	O
The	O
Board	O
of	O
Directors	O
and	O
Human	O
Resources	O
and	O
Remuneration	O
Committee	O
seek	O
and	O
consider	O
advice	O
from	O
independent	O
remuneration	O
consultants	O
to	O
ensure	O
that	O
they	O
have	O
all	O
the	O
relevant	O
information	O
at	O
their	O
disposal	O
to	O
determine	O
executive	O
KMP	O
remuneration.	O

The	O
engagement	O
of	O
remuneration	O
consultants	O
is	O
governed	O
by	O
internal	O
protocols	O
that	O
set	O
the	O
parameters	O
around	O
the	O
interaction	O
between	O
management	O
and	O
consultants	O
to	O
minimise	O
the	O
risk	O
of	O
any	O
undue	O
influence	O

What	O

in	O
total	O
fixed	O
remuneration?	O
An	O
executive	O
KMP	O
’	O
s	O

remuneration	O

salary	O
and	O

benefits	O
(	O
including	O
statutory	O

)	O

may	O
be	O

agreed	O
form	O

as	O
cash	O

and	O

that	O
no	O

Company	O
for	O
these	O

of	O

(	O
a	O
)	O
Annual	O
leave	O
has	O
been	O
separately	O
categorised	O
and	O
is	O
measured	O
on	O
an	O
accrual	O
basis	O
and	O
reflects	O
the	O
movement	O
in	O
the	O
accrual	O
over	O
the	O
twelve-month	O
period.	O

Any	O
reduction	O
in	O
accrued	O
annual	O
leave	O
reflects	O
more	O
leave	O
taken/cashed	O
out	O
than	O
that	O
which	O
accrued	O
in	O
the	O
period.	O

(	O
b	O
)	O
Represents	O
direct	O
contributions	O
to	O
superannuation	O
funds	O
based	O
on	O
quarterly	O
contribution	O
limits	O
under	O
Super	O
Guarantee	O
Charge	O
regulations	O
(	O
in	O
2016	O
contributions	O
were	O
based	O
on	O
annual	O
contribution	O
limits	O
)	O
.	O

Amounts	O
greater	O
than	O
the	O
maximum	O
superannuation	O
level	O
have	O
been	O
paid	O
and	O
included	O
in	O
cash	O
salary.	O

(	O
c	O
)	O
Represents	O
the	O
net	O
accrual	O
movement	O
for	O
long	O
service	O
leave	O
(	O
LSL	O
)	O
over	O
the	O
twelve-month	O
period	O
which	O
will	O
only	O
be	O
paid	O
if	O
executive	O
KMP	O
meets	O
the	O
required	O
service	O
conditions.	O

(	O
d	O
)	O
Termination	O
benefits	O
include	O
the	O
value	O
of	O
benefits	O
such	O
as	O
payment	O
for	O
notice	O
period	O
and	O

balances	O

upon	O
termination.	O

(	O
e	O
)	O
The	O
fair	O
values	O
were	O
calculated	O
as	O
at	O
the	O
grant	O
dates.	O

In	O
accordance	O
with	O
the	O
requirements	O
of	O
applicable	O
accounting	O
standards	O
,	O
remuneration	O
includes	O
a	O
proportion	O
of	O
the	O
notional	O
value	O
of	O
equity	O
rights	O
compensation	O
granted	O
or	O
outstanding	O
during	O
the	O
year.	O

The	O
notional	O
value	O
of	O
equity	O
rights	O
granted	O
as	O
compensation	O
which	O
do	O
not	O
vest	O
during	O
the	O
reporting	O
period	O
is	O
determined	O
as	O
at	O
the	O
grant	O
date	O
and	O
progressively	O
allocated	O
over	O
the	O
vesting	O
period.	O

amount	O
included	O
as	O
remuneration	O

or	O

of	O
the	O
benefit	O
(	O

)	O

fact	O
receive.	O

NGANAMPA	O

a	O
limited	O
assurance	O
engagement	O
vary	O
in	O
nature	O
and	O
timing	O
from	O
,	O
and	O
are	O
less	O
in	O
extent	O
than	O
for	O
a	O
reasonable	O
assurance	O
engagement.	O

Consequently	O
the	O
level	O
of	O
assurance	O
obtained	O
in	O
a	O
limited	O
assurance	O
engagement	O
is	O
substantially	O
lower	O
than	O
the	O
assurance	O
that	O
would	O
have	O
been	O
obtained	O
had	O
a	O
reasonable	O
assurance	O
engagement	O
been	O
performed.	O

Misstatements	O
,	O
including	O
omissions	O
,	O
are	O
considered	O
material	O
if	O
,	O
individually	O
or	O
in	O
the	O
aggregate	O
,	O
they	O
could	O
reasonably	O
be	O
expected	O
to	O
influence	O
relevant	O
decisions	O
of	O
the	O
Directors	O
of	O
OZ	O
Minerals	O
Limited.	O

Use	O
of	O
this	O
Assurance	O
Report	O

report	O
has	O
been	O
prepared	O
for	O
the	O
Directors	O
of	O
OZ	O
Minerals	O
Limited	O
for	O
the	O
purpose	O
of	O

on	O

Recognised	O

tax	O
losses	O

to	O
an	O

fraction	O

the	O
amount	O
of	O

year	O

may	O
only	O

after	O
unrestricted	O
tax	O
losses	O
are	O
utilised.	O

Unrecognised	O
tax	O
losses	O

the	O
year	O
,	O
a	O

of	O
unrecognised	O
tax	O

ANNUAL	O
AND	O
SUSTAINABILITY	O
REPORT	O
2017	O
Recognition	O
and	O
measurement	O
of	O
income	O
taxes	O
Current	O
tax	O
The	O
tax	O
currently	O
payable	O
is	O
based	O
on	O
taxable	O
profit	O
for	O
the	O
year	O
,	O
using	O
rates	O
enacted	O
or	O
substantively	O
enacted	O
at	O
reporting	O
date	O
,	O
and	O
any	O
adjustments	O
to	O
tax	O
payable	O
in	O
respect	O
of	O
previous	O
years.	O

Deferred	O
tax	O
Deferred	O
tax	O
assets	O
and	O
liabilities	O
are	O
determined	O
using	O
the	O
balance	O
sheet	O
method	O
which	O
calculates	O
temporary	O
differences	O
based	O
on	O
the	O
difference	O
between	O
the	O
carrying	O
amount	O
of	O
the	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
’	O
s	O
assets	O
and	O
liabilities	O
in	O
the	O
balance	O
sheet	O
and	O
their	O
associated	O
tax	O
bases.	O

Deferred	O
tax	O
assets	O
and	O
liabilities	O
are	O
not	O
recognised	O
for	O
temporary	O
differences	O
arising	O
from	O
investments	O
in	O
subsidiaries	O
where	O
the	O
consolidated	O
entity	O
is	O
able	O
to	O
control	O
the	O
reversal	O
of	O
the	O
temporary	O
differences	O
,	O
and	O
it	O
is	O
probable	O
they	O
will	O
not	O
reverse	O
in	O
the	O
foreseeable	O
future.	O

Deferred	O
tax	O
assets	O
are	O
recognised	O
to	O
the	O
extent	O
that	O
it	O
is	O
probable	O
that	O
future	O
taxable	O
income	O
will	O
be	O
available	O
to	O
utilise	O
them.	O

The	O
carrying	O
amount	O
of	O
deferred	O
tax	O
assets	O
is	O
reviewed	O
at	O
the	O
end	O
of	O
each	O
reporting	O
date	O
and	O
adjusted	O
based	O
on	O
estimates	O
of	O
future	O
taxable	O
income	O
and	O
or	O
capital	O
gains	O
against	O
which	O
the	O
deferred	O
tax	O
asset	O
could	O
be	O
utilised.	O

Deferred	O
tax	O
assets	O
and	O
liabilities	O
are	O
measured	O
at	O
the	O
tax	O
rates	O
applicable	O
to	O
each	O
jurisdiction	O
which	O
are	O
expected	O
to	O
apply	O
in	O
the	O
period	O
when	O
the	O
assets	O
are	O
realised	O
or	O
liabilities	O
discharged	O
and	O
are	O
offset	O
where	O
they	O
relate	O
to	O
the	O
same	O
tax	O
authority	O
and	O
there	O
is	O
a	O
legally	O
enforceable	O
right	O
to	O
offset.	O

Recognition	O
and	O
measurement	O
of	O
inventories	O
Inventory	O
is	O
valued	O
at	O
the	O
lower	O
of	O
cost	O
incurred	O
in	O
bringing	O
product	O
to	O
its	O
present	O
location	O
and	O
condition	O
and	O
net	O
realisable	O
value.	O

Costs	O
are	O
assigned	O
to	O
individual	O
items	O
of	O
inventory	O
on	O
the	O
basis	O
of	O
weighted	O
average	O
costs.	O

Cost	O
comprises	O
direct	O
materials	O
and	O
labour	O
,	O
and	O
a	O
proportion	O
of	O
overhead	O
expenditure	O
directly	O
related	O
to	O
the	O
production	O
of	O
inventories.	O

Expenditure	O
directly	O
related	O
to	O
the	O
production	O
of	O
inventories	O
includes	O
processing	O
costs	O
,	O
transportation	O
costs	O
to	O
the	O
point	O
of	O
sale	O
,	O
and	O
depreciation	O
of	O
plant	O
and	O
equipment	O
and	O
mining	O
property	O
and	O
development	O
assets	O
,	O
the	O
latter	O
of	O
which	O
includes	O
deferred	O
stripping	O
assets	O
and	O
mine	O
rehabilitation	O
costs	O
incurred	O
in	O
the	O
mining	O
process.	O

Net	O
realisable	O
value	O
is	O
calculated	O
by	O
estimating	O
the	O
value	O
that	O
is	O
expected	O
to	O
be	O
realised	O
upon	O
sale	O
of	O
concentrate	O
after	O
deducting	O
estimated	O
costs	O
of	O
processing	O
,	O
and	O
selling	O
costs.	O

This	O
estimation	O
is	O
based	O
on	O
assumptions	O
of	O
future	O
prices	O
and	O
costs	O
,	O
as	O
well	O
as	O
expected	O
future	O
ore	O
blend	O
rates	O
and	O
timing	O
of	O
processing.	O

Inventories	O
expected	O
to	O
be	O
processed	O
or	O
sold	O
within	O
twelve	O
months	O
after	O
balance	O
date	O
are	O
classified	O
as	O
current	O
assets	O
,	O
all	O
other	O
inventories	O
are	O
classified	O
as	O
non-current.104	O

capitalised	O
exploration	O
expenditure.	O

Recognition	O
and	O
measurement	O
of	O
exploration	O
expenditure	O
The	O
ultimate	O
recoupment	O
of	O
costs	O
capitalised	O
Exploration	O
and	O
evaluation	O
expenditure	O
is	O
recognised	O
in	O
the	O
Income	O
Statement	O
as	O
incurred	O
,	O
for	O
exploration	O
and	O
evaluation	O
phases	O
is	O
unless	O
the	O
expenditure	O
is	O
expected	O
to	O
be	O
recouped	O
through	O
successful	O
development	O
and	O
dependent	O
on	O
successful	O
development	O
exploitation	O
of	O
the	O
area	O
of	O
interest	O
,	O
or	O
alternatively	O
by	O
its	O
sale	O
,	O
in	O
which	O
case	O
it	O
is	O
recognised	O
and	O
commercial	O
exploitation	O
or	O
sale	O
of	O
the	O
as	O
an	O
asset	O
on	O
an	O
area	O
of	O
interest	O
basis.	O

respective	O
areas	O
of	O
interest.	O

Exploration	O
and	O
evaluation	O
assets	O
are	O
classified	O
as	O
tangible	O
or	O
intangible	O
according	O
to	O
the	O
nature	O
of	O
the	O
assets.	O

Exploration	O
and	O
evaluation	O
assets	O
are	O
not	O
depreciated	O
and	O
are	O
assessed	O
for	O
impairment	O
if	O
:	O
/	O
sufficient	O
information	O
exists	O
to	O
determine	O
technical	O
feasibility	O
and	O
commercial	O
viability	O
;	O
or	O
/	O
other	O
facts	O
and	O
circumstances	O
suggest	O
that	O
the	O
carrying	O
amount	O
exceeds	O
the	O
recoverable	O
amount.	O

For	O
the	O
purposes	O
of	O
impairment	O
testing	O
,	O
exploration	O
and	O
evaluation	O
assets	O
are	O
allocated	O
to	O
CGUs	O
to	O
which	O
the	O
exploration	O
activity	O
relates.	O

A	O
CGU	O
is	O
not	O
larger	O
than	O
the	O
area	O
of	O
interest.	O

Once	O
the	O
technical	O
feasibility	O
and	O
commercial	O
viability	O
of	O
the	O
extraction	O
of	O
mineral	O
reserves	O
in	O
an	O
area	O
of	O
interest	O
are	O
demonstrable	O
,	O
exploration	O
and	O
evaluation	O
assets	O
attributable	O
to	O
that	O
area	O
of	O
interest	O
are	O
first	O
tested	O
for	O
impairment	O
and	O
then	O
reclassified	O
to	O
mine	O
property	O
and	O
development	O
assets	O
within	O
property	O
,	O
plant	O
and	O
equipment.	O

From	O
time	O
to	O
time	O
the	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
enters	O
into	O
arrangements	O
which	O
enable	O
it	O
to	O
secure	O
the	O
opportunity	O
to	O
explore	O
and	O
potentially	O
earn	O
the	O
right	O
to	O
mineralisation	O
if	O
discovered	O
on	O
underlying	O
exploration	O
tenements	O
held	O
by	O
other	O
entities	O
(	O
earn-in	O
arrangements	O
)	O
.	O

Expenditure	O
incurred	O
under	O
earn-in	O
arrangements	O
is	O
expensed	O
as	O
incurred.	O

Under	O
these	O
agreements	O
OZ	O
Minerals	O
does	O
not	O
assume	O
any	O
liabilities	O
or	O
hold	O
any	O
rights	O
to	O
other	O
assets	O
that	O
the	O
holder	O
of	O
the	O
tenement	O
may	O
possess.108	O
ANNUAL	O
AND	O
SUSTAINABILITY	O
REPORT	O
2017	O
Assets	O
held	O
for	O
sale	O
The	O
Tunnel	O

Machine	O

as	O

AASB	O
5	O
was	O

8.	O

Lease	O
receivable	O
Recognition	O
and	O
measurement	O
of	O
finance	O
lease	O
receivable	O
Leases	O
which	O
transfer	O
substantially	O
all	O
the	O
risk	O
and	O
rewards	O
of	O
ownership	O
of	O
an	O
asset	O
are	O
classified	O
as	O
finance	O
leases.	O

Where	O
a	O
finance	O
lease	O
is	O
provided	O
,	O
the	O
item	O
of	O
equipment	O
is	O
derecognised	O
and	O
the	O
present	O
value	O
of	O
the	O
minimum	O
lease	O
payments	O
receivable	O
are	O
recognised	O
as	O
a	O
lease	O
receivable.	O

Contingent	O
rents	O
are	O
recognised	O
as	O
revenue	O
in	O
the	O
period	O
in	O
which	O
they	O
are	O
earned.	O

The	O
finance	O
lease	O
receivable	O
represents	O
the	O
consideration	O
paid	O
by	O
OZ	O
Minerals	O
to	O
acquire	O
mining	O
equipment	O
which	O
was	O
leased	O
back	O
to	O
Thiess	O
on	O
an	O
interest	O
free	O
basis.	O

OZ	O
Minerals	O
benefits	O
progressively	O
over	O
the	O
mining	O
services	O
contract	O
from	O
reduced	O
mining	O
services	O
charges	O
by	O
Thiess.	O

Upon	O
termination	O
of	O
the	O
mining	O
services	O
contract	O
,	O
any	O
carrying	O
value	O
of	O
lease	O
receivable	O
is	O
expected	O
to	O
be	O
recovered	O
by	O
OZ	O
Minerals	O
from	O
a	O
resale	O
of	O
the	O
equipment	O
to	O
Thiess.	O

The	O
finance	O
lease	O
receivable	O
of	O
$19.6m	O
as	O
at	O
31	O
December	O
2017	O
comprises	O
$27.5m	O
from	O
the	O
comparative	O
year	O
,	O
less	O
a	O
$7.9	O
million	O
(	O
2016	O
:	O
$7.3	O
million	O
)	O
amortisation	O
charge	O
against	O
the	O
finance	O
lease	O
receivable	O
during	O
the	O
year.	O

9.	O

Provisions	O
MINE	O
REHABILITATION	O
,	O
RESTORATION	O
AND	O
DISMANTLING	O
OBLIGATIONS	O
The	O
provision	O
for	O
mine	O
rehabilitation	O
includes	O
future	O
cost	O
estimates	O
associated	O
with	O
reclamation	O
,	O
plant	O
closures	O
,	O
waste	O
site	O
closures	O
,	O
monitoring	O
,	O
demobilisation	O
of	O
equipment	O
,	O
decontamination	O
,	O
water	O
purification	O
and	O
permanent	O
storage	O
of	O
historical	O
residues.	O

Uncertainty	O
exists	O
as	O
to	O
the	O
amount	O
of	O
rehabilitation	O
obligations	O
which	O
will	O
be	O
incurred	O
due	O
to	O
the	O
impact	O
of	O
changes	O
in	O
environmental	O
legislation	O
,	O
and	O
many	O
other	O
factors	O
,	O
including	O
future	O
changes	O
in	O
technology	O
,	O
price	O
increases	O
and	O
changes	O
in	O
interest	O
rates.	O

The	O
calculation	O
of	O
these	O
provision	O
estimates	O
requires	O
assumptions	O
such	O
as	O
application	O
of	O
environmental	O
legislation	O
,	O
plant	O
closure	O
dates	O
,	O
available	O
technologies	O
,	O
engineering	O
cost	O
estimates	O
and	O
discount	O
rates.	O

A	O
change	O
in	O
any	O
of	O
the	O
assumptions	O
used	O
may	O
have	O
a	O
material	O
impact	O
on	O
the	O
carrying	O
value	O
of	O
mine	O
rehabilitation	O
,	O
restoration	O
and	O
dismantling	O
provisions.	O

Recognition	O
and	O
measurement	O
of	O
provisions	O
Provisions	O
are	O
measured	O
at	O
the	O
present	O
value	O
of	O
the	O
best	O
estimate	O
of	O
the	O
expenditure	O
required	O
to	O
settle	O
the	O
present	O
obligation	O
at	O
balance	O
sheet	O
date.	O

The	O
discount	O
rate	O
used	O
to	O
determine	O
the	O
present	O
value	O
reflects	O
current	O
market	O
assessments	O
of	O
the	O
time	O
value	O
of	O
money	O
and	O
the	O
risks	O
specific	O
to	O
the	O
liability.	O

The	O
increase	O
in	O
provisions	O
due	O
to	O
the	O
passage	O
of	O
time	O
is	O
recognised	O
in	O
the	O
Income	O
Statement	O
as	O
financing	O
expenses.	O

Provisions	O
are	O
made	O
for	O
the	O
estimated	O
cost	O
of	O
rehabilitation	O
,	O
decommissioning	O
and	O
restoration	O
relating	O
to	O
areas	O
disturbed	O
during	O
mining	O
and	O
exploration	O
operations	O
up	O
to	O
the	O
reporting	O
date	O
but	O
not	O
yet	O
rehabilitated.	O

Provisions	O
for	O
mine	O
rehabilitation	O
are	O
based	O
on	O
current	O
estimates	O
of	O
costs	O
to	O
rehabilitate	O
such	O
areas	O
,	O
discounted	O
to	O
their	O
present	O
value	O
based	O
on	O
expected	O
future	O
cash	O
flows.	O

The	O
estimated	O
costs	O
include	O
the	O
current	O
cost	O
of	O
rehabilitation	O
necessary	O
to	O
meet	O
legislative	O
requirements.	O

Changes	O
in	O
estimates	O
are	O
dealt	O
with	O
on	O
a	O
prospective	O
basis	O
as	O
they	O
arise.	O

The	O
provision	O
is	O
recognised	O
as	O
a	O
liability	O
,	O
separated	O
into	O
current	O
(	O
estimated	O
costs	O
arising	O
within	O
twelve	O
months	O
)	O
and	O
non-current	O
components	O
based	O
on	O
the	O
expected	O
timing	O
of	O
these	O
cash	O
flows.	O

Ordinary	O

to	O

upon	O
a	O

share.	O

Recognition	O
and	O

of	O

capital	O

shares	O
are	O
classified	O

equity.	O

about	O

instruments	O

Provisional	O

to	O
trade	O

are	O

initially	O
at	O

value	O
and	O
subsequently	O
measured	O
at	O
amortised	O
cost	O

effective	O

method.	O

The	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
derecognises	O
a	O
financial	O
asset	O
or	O
part	O
of	O
it	O
when	O

and	O
only	O
when	O

rights	O
to	O
the	O
cash	O
flows	O
from	O
the	O
financial	O
asset	O
expire	O
or	O
the	O
financial	O
asset	O
is	O
transferred	O
to	O
another	O
party	O
without	O
retaining	O
control	O
or	O
substantially	O
all	O
risks	O
and	O
rewards	O
of	O
the	O
asset.	O

On	O

of	O
a	O
financial	O
asset	O
,	O

difference	O
between	O

date	O
of	O

)	O
and	O
the	O
consideration	O
received	O
(	O
including	O
any	O
new	O
asset	O
obtained	O
less	O
any	O
new	O
liability	O
assumed	O
)	O
and	O
any	O
cumulative	O
gain	O
or	O
loss	O
that	O
had	O
been	O
recognised	O
in	O
equity	O
is	O
recognised	O
in	O
the	O
Income	O
Statement.	O

A	O
financial	O
asset	O
measured	O
at	O
amortised	O
cost	O
is	O
assessed	O
at	O
each	O
reporting	O
date	O
as	O
to	O
whether	O
there	O
is	O
any	O
objective	O
evidence	O
of	O
impairment	O
as	O
a	O
result	O
of	O
one	O
or	O
more	O
events	O
having	O
an	O
impact	O
on	O
the	O
estimated	O
future	O
cash	O
flows	O
of	O
the	O
asset.	O

An	O
impairment	O
loss	O
in	O
respect	O
of	O
financial	O
assets	O
measured	O
at	O
amortised	O
cost	O
is	O
recognised	O
in	O
the	O
Income	O
Statement	O
and	O
is	O
measured	O
as	O
the	O
difference	O
between	O
the	O
asset	O
’	O
s	O
carrying	O
amount	O
and	O
the	O
present	O
value	O
of	O
estimated	O
future	O
cash	O
flows	O
discounted	O
at	O
the	O
asset	O
’	O
s	O
original	O
effective	O
interest	O
rate.	O

The	O
carrying	O
amount	O
of	O
the	O
asset	O
is	O
reduced	O
through	O
the	O
use	O
of	O
an	O
allowance	O
account.	O

In	O
the	O
event	O
that	O
an	O
impairment	O
loss	O
is	O
reversed	O
,	O
the	O
asset	O
’	O
s	O
carrying	O
amount	O
can	O
not	O
exceed	O
what	O
the	O
carrying	O
amount	O
would	O
have	O
been	O
had	O
the	O
impairment	O
not	O
been	O
recognised.	O

The	O
amount	O
of	O
the	O
reversal	O
is	O
recognised	O
in	O
the	O
Income	O
Statement.	O

Non-derivative	O
financial	O
liabilities	O
All	O
financial	O
liabilities	O
are	O
recognised	O
initially	O
at	O
fair	O
value	O
and	O
net	O
of	O
directly	O
attributable	O
transaction	O
costs.	O

Trade	O
and	O
other	O
payables	O
represent	O
liabilities	O
for	O
goods	O
and	O
services	O
provided	O
to	O
the	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
prior	O
to	O
the	O
end	O
of	O
the	O
financial	O
year	O
which	O
are	O
unpaid.	O

The	O
amounts	O
are	O
non-interest-bearing	O
,	O
unsecured	O
and	O
are	O
usually	O
paid	O
within	O
30	O
days	O
of	O
recognition.	O

The	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
derecognises	O
financial	O
liabilities	O
when	O
its	O
obligations	O
are	O
discharged	O
,	O
cancelled	O
or	O
expire.	O

The	O
difference	O
between	O
the	O
carrying	O
amount	O
of	O
the	O
liability	O
derecognised	O
and	O
the	O
consideration	O
paid	O
and	O
payable	O
is	O
recognised	O
in	O
the	O
Income	O
Statement.	O

Derivative	O
financial	O
instruments	O
Recognition	O
and	O
measurement	O
Derivative	O
financial	O
instruments	O
are	O
initially	O
recognised	O
at	O
fair	O
value	O
on	O
the	O
date	O
the	O
derivative	O
contract	O
is	O
entered	O
into	O
and	O
are	O
subsequently	O
remeasured	O
to	O
their	O
fair	O
value	O
at	O
each	O
reporting	O
date.	O

Changes	O
in	O
the	O
fair	O
value	O
of	O
any	O
derivative	O
instrument	O
are	O
recognised	O
in	O
the	O
Income	O
Statement	O
,	O
or	O
Other	O
Comprehensive	O
Income	O
,	O
based	O
the	O
designation	O
and	O
effectiveness	O
of	O
the	O
hedge	O
instrument.	O

Derivative	O
financial	O
instruments	O
that	O
have	O
been	O
designated	O
as	O
a	O
hedge	O
instrument	O
are	O
initially	O
recognised	O
at	O
fair	O
value	O
on	O
the	O
date	O
the	O
derivative	O
contract	O
is	O
entered	O
into	O
and	O
are	O
subsequently	O
remeasured	O
to	O
their	O
fair	O
value	O
at	O
each	O
reporting	O
date.	O

Formal	O
designation	O
of	O
the	O
hedge	O
and	O
documentation	O
of	O
the	O
relationship	O
between	O
the	O
hedging	O
instrument	O
and	O
the	O
hedged	O
item	O
is	O
finalised	O
at	O
the	O
inception	O
of	O
the	O
transaction.	O

Changes	O
in	O
the	O
fair	O
value	O
of	O
the	O
derivative	O
financial	O
instrument	O
which	O
has	O
been	O
designated	O
in	O
a	O
hedge	O
relationship	O
will	O
be	O
recognised	O
in	O
Other	O
Comprehensive	O
Income	O
if	O
the	O
hedging	O
relationship	O
remains	O
effective	O
and	O
the	O
underlying	O
hedge	O
item	O
has	O
not	O
been	O
recognised	O
in	O
the	O
Income	O
Statement	O
,	O
or	O
recognised	O
in	O
the	O
Income	O
Statement	O
if	O
the	O
hedge	O
relationship	O
is	O
no	O
longer	O
effective	O
or	O
the	O
underlying	O
hedged	O
item	O
has	O
been	O
recognised	O
in	O
the	O
Income	O
Statement.	O

Any	O

of	O

of	O

ANNUAL	O
AND	O
SUSTAINABILITY	O
REPORT	O
2017	O
Foreign	O
currency	O
exchange	O
risk	O
management	O
and	O
sensitivity	O
analysis	O
The	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
is	O
exposed	O
to	O
foreign	O
currency	O
risk	O
arising	O
from	O
assets	O
and	O
liabilities	O
that	O
are	O
held	O
in	O
currencies	O
other	O
than	O
the	O
Australian	O
dollar.	O

All	O
OZ	O
Minerals	O
operations	O
have	O
a	O
functional	O
currency	O
of	O
Australian	O
dollars.	O

An	O
entity	O
’	O
s	O
functional	O
currency	O
is	O
the	O
currency	O
of	O
the	O
primary	O
economic	O
environment	O
in	O
which	O
the	O
entity	O
operates.	O

Determination	O
of	O
an	O
entity	O
’	O
s	O
functional	O
currency	O
requires	O
management	O
’	O
s	O
judgement	O
when	O
considering	O
a	O
number	O
of	O
factors	O
including	O
the	O
currency	O
that	O
mainly	O
influences	O
revenue	O
,	O
costs	O
of	O
production	O
,	O
and	O
competitive	O
forces	O
and	O
regulations	O
which	O
impact	O
revenue.	O

In	O
addition	O
,	O
consideration	O
must	O
be	O
given	O
to	O
the	O
currency	O
in	O
which	O
financing	O
and	O
operating	O
activities	O
are	O
undertaken.	O

Foreign	O
currency	O
transactions	O
are	O
translated	O
into	O
the	O
functional	O
currency	O
using	O
exchange	O
rates	O
prevailing	O
at	O
the	O
date	O
of	O
the	O
transaction.	O

Foreign	O
exchange	O
gains	O
and	O
losses	O
resulting	O
from	O
the	O
settlement	O
of	O
such	O
transactions	O
and	O
from	O
the	O
translation	O
at	O
year	O
end	O
exchange	O
rates	O
of	O
financial	O
assets	O
and	O
liabilities	O
denominated	O
in	O
foreign	O
currencies	O
are	O
recognised	O
in	O
the	O
Income	O
Statement	O
except	O
for	O
gold	O
derivative	O
contracts	O
which	O
are	O
recognised	O
in	O
Other	O
Comprehensive	O
Income.	O

0.9fInAnCIAL	O
RePoR	O
t	O
121	O
Basis	O
of	O
consolidation	O
Investments	O
in	O
subsidiaries	O
Subsidiaries	O
are	O
those	O
entities	O
over	O
which	O
the	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
is	O
capable	O
of	O
exerting	O
control.	O

The	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
controls	O
an	O
entity	O
when	O
it	O
is	O
exposed	O
to	O
,	O
or	O
has	O
rights	O
to	O
,	O
variable	O
returns	O
from	O
its	O
involvement	O
with	O
the	O
entity	O
and	O
has	O
the	O
ability	O
to	O
affect	O
those	O
returns	O
through	O
its	O
power	O
over	O
the	O
entity.	O

Where	O
the	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
holds	O
less	O
than	O
a	O
majority	O
of	O
the	O
voting	O
rights	O
,	O
other	O
relevant	O
factors	O
are	O
considered	O
in	O
assessing	O
whether	O
power	O
over	O
the	O
entity	O
exists.	O

Factors	O
considered	O
include	O
rights	O
arising	O
from	O
other	O
contractual	O
arrangements	O
,	O
any	O
contractual	O
arrangements	O
with	O
other	O
vote	O
holders	O
as	O
well	O
as	O
the	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
’	O
s	O
voting	O
and	O
potential	O
voting	O
rights.	O

The	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
reassesses	O
whether	O
it	O
controls	O
an	O
entity	O
if	O
facts	O
and	O
circumstances	O
indicate	O
that	O
there	O
has	O
been	O
a	O
change	O
in	O
one	O
of	O
the	O
factors	O
which	O
indicate	O
control.	O

Subsidiaries	O
are	O
consolidated	O
from	O
the	O
date	O
on	O
which	O
control	O
is	O
assessed	O
to	O
exist	O
until	O
the	O
date	O
that	O
control	O
ceases.	O

The	O
purchase	O
method	O
of	O
accounting	O
is	O
used	O
to	O
account	O
for	O
the	O
acquisition	O
of	O
subsidiaries	O
by	O
the	O
Consolidated	O
Entity.	O

Intercompany	O
transactions	O
,	O
balances	O
and	O
unrealised	O
gains	O
and	O
losses	O
on	O
transactions	O
between	O
companies	O
controlled	O
by	O
the	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
are	O
eliminated	O
on	O
consolidation.	O

AASB	O
15	O
Revenue	O
from	O
Contracts	O
with	O
Customers	O
AASB	O
15	O
changes	O
the	O
timing	O
(	O
and	O
in	O
some	O
case	O
,	O
the	O
quantum	O
)	O
of	O
revenue	O
recognised	O
from	O
customers.	O

Currently	O
revenue	O
for	O
domestic	O
sales	O
is	O
recognised	O
when	O
the	O
concentrates	O
are	O
delivered	O
to	O
the	O
customers	O
’	O
premises	O
,	O
which	O
is	O
the	O
point	O
when	O
the	O
customer	O
takes	O
over	O
the	O
risk	O
and	O
rewards	O
of	O
ownership	O
transfer.	O

The	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
’	O
s	O
assessment	O
indicates	O
that	O
under	O
AASB	O
15	O
,	O
revenue	O
will	O
continued	O
to	O
be	O
recognised	O
on	O
the	O
same	O
basis	O
when	O
the	O
customer	O
obtains	O
control	O
of	O
the	O
concentrates.	O

Revenue	O
for	O
export	O
sales	O
is	O
currently	O
recognised	O
when	O
shipments	O
of	O
concentrates	O
are	O
loaded	O
on	O
to	O
the	O
vessel	O
as	O
the	O
risk	O
and	O
reward	O
of	O
ownership	O
is	O
transferred	O
to	O
the	O
customer	O
at	O
that	O
point.	O

The	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
’	O
s	O
assessment	O
under	O
AASB	O
15	O
indicates	O
that	O
the	O
export	O
contracts	O
are	O
made	O
up	O
of	O
two	O
performance	O
obligations.	O

The	O
first	O
obligation	O
to	O
deliver	O
the	O
concentrates	O
to	O
the	O
port	O
of	O
shipment	O
and	O
the	O
second	O
obligation	O
is	O
to	O
organise	O
shipping	O
of	O
the	O
concentrate	O
,	O
which	O
will	O
be	O
satisfied	O
when	O
concentrates	O
are	O
delivered	O
to	O
the	O
destination	O
port.	O

The	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
assessed	O
that	O
revenue	O
relating	O
to	O
the	O
first	O
obligation	O
of	O
delivery	O
of	O
the	O
concentrates	O
to	O
the	O
port	O
of	O
shipping	O
will	O
be	O
recognised	O
at	O
that	O
point	O
and	O
revenue	O
relating	O
to	O
the	O
shipping	O
obligation	O
will	O
be	O
recognised	O
in	O
future	O
periods	O
upon	O
delivery	O
of	O
concentrates.	O

the	O
basis	O

that	O

,	O

(	O

’	O

)	O

’	O

$73.975	O
million	O
(	O

)	O
.	O

Alliance	O
applied	O

to	O

Ruling	O
2015/81	O
was	O
subsequently	O
issued.	O

A	O

Meeting	O
of	O
Alliance	O
was	O
held	O
in	O

of	O
$0.12	O
per	O

for	O

share	O
held	O
on	O
the	O
Record	O
Date.	O

The	O
Sale	O
completed	O
on	O
18	O
September	O
2015.	O

On	O
12	O
October	O
2015	O
,	O
trading	O
in	O
Alliance	O
shares	O
began	O
on	O
an	O
‘	O
ex	O
capital	O
return	O
basis	O
’	O
.	O

The	O
Record	O
date	O
for	O
the	O
Capital	O
Return	O
was	O
14	O
October	O
2015.	O

Processing	O
of	O
payments	O
totalling	O
$50.06	O
million	O
commenced	O
on	O
28	O
October	O
2015.	O

The	O
Class	O
Ruling	O
noted	O
that	O
:	O
“	O
Alliance	O
will	O
not	O
return	O
capital	O
of	O
any	O
more	O
than	O
$0.12	O
per	O
share	O
at	O
this	O
time	O
until	O
Alliance	O
has	O
determined	O
its	O
tax	O
liability	O
in	O
respect	O
of	O
the	O
Sale	O
,	O
which	O
will	O
not	O
be	O
finalised	O
until	O
after	O
the	O
end	O
of	O
the	O
income	O
year	O
ended	O
30	O
June	O
2016.	O

”	O
Alliance	O
recently	O
received	O
tax	O
advice	O
from	O
its	O
advisors	O
that	O
it	O
will	O
be	O
able	O
to	O
utilise	O
its	O
carry	O
forward	O
tax	O
losses	O
to	O
offset	O
the	O
tax	O
gain	O
made	O
on	O
the	O
sale	O
of	O
its	O
interest	O
in	O
the	O
Four	O
Mile	O
Uranium	O
Project	O
as	O
it	O
satisfied	O
the	O
company	O
loss	O
recoupment	O
test	O
at	O
30	O
June	O
2016	O
,	O
being	O
the	O
continuity	O
of	O
ownership	O
test.	O

Alliance	O
has	O
been	O
advised	O
to	O
apply	O
for	O
another	O
Class	O
Ruling	O
to	O
enable	O
a	O
further	O
return	O
of	O
capital	O
to	O
be	O
put	O
to	O
shareholders.	O

If	O
the	O
Class	O
Ruling	O
is	O
positive	O
and	O
is	O
approved	O
by	O
shareholders	O
,	O
the	O
further	O
return	O
of	O
capital	O
would	O
be	O
made	O
as	O
soon	O
as	O
possible.	O

At	O
30	O
June	O
2016	O
Alliance	O
had	O
cash	O
reserves	O
of	O
$24.7	O
million.	O

On	O
26	O
April	O

,	O
the	O
Company	O

the	O

of	O
Mr	O

On	O
26	O
May	O
2016	O
,	O
Alliance	O
announced	O
the	O
establishment	O
of	O
a	O
Share	O
Sale	O
Facility	O
(	O
Facility	O
)	O
for	O
holders	O
of	O
unmarketable	O
parcels	O
of	O
shares	O
in	O
the	O
Company.	O

The	O
Facility	O
allowed	O
investors	O
with	O
small	O
holdings	O
to	O
dispose	O
of	O
their	O
unmarketable	O
parcels	O
and	O
will	O
allow	O
the	O
Company	O
to	O
reduce	O
administrative	O
costs.	O

Pursuant	O
to	O
the	O
terms	O
of	O
the	O
facility	O
,	O
2	O
,	O
989	O
shareholders	O
who	O
held	O
unmarketable	O
parcels	O
of	O
shares	O
as	O
at	O
7pm	O
AEST	O
on	O
25	O
May	O
2016	O
(	O
post-reporting	O
)	O
have	O
agreed	O
to	O
sell	O
their	O
shares.	O

These	O
holdings	O
total	O
9	O
,	O
428	O
,	O
409	O
shares.	O

At	O
the	O
Monardes	O
copper-uranium	O
project	O
in	O
Chile	O
,	O
Alliance	O
completed	O
a	O

drilling	O
program	O
targeting	O
copper	O
and	O
uranium.	O

However	O
,	O
the	O
results	O
were	O
too	O
low	O
grade	O
to	O
warrant	O
further	O
work	O
and	O
it	O
was	O
decided	O
to	O
withdraw	O
from	O
exploration	O
activities	O
in	O
Chile.	O

the	O
year	O
,	O

)	O

period	O

the	O
asset.	O

the	O

for	O
prior	O
periods	O
,	O
where	O
applicable.	O

Deferred	O

liabilities	O

assets	O

and	O

assets	O
against	O

and	O

to	O
liabilities	O

,	O
based	O
on	O
those	O
tax	O
rates	O
that	O

NOTE	O
11.	O

CURRENT	O
ASSETS	O
-	O

TRADE	O
AND	O
OTHER	O
RECEIVABLES	O
Trade	O
receivables	O
-	O

1	O
,	O
800	O
Accrued	O
revenue	O
26	O
,	O
950	O
1	O
,	O
289	O
GST	O
receivable	O
15	O
,	O
791	O
104	O
,	O
432	O
42	O
,	O
741	O
107	O
,	O
521	O
Accounting	O
policy	O
for	O
trade	O
and	O
other	O
receivables	O
Trade	O
receivables	O
are	O
initially	O
recognised	O
at	O
fair	O
value	O
and	O
subsequently	O
measured	O
at	O
amortised	O
cost	O
using	O
the	O
effective	O
interest	O
method	O
,	O
less	O
any	O
provision	O
for	O
impairment.	O

Trade	O
receivables	O
are	O
generally	O
due	O
for	O
settlement	O
within	O
30	O
days.	O

Collectability	O
of	O
trade	O
receivables	O
is	O
reviewed	O
on	O
an	O
ongoing	O
basis.	O

Debts	O
which	O
are	O
known	O
to	O
be	O
uncollectable	O
are	O
written	O
off	O
by	O
reducing	O
the	O
carrying	O
amount	O
directly.	O

A	O
provision	O
for	O
impairment	O
of	O
trade	O
receivables	O
is	O
raised	O
when	O
there	O
is	O
objective	O
evidence	O
that	O
the	O
consolidated	O
entity	O
will	O
not	O
be	O
able	O
to	O
collect	O
all	O
amounts	O
due	O
according	O
to	O
the	O
original	O
terms	O
of	O
the	O
receivables.	O

Significant	O
financial	O
difficulties	O
of	O
the	O
debtor	O
,	O
probability	O
that	O
the	O
debtor	O
will	O
enter	O
bankruptcy	O
or	O
financial	O
reorganisation	O
and	O
default	O
or	O
delinquency	O
in	O
payments	O
(	O
more	O
than	O
60	O
days	O
overdue	O
)	O
are	O
considered	O
indicators	O
that	O
the	O
trade	O
receivable	O
may	O
be	O
impaired.	O

The	O
amount	O
of	O
the	O
impairment	O
allowance	O
is	O
the	O
difference	O
between	O
the	O
asset's	O
carrying	O
amount	O
and	O
the	O
present	O
value	O
of	O
estimated	O
future	O
cash	O
flows	O
,	O
discounted	O
at	O
the	O
original	O
effective	O
interest	O
rate.	O

Cash	O
flows	O
relating	O
to	O
short-term	O
receivables	O
are	O
not	O
discounted	O
if	O
the	O
effect	O
of	O
discounting	O
is	O
immaterial.	O

Other	O
receivables	O
are	O
recognised	O
at	O
amortised	O
cost	O
,	O
less	O
any	O
provision	O
for	O
impairment.	O

Accounting	O
policy	O
for	O
Goods	O
&	O
Services	O
Tax	O
(	O
‘	O
GST	O
’	O
)	O
and	O
other	O
similar	O
taxes	O
Revenues	O
,	O
expenses	O
and	O
assets	O
are	O
recognised	O
net	O
of	O
the	O
amount	O
of	O
associated	O
GST	O
,	O
unless	O
the	O
GST	O
incurred	O
is	O
not	O
recoverable	O
from	O
the	O
tax	O
authority.	O

In	O
this	O
case	O
it	O
is	O
recognised	O
as	O
part	O
of	O
the	O
cost	O
of	O
the	O
acquisition	O
of	O
the	O
asset	O
or	O
as	O
part	O
of	O
the	O
expense.	O

Receivables	O
and	O
payables	O
are	O
stated	O
inclusive	O
of	O
the	O
amount	O
of	O
GST	O
receivable	O
or	O
payable.	O

The	O
net	O
amount	O
of	O
GST	O
recoverable	O
from	O
,	O
or	O
payable	O
to	O
,	O
the	O
tax	O
authority	O
is	O
included	O
in	O
other	O
receivables	O
or	O
other	O
payables	O
in	O
the	O
statement	O
of	O
financial	O
position.	O

Cash	O
flows	O
are	O
presented	O
on	O
a	O
gross	O
basis.	O

The	O
GST	O
components	O
of	O
cash	O
flows	O
arising	O
from	O
investing	O
or	O
financing	O
activities	O
which	O
are	O
recoverable	O
from	O
,	O
or	O
payable	O
to	O
the	O
tax	O
authority	O
,	O
are	O
presented	O
as	O
operating	O
cash	O
flows.	O

Commitments	O
and	O
contingencies	O
are	O
disclosed	O
net	O
of	O
the	O
amount	O
of	O
GST	O
recoverable	O
from	O
,	O
or	O
payable	O
to	O
,	O
the	O
tax	O
authority.	O

ANNUAL	O
REPORT	O
2016	O
29Notes	O
to	O
the	O
financial	O
statements	O
30	O
June	O
2016	O
Accounting	O
policy	O
for	O
non-current	O
assets	O
classified	O
as	O
held	O
for	O
sale	O
Non-current	O
assets	O
are	O
not	O
depreciated	O
or	O
amortised	O
while	O
they	O
are	O
Non-current	O
assets	O
and	O
assets	O
of	O
disposal	O
groups	O
are	O
classified	O
as	O
classified	O
as	O
held	O
for	O
sale.	O

Interest	O
and	O
other	O
expenses	O
attributable	O
held	O
for	O
sale	O
if	O
their	O
carrying	O
amount	O
will	O

are	O
usually	O

within	O
30	O
days	O
of	O
recognition.	O

date	O

measured	O
as	O
the	O
present	O
value	O
of	O
expected	O
future	O
payments	O
to	O
be	O
made	O
in	O
respect	O
of	O
services	O
provided	O
by	O
employees	O
up	O
to	O
the	O
reporting	O
date	O
using	O
the	O
projected	O
unit	O
credit	O
method.	O

Consideration	O
is	O
given	O
to	O
expected	O
future	O
wage	O
and	O
salary	O
levels	O
,	O
experience	O
of	O
employee	O
departures	O
and	O
periods	O
of	O
service.	O

Expected	O
future	O
payments	O
are	O
discounted	O
using	O
market	O
yields	O
at	O
the	O
reporting	O
date	O
on	O
national	O
corporate	O
bonds	O
with	O
terms	O
to	O
maturity	O
and	O
currency	O
that	O
match	O
,	O
as	O
closely	O
as	O
possible	O
,	O
the	O
estimated	O
future	O
cash	O
outflows.	O

Ordinary	O
shares	O
Ordinary	O
shares	O
entitle	O
the	O
holder	O
to	O
participate	O
in	O
dividends	O
and	O
the	O
proceeds	O
on	O
the	O
winding	O
up	O
of	O
the	O
company	O
in	O
proportion	O
to	O
the	O
number	O
of	O
and	O
amounts	O
paid	O
on	O
the	O
shares	O
held.	O

The	O
fully	O
paid	O
ordinary	O
shares	O
have	O
no	O
par	O
value	O
and	O
the	O
company	O
does	O
not	O
have	O
a	O
limited	O
amount	O
of	O
authorised	O
capital.	O

On	O
a	O
show	O
of	O
hands	O
every	O
member	O
present	O
at	O
a	O
meeting	O
in	O
person	O
or	O
by	O
proxy	O
shall	O
have	O
one	O
vote	O
and	O
upon	O
a	O
poll	O
each	O
share	O
shall	O
have	O
one	O
vote.	O

Share	O
buy-back	O
There	O
is	O
no	O
current	O
on-market	O
share	O
buy-back.	O

Capital	O
risk	O
management	O
The	O
consolidated	O
entity's	O
objectives	O
when	O
managing	O
capital	O
are	O
to	O
safeguard	O
its	O
ability	O
to	O
continue	O
as	O
a	O
going	O
concern	O
,	O
so	O
that	O
it	O
can	O
provide	O
returns	O
for	O
shareholders	O
and	O
benefits	O
for	O
other	O
stakeholders	O
and	O
to	O
maintain	O
an	O
optimum	O
capital	O
structure	O
to	O
reduce	O
the	O
cost	O
of	O
capital.	O

Capital	O
is	O
regarded	O
as	O
total	O
equity	O
,	O
as	O
recognised	O
in	O
the	O
statement	O
of	O
financial	O
position	O
,	O
plus	O
net	O
debt.	O

Net	O
debt	O
is	O
calculated	O
as	O
total	O
borrowings	O
less	O
cash	O
and	O
cash	O
equivalents.	O

In	O
order	O
to	O
maintain	O
or	O
adjust	O
the	O
capital	O
structure	O
,	O
the	O
consolidated	O
entity	O
may	O
issue	O
new	O
shares	O
or	O
sell	O
assets	O
to	O
reduce	O
debt.	O

The	O
consolidated	O
entity	O
would	O
look	O
to	O
raise	O
capital	O
when	O
an	O
opportunity	O
to	O
invest	O
in	O
a	O
business	O
or	O
company	O
was	O
seen	O
as	O
value	O
adding	O
relative	O
to	O
the	O
current	O
parent	O
entity's	O
share	O
price	O
at	O
the	O
time	O
of	O
the	O
investment.	O

The	O
consolidated	O
entity	O
is	O
actively	O
pursuing	O
additional	O
investments	O
in	O
the	O
short	O
term	O
to	O
supplement	O
its	O
existing	O
businesses	O
in	O
order	O
to	O
maximise	O
synergies.	O

The	O
consolidated	O
entity	O
is	O
not	O
subject	O
to	O
any	O
financing	O
arrangement	O
covenants.	O

The	O
capital	O
risk	O
management	O
policy	O
remains	O
unchanged	O
from	O
the	O
30	O
June	O
2015	O
Annual	O
Report.	O

Accounting	O
policy	O
for	O
issued	O
capital	O
Ordinary	O
shares	O
are	O
classified	O
as	O
equity.	O

Incremental	O
costs	O
directly	O
attributable	O
to	O
the	O
issue	O
of	O
new	O
shares	O
or	O
options	O
are	O
shown	O
in	O
equity	O
as	O
a	O
deduction	O
,	O
net	O
of	O
tax	O
,	O
from	O
the	O
proceeds.	O

ANNUAL	O
REPORT	O
2016	O
35Notes	O
to	O
the	O
financial	O
statements	O
30	O
June	O
2016	O
NOTE	O
24.	O

FINANCIAL	O
INSTRUMENTS	O
Financial	O
risk	O
management	O
objectives	O
The	O
consolidated	O
entity's	O
activities	O
expose	O
it	O
to	O
a	O
variety	O
of	O
financial	O
risks	O
:	O
market	O
risk	O
(	O
including	O
foreign	O
currency	O
risk	O
,	O
price	O
risk	O
and	O
interest	O
rate	O
risk	O
)	O
,	O
credit	O
risk	O
and	O
liquidity	O
risk.	O

The	O
consolidated	O
entity's	O
overall	O
risk	O
management	O
program	O
focuses	O
on	O
the	O
unpredictability	O
of	O
financial	O
markets	O
and	O
seeks	O
to	O
minimise	O
potential	O
adverse	O
effects	O
on	O
the	O
financial	O
performance	O
of	O
the	O
consolidated	O
entity.	O

The	O
consolidated	O
entity	O
uses	O
different	O
methods	O
to	O
measure	O
different	O
types	O
of	O
risk	O
to	O
which	O
it	O
is	O
exposed.	O

These	O
methods	O
include	O
sensitivity	O
analysis	O
in	O
the	O
case	O
of	O
interest	O
rate	O
,	O
foreign	O
exchange	O
and	O
other	O
price	O
risks	O
,	O
ageing	O
analysis	O
for	O
credit	O
risk	O
and	O
beta	O
analysis	O
in	O
respect	O
of	O
investment	O
portfolios	O
to	O
determine	O
market	O
risk.	O

Risk	O
management	O
is	O
carried	O
out	O
by	O
senior	O
finance	O
executives	O
(	O
'finance'	O
)	O
under	O
policies	O
approved	O
by	O
the	O
Board	O
of	O
Directors	O
(	O
'the	O
Board'	O
)	O
.	O

These	O
policies	O
include	O
identification	O
and	O
analysis	O
of	O
the	O
risk	O
exposure	O
of	O
the	O
consolidated	O
entity	O
and	O
appropriate	O
procedures	O
,	O
controls	O
and	O
risk	O
limits.	O

Finance	O
identifies	O
,	O
evaluates	O
and	O
hedges	O
financial	O
risks	O
within	O
the	O
consolidated	O
entity's	O
operating	O
units.	O

Finance	O
reports	O
to	O
the	O
Board	O
on	O
a	O
monthly	O
basis.	O

Market	O
risk	O
Foreign	O
currency	O
risk	O
The	O
consolidated	O
entity	O
undertakes	O
certain	O
transactions	O
denominated	O
in	O
foreign	O
currency	O
and	O
is	O
exposed	O
to	O
foreign	O
currency	O
risk	O
through	O
foreign	O
exchange	O
rate	O
fluctuations.	O

Foreign	O
exchange	O
risk	O
arises	O
from	O
future	O
commercial	O
transactions	O
and	O
recognised	O
financial	O
assets	O
and	O
financial	O
liabilities	O
denominated	O
in	O
a	O
currency	O
that	O
is	O
not	O
the	O
entity's	O
functional	O
currency.	O

The	O
risk	O
is	O
measured	O
using	O
sensitivity	O
analysis	O
and	O
cash	O
flow	O
forecasting.	O

Foreign	O
exchange	O
risk	O
arises	O
from	O
future	O
commitments	O
,	O
assets	O
and	O
liabilities	O
that	O
are	O
denominated	O
in	O
a	O
currency	O
that	O
is	O
not	O
the	O
Company's	O

currency.	O

The	O
Company	O
operates	O
in	O
Australia	O
and	O
Chile	O
and	O
at	O
present	O
has	O
minimal	O
foreign	O

greater	O
exposure	O
in	O
the	O
future	O
as	O

for	O

in	O
US	O
Dollars.	O

Interest	O
rate	O
risk	O
Interest	O
rate	O
risk	O

the	O
risk	O
that	O

financial	O
position	O
will	O
be	O
adversely	O

by	O
movements	O
in	O
interest	O
rates.	O

Interest	O
rate	O
risk	O
on	O
short	O
term	O
deposits	O
is	O
not	O
considered	O
to	O
be	O
a	O
material	O
risk	O
due	O
to	O
the	O
short	O
term	O
nature	O
of	O
these	O
financial	O
instruments.	O

Credit	O
risk	O
Credit	O
risk	O
refers	O
to	O
the	O
risk	O
that	O
a	O
counterparty	O
will	O
default	O
on	O
its	O
contractual	O
obligations	O
resulting	O
in	O
financial	O
loss	O
to	O
the	O
consolidated	O
entity.	O

The	O
consolidated	O
entity	O
has	O
a	O
strict	O
code	O
of	O
credit	O
,	O
including	O
obtaining	O
agency	O
credit	O
information	O
,	O
confirming	O
references	O
and	O
setting	O
appropriate	O
credit	O
limits.	O

The	O
consolidated	O
entity	O
obtains	O
guarantees	O
where	O
appropriate	O
to	O
mitigate	O
credit	O
risk.	O

The	O
maximum	O
exposure	O
to	O
credit	O
risk	O
at	O
the	O
reporting	O
date	O
to	O
recognised	O
financial	O
assets	O
is	O
the	O
carrying	O
amount	O
,	O
net	O
of	O
any	O
provisions	O
for	O

of	O
those	O
assets	O
,	O

disclosed	O
in	O
the	O
statement	O
of	O
financial	O
position	O
and	O
notes	O
to	O
the	O
financial	O
statements.	O

The	O
consolidated	O
entity	O
does	O
not	O
hold	O
any	O
collateral.	O

Liquidity	O
risk	O
Vigilant	O
liquidity	O
risk	O
management	O
requires	O
the	O
consolidated	O
entity	O
to	O
maintain	O
sufficient	O
liquid	O
assets	O
(	O
mainly	O
cash	O
and	O
cash	O
equivalents	O
)	O
and	O
available	O
borrowing	O
facilities	O
to	O
be	O
able	O
to	O
pay	O
debts	O
as	O
and	O
when	O
they	O
become	O
due	O
and	O
payable.	O

The	O
consolidated	O
entity	O
manages	O
liquidity	O
risk	O
by	O
maintaining	O
adequate	O
cash	O
reserves	O
and	O
available	O
borrowing	O
facilities	O
by	O
continuously	O
monitoring	O
actual	O
and	O

cash	O
flows	O
and	O
matching	O
the	O
maturity	O
profiles	O
of	O
financial	O
assets	O
and	O
liabilities.	O

arrangements	O

in	O
place.	O

Fair	O
value	O
of	O
financial	O
instruments	O
Unless	O
otherwise	O
stated	O
,	O
the	O
carrying	O
amounts	O
of	O
financial	O
instruments	O
reflect	O
their	O
fair	O
value.	O

The	O
carrying	O
amounts	O
of	O
trade	O
receivables	O
and	O
trade	O
payables	O
are	O
assumed	O
to	O
approximate	O
their	O
fair	O
values	O
due	O
to	O
their	O
short-term	O
nature.	O

The	O
fair	O
value	O
of	O
financial	O
liabilities	O
is	O
estimated	O
by	O
discounting	O
the	O
remaining	O
contractual	O
maturities	O
at	O
the	O
current	O
market	O
interest	O
rate	O
that	O
is	O
available	O
for	O
similar	O
financial	O
instruments.	O

REPORT	O

to	O

FAIR	O
VALUE	O
MEASUREMENT	O
Fair	O
value	O
hierarchy	O
The	O
following	O
tables	O
detail	O
the	O
consolidated	O
entity's	O
assets	O
and	O
liabilities	O
,	O
measured	O
or	O
disclosed	O
at	O
fair	O
value	O
,	O
using	O
a	O
three	O
level	O
hierarchy	O
,	O
based	O
on	O
the	O
lowest	O
level	O
of	O
input	O
that	O
is	O
significant	O
to	O
the	O
entire	O
fair	O
value	O
measurement	O
,	O
being	O
:	O
Level	O
1	O
:	O
Quoted	O
prices	O
(	O
unadjusted	O
)	O
in	O
active	O
markets	O
for	O
identical	O
assets	O
or	O
liabilities	O
that	O
the	O
entity	O
can	O
access	O
at	O
the	O
measurement	O
date	O
Level	O
2	O
:	O
Inputs	O
other	O
than	O
quoted	O
prices	O
included	O
within	O
Level	O
1	O
that	O
are	O
observable	O
for	O
the	O
asset	O
or	O
liability	O
,	O
either	O
directly	O
or	O
indirectly	O
Level	O
3	O
:	O
Unobservable	O
inputs	O
for	O
the	O
asset	O
or	O
liability	O
Level	O
1	O
$	O
Level	O
2	O
$	O
Level	O
3	O
$	O
Total	O
$	O
Consolidated	O
-	O

2016	O
Assets	O
Ordinary	O
shares	O
188	O
,	O
617	O
-	O

-	O

188	O
,	O
617	O
Total	O
assets	O
188	O
,	O
617	O
-	O

-	O

188	O
,	O
617	O
Consolidated	O
-	O

2015	O
Assets	O
Ordinary	O
shares	O
270	O
,	O
680	O
-	O

-	O

270	O
,	O
680	O
Total	O
assets	O
270	O
,	O
680	O
-	O

-	O

270	O
,	O
680	O
Assets	O
and	O
liabilities	O
held	O
for	O
sale	O
are	O
measured	O
at	O
fair	O
value	O
on	O
a	O
non-recurring	O
basis.	O

There	O
were	O
no	O
transfers	O
between	O
levels	O
during	O
the	O
financial	O
year.	O

Accounting	O
policy	O
for	O
fair	O
value	O
measurement	O
When	O
an	O
asset	O
or	O
liability	O
,	O
financial	O
or	O
non-financial	O
,	O
is	O
measured	O
at	O
fair	O
value	O
for	O
recognition	O
or	O
disclosure	O
purposes	O
,	O
the	O
fair	O
value	O
is	O
based	O
on	O
the	O
price	O
that	O
would	O
be	O
received	O
to	O
sell	O
an	O
asset	O
or	O
paid	O
to	O
transfer	O
a	O
liability	O
in	O
an	O
orderly	O
transaction	O
between	O
market	O
participants	O
at	O
the	O
measurement	O
date	O
;	O
and	O
assumes	O
that	O
the	O
transaction	O
will	O
take	O
place	O
either	O
:	O
in	O
the	O
principal	O
market	O
;	O
or	O
in	O
the	O
absence	O
of	O
a	O
principal	O
market	O
,	O
in	O
the	O
most	O
advantageous	O
market.	O

Fair	O
value	O
is	O
measured	O
using	O
the	O
assumptions	O
that	O
market	O
participants	O
would	O
use	O
when	O
pricing	O
the	O
asset	O
or	O
liability	O
,	O
assuming	O
they	O
act	O
in	O
their	O
economic	O
best	O
interests.	O

Valuation	O
techniques	O
that	O
are	O
appropriate	O
in	O
the	O
circumstances	O
and	O
for	O
which	O
sufficient	O
data	O
are	O
available	O
to	O
measure	O
fair	O
value	O
,	O
are	O
used	O
,	O
maximising	O
the	O
use	O
of	O
relevant	O
observable	O
inputs	O
and	O
minimising	O
the	O
use	O
of	O
unobservable	O
inputs.	O

Assets	O
and	O
liabilities	O
measured	O
at	O
fair	O
value	O
are	O
classified	O
,	O
into	O
three	O
levels	O
,	O
using	O
a	O
fair	O
value	O
hierarchy	O
that	O
reflects	O
the	O
significance	O
of	O
the	O
inputs	O
used	O
in	O
making	O
the	O
measurements.	O

Classifications	O
are	O
reviewed	O
at	O
each	O
reporting	O
date	O
and	O
transfers	O
between	O
levels	O
are	O
determined	O
based	O
on	O
a	O
reassessment	O
of	O
the	O
lowest	O
level	O
of	O
input	O
that	O
is	O
significant	O
to	O
the	O
fair	O
value	O
measurement.	O

38	O
ALLIANCE	O
RESOURCES	O
LIMITEDNotes	O
to	O
the	O
financial	O
statements	O
30	O
June	O
2016	O
NOTE	O
26.	O

KEY	O
MANAGEMENT	O
PERSONNEL	O
DISCLOSURES	O
Directors	O
The	O
following	O
persons	O
were	O
directors	O
of	O
Alliance	O
Resources	O
Limited	O
during	O
the	O
financial	O
year	O
:	O
Chairman	O
-	O

Non-executive	O

SHARE-BASED	O
PAYMENTS	O

Option	O
Plan	O
(	O

)	O
has	O
been	O
established	O
by	O
the	O
consolidated	O
entity	O
and	O
approved	O
by	O
shareholders	O
at	O
a	O
general	O
meeting	O
,	O
whereby	O
the	O
consolidated	O
entity	O
may	O
,	O
at	O
the	O
discretion	O
of	O
the	O

grant	O
options	O
over	O
ordinary	O
shares	O
in	O
the	O
parent	O
entity	O
to	O
certain	O
key	O
management	O
personnel	O
of	O
the	O
consolidated	O
entity.	O

options	O
are	O
issued	O
for	O
nil	O
consideration	O
and	O
are	O
granted	O
in	O
accordance	O
with	O
performance	O
guidelines	O
established	O
by	O
the	O
Remuneration	O
Committees.	O

out	O
below	O
are	O

of	O
options	O

under	O

plan	O

ALLIANCE	O
RESOURCES	O
LIMITEDNotes	O
to	O
the	O
financial	O
statements	O
30	O
June	O
2016	O
Accounting	O
policy	O
for	O
share-based	O
payments	O
The	O
cost	O
of	O
cash-settled	O
transactions	O
is	O
initially	O
,	O
and	O
at	O
each	O
reporting	O
date	O
until	O
vested	O
,	O
determined	O
by	O
applying	O
either	O
the	O
Equity-settled	O
and	O
cash-settled	O
share-based	O
compensation	O
benefits	O
Binomial	O
or	O
Black-Scholes	O
option	O
pricing	O
model	O
,	O
taking	O
into	O
are	O
provided	O
to	O
employees.	O

consideration	O
the	O
terms	O
and	O

3	O

Lefroy	O
Exploration	O
Limited	O
(	O
ASX	O
:	O
LEX	O
)	O
(	O
“	O
Lefroy	O
”	O
or	O
“	O
the	O
Company	O
”	O
)	O
is	O
pleased	O
to	O
report	O
results	O
from	O
two	O
RC	O
drill	O
programs	O
evaluating	O
the	O
Burns	O
copper	O
(	O
Cu	O
)	O
gold	O
(	O
Au	O
)	O
prospect.	O

Burns	O
is	O
within	O
the	O
Eastern	O
Lefroy	O
tenement	O
package	O
,	O
which	O
is	O
part	O
of	O
the	O
wholly	O
owned	O
greater	O
Lefroy	O
Gold	O
Project	O
(	O
LGP	O
)	O
located	O
50km	O
southeast	O
of	O
Kalgoorlie	O
(	O
Figure	O
1	O
)	O
.	O

The	O
Burns	O
copper	O
gold	O
prospect	O
is	O
situated	O
on	O
the	O
eastern	O
margin	O
of	O
a	O
large	O
interpreted	O
felsic	O
intrusion	O
,	O
termed	O
the	O
Burns	O
Intrusion.	O

The	O
intrusion	O
does	O
not	O
outcrop	O
but	O
features	O
a	O
distinctive	O
annular	O
aeromagnetic	O
and	O
gravity	O
geophysical	O
signature	O
(	O
Figure	O
2	O
)	O
.	O

The	O
Company	O
has	O
not	O
yet	O
established	O
the	O
association	O
between	O
the	O
larger	O
Burns	O
intrusion	O
and	O
the	O
diorite	O
porphyry	O
intrusions	O
intersected	O
at	O
Burns	O
but	O
consider	O
there	O
is	O
a	O
genetic	O
relationship	O
between	O
them.	O

Broad	O
high-grade	O
gold	O
mineralisation	O
is	O
hosted	O
within	O
a	O
newly	O
discovered	O
hematite-pyrite-	O
chalcopyrite-magnetite	O
altered	O
diorite	O
porphyry	O
(	O
refer	O
LEX	O
ASX	O
release	O
23	O
February	O
2021	O
)	O
that	O
intrudes	O
high	O
Mg	O
basalt	O
at	O
Burns.	O

This	O
porphyry	O
,	O
termed	O
the	O
Eastern	O
Porphyry	O
,	O
is	O
open	O
to	O
the	O
north	O
and	O
south.	O

The	O
eastern	O
extent	O
of	O
the	O
Eastern	O
Porphyry	O
is	O
now	O
defined	O
,	O
on	O
multiple	O
drill	O
sections	O
,	O
by	O
foliated	O
basalt	O
(	O
footwall	O
basalt	O
)	O
.	O

The	O
copper	O
and	O
gold	O
mineralisation	O
hosted	O
by	O
both	O
the	O
diorite	O
porphyry	O
,	O
basalt	O
and	O
massive	O
magnetite	O
veins	O
is	O
considered	O
by	O
the	O
Company	O
to	O
be	O
a	O
new	O
and	O
unique	O
style	O
of	O
Au-Cu-Ag	O
mineralisation	O
in	O
the	O
area	O
,	O
a	O
land	O
position	O
dominated	O
by	O
Lefroy	O
(	O
Figure	O
1	O
)	O
.	O

The	O
existence	O
of	O
additional	O
mineralisation	O
further	O
east	O
and	O
north	O
under	O
Lake	O
Randall	O
is	O
not	O
discounted	O
by	O
the	O
current	O
drilling	O
campaign	O
and	O
will	O
be	O
the	O
subject	O
of	O
more	O

and	O
drilling	O
that	O
is	O
about	O
to	O

Figure	O
1	O
Lefroy	O
Gold	O
Project	O
,	O

Eastern	O
and	O

Lefroy	O
,	O

Burns	O
prospect	O

Strike.	O

Refer	O
to	O
Figure	O
3	O
for	O
Burns	O
drill	O
hole	O
plan.	O

2	O
|	O
P	O
age	O
ASX	O
Announcement	O
3	O
November	O
2021	O
RC	O
Drill	O
programs-background	O
Two	O
RC	O
drilling	O
campaigns	O
were	O
completed	O
at	O
Burns	O
during	O
the	O
July	O
to	O
October	O
2021	O
period.	O

The	O
July	O
program	O
evaluated	O
extensions	O
immediately	O
peripheral	O
to	O
the	O
established	O
Burns	O
prospect	O
while	O
in	O
October	O
a	O
17	O
hole	O
step	O
out	O
program	O
was	O
completed	O
evaluating	O
multiple	O
magnetic	O
anomalies	O
along	O
a	O
3000m	O
corridor	O
north	O
of	O
Burns	O
(	O
refer	O
Figure	O
2	O
)	O
.	O

Figure	O
2	O
Combined	O
satellite	O
image	O
with	O
transparent	O
TMI	O
RTP	O
aeromagnetic	O
image	O
highlighting	O
the	O
discrete	O

due	O
to	O
high	O
flows	O
of	O
ground	O

of	O

3	O

2021	O

1	O

About	O
Lefroy	O
Exploration	O
Limited	O
and	O

for	O
high	O
value	O
gold	O
deposits	O
in	O
the	O
Yilgarn	O
Block	O
of	O
Western	O
Australia.	O

Key	O
projects	O
include	O
the	O
Lefroy	O
Gold	O
Project	O
to	O
the	O
southeast	O
of	O
Kalgoorlie	O
and	O
the	O
Lake	O
Johnston	O
Project	O
120km	O
to	O
the	O
west	O
of	O
Norseman.	O

100%	O
owned	O
Lefroy	O
Gold	O
Project	O
contains	O
mainly	O

tenure	O
and	O
covers	O
637.6km2	O
in	O
the	O
heart	O
of	O
the	O
world	O
class	O
gold	O
production	O
area	O
between	O
Kalgoorlie	O
and	O
Norseman.	O

Project	O
is	O
near	O
Gold	O

’	O

Ives	O
gold	O
camp	O
,	O
which	O
contains	O
the	O

gold	O

in	O

Lefroy	O
and	O
is	O
also	O
immediately	O
south	O
of	O
Silver	O
Lake	O
Resources	O
’	O
(	O
ASX	O
:	O
SLR	O
)	O
Daisy	O
Milano	O
gold	O
mining	O
operation.	O

is	O

on	O

2018.	O

for	O

Omnia	O

on	O
the	O

Maguires	O

to	O

and	O

Prospect	O
North	O
and	O

.	O

shear-hosted	O

was	O
originally	O

by	O
BHP	O
in	O
the	O
1980	O
’	O

and	O

the	O

and	O
limited	O
work	O
has	O
been	O

such	O
as	O

@	B-E
18.6g/t	B-P

at	O

a	O

of	O
4m	O
@19.2g/t.	B-P

This	O

reports	O
the	O
results	O
from	O
these	O
45	O
RC	O
drill	O
holes	O
for	O
an	O

4	O

300m	O
of	O
drilling.	O

of	O
the	O

in	O

2	O
and	O
4.	O

The	O
bulk	O
of	O
previous	O
drilling	O
at	O
Maguires	O
was	O
focused	O
at	O
the	O
Old	O
Prospect	O
in	O
the	O
late	O
1980	O
’	O

,	O
with	O
the	O
new	O

to	O

the	O
previous	O
results	O
and	O
test	O
for	O
extensions	O
both	O
along	O
strike	O
and	O

The	O
new	O
drilling	O
has	O
expanded	O
the	O
size	O
and	O
confirmed	O
the	O
typical	O
grades	O
of	O
the	O
Old	O
Prospect	O
North	O
and	O

that	O
the	O
mineralisation	O
remains	O
open	O
in	O
all	O
directions	O
(	O
Figure	O
3	O
)	O
.	O

The	O
drilling	O
intersected	O
parallel	O
zones	O
of	O
quartz	O
carbonate	O
veining	O
hosted	O
in	O
highly	O
sheared	O
mafic	O
,	O
ultramafic	O
and	O
sedimentary	O
rocks.	O

The	O
depth	O
to	O
fresh	O
rock	O
was	O
variable	O
,	O
ranging	O
from	O
60-90m.	O

Pyrite	O
and	O
arsenopyrite	O
were	O
identified	O
in	O
primary	O
mineralization	O
within	O
fresh	O
rock.	O

Old	O
Prospect	O
South	O
(	O
Figures	O
3	O
and	O
6	O
)	O
has	O
a	O
strike	O
length	O
of	O
50-100m	O

North	O
(	O

3	O
and	O
5	O
)	O
is	O
100-150m	O
long	O
with	O
an	O
estimated	O

thickness	O
averaging	O
2-3m.	O

The	O
gold	O
mineralisation	O
dips	O
steeply	O
west	O
and	O
high	O
grades	O
shoots	O
are	O
interpreted	O
to	O
plunge	O
steeply	O
north.	O

In	O

areas	O
the	O

is	O
open	O
in	O
all	O
directions.	O

intercept	O
of	O

@	B-E

(	B-H
hole	I-H
21MRR039	I-H
–	O

Background	O

OZZ	O
Resources	O

the	O

program	O

Murchison	O

of	O
Meekatharra	O

has	O

such	O
as	O
6m	O
at	O
18.6g/t	B-P
Au	B-M
,	O
7m	B-D
at	B-E
8.7g/t	B-P
and	B-E
6m	B-D
at	B-E

has	O

estimate	O
in	O
the	O
near	O
term.	O

Rabbit	O
Bore	O
,	O
located	O
NW	O
of	O
Cue	O
,	O
hosts	O
a	O
5km	O
strike	O
length	O
of	O
prospective	O
shear	O
zones	O
largely	O
under	O
cover	O
,	O
including	O
several	O
historic	O
gold	O
working	O
which	O
have	O
returned	O
rock	O
chip	O
assays	O
of	O
up	O
to	O
4.2g/t	B-P
gold.	O

The	O
detailed	O
magnetic	O
data	O
obtained	O
from	O
the	O
recent	O
aeromagnetic	O
survey	O
will	O
be	O
utilised	O
,	O
together	O
with	O
soil	O
sampling	O
programs	O
,	O
to	O
generate	O
targets	O
for	O
initial	O
drilling.	O

Previous	O
soil	O
sampling	O
has	O
also	O
returned	O
anomalous	O
copper	O
,	O
nickel	O
and	O
cobalt	O
results.	O

Peterwangy	O
,	O
which	O
was	O
the	O
site	O
of	O
WA	O
’	O
s	O
first	O
gold	O
rush	O
in	O
1868	O
,	O
hosts	O
historic	O
workings	O
within	O
a	O
3km	O
long	O
greenstone	O
belt	O
straddling	O
the	O
craton-scale	O
Koolanooka	O
Fault.	O

No	O
drilling	O
has	O
ever	O
been	O
undertaken	O
at	O
the	O
project	O
,	O
and	O
OZZ	O
will	O
utilise	O
a	O
combination	O
of	O
the	O
recent	O
aeromagnetic	O
survey	O
data	O
and	O
ground-based	O
soil	O
sampling	O
to	O
generate	O
drill	O
targets.	O

The	O
more	O
advanced	O
Mt	O
Davis	O
project	O
,	O
located	O
20km	O
north	O
of	O
Leonora	O
and	O
4km	O
southeast	O
of	O
Red	O
5	O
Limited	O
’	O
s	O
4.1Moz	O
King	O
of	O
the	O
Hills	O
gold	O
project	O
(	O
currently	O
being	O
developed	O
as	O
a	O
major	O
new	O
standalone	O
open	O
pit	O
and	O
underground	O
gold	O
mine	O
)	O
,	O
will	O
become	O
a	O
focus	O
once	O
heritage	O
and	O
access	O
approvals	O
are	O
finalised.	O

The	O
project	O
contains	O
mineralisation	O
at	O
the	O
Trig	O
deposit	O
,	O
which	O
is	O
hosted	O
by	O
the	O
same	O
geological	O
structures	O
associated	O
with	O
major	O
mineralisation	O
around	O
Leonora	O
,	O
including	O
the	O
world-	O
class	O
+8Moz	O
Sons	O
of	O
Gwalia	O
mine.	O

A	O
separate	O
aeromagnetic	O
(	O
drone	O
)	O
survey	O
is	O
planned	O
for	O
the	O
Wardarbie	O
South	O
Project	O
,	O
west	O
of	O
Meekatharra.	O

This	O
data	O
will	O
be	O
used	O
in	O
conjunction	O
with	O
soil	O
sampling	O
to	O
define	O
drill	O
targets	O
within	O
the	O
three	O
kilometres	O
of	O
prospective	O
lithologies.	O

APPENDIX	O
2	O
JORC	O
Code	O
,	O
2012	O
Edition	O

Table	O
1	O
Section	O
1	O
Sampling	O
Techniques	O
and	O
Data	O
Criteria	O
Commentary	O
Sampling	O
techniques	O
•	O

The	O
sampling	O
has	O
been	O
carried	O
out	O
using	O
Reverse	O
Circulation	O
drilling	O
(	O
RC	O
)	O
.	O

A	O
total	O
of	O
45	O
holes	O
(	O
21MRRC001-045	O
)	O
were	O
drilled	O
in	O
the	O
reported	O
program	O
for	O
a	O
total	O
of	O
4	O
,	O
300m	O
at	O
depths	O
ranging	O
from	O
54	O
to	O
200m	O
•	O

Ozz	O
Resources	O
LTD	O
(	O
OZZ	O
)	O
sampling	O
is	O
conducted	O
using	O
standard	O
industry	O
practices	O
including	O
the	O
use	O
of	O
duplicates	O
,	O
blanks	O
and	O
standards	O
at	O
regular	O
intervals.	O

The	O
performance	O
of	O
QAQC	O
controls	O
is	O
monitored	O
on	O
a	O
batch-by-batch	O
basis.	O

•	O

All	O
sampling	O
and	O
data	O
collection	O
is	O
supervised	O
by	O
a	O
qualified	O
geologist.	O

•	O

RC	O
holes	O
were	O
drilled	O
with	O
a	O
5.25-inch	O
face-sampling	O
bit	O
,	O
with	O
1m	O
samples	O
collected	O
through	O
a	O
cyclone	O
and	O
cone	O
splitter	O
,	O
to	O
result	O
in	O
a	O
2-3kg	O
and	O
a	O
bulk	O
25-40kg	O
sample	O
per	O
metre.	O

The	O
2-3	O
kg	O
samples	O
were	O
dispatched	O
to	O
SGS	O
laboratories	O
in	O
Perth.	O

These	O
samples	O
were	O
sorted	O
and	O
dried	O
by	O
the	O
assay	O
laboratory	O
,	O
pulverised	O
to	O
form	O
a	O
50gm	O
charge	O
for	O
Fire	O
Assay/AAS.	O

Drilling	O
techniques	O
•	O

RC	O
drilling	O
was	O
completed	O
by	O
Three	O
Rivers	O
Drilling	O
Pty	O
Ltd	O
,	O
using	O
a	O
Schramm	O
64	O
track	O
mounted	O
rig	O
with	O
Sullair	O
350/900	O
cfm	O
on-board	O
compressor	O
,	O
augmented	O
with	O
a	O
2000cfm	O
auxiliary	O
Air	O
Truck	O
mounted	O
with	O
an	O
Ingersoll	O
Rand	O
350/1070	O
cfm	O
compressor	O
coupled	O
to	O
a	O
2010	O
Air	O
Research	O
Booster	O
compressor	O
capable	O
of	O
900	O
psi.	O

RC	O
holes	O
were	O
collared	O
with	O
a	O
5	O
5/8-inch	O
diameter	O
face	O
sampling	O
bit	O
and	O
drilled	O
through	O
to	O
depth	O
with	O
a	O
5	O
1/4-inch	O
diameter	O
face	O
sampling	O
bit.	O

Drill	O
sample	O
recovery	O
•	O

Sample	O
weights	O
,	O
dryness	O
and	O
recoveries	O
are	O
observed	O
and	O
recorded	O
with	O
sample	O
data	O
by	O
the	O
supervising	O
geologists.	O

•	O

Samples	O
were	O
weighed	O
at	O
the	O
laboratory	O
to	O
allow	O
comparative	O
analysis	O
between	O
submitted	O
sample	O
weight	O
and	O
grade.	O

•	O

OZZ	O
contracted	O
drillers	O
use	O
industry	O
appropriate	O
methods	O
to	O
maximise	O
sample	O
recovery	O
and	O
minimise	O
downhole	O
contamination.	O

•	O

No	O
significant	O
sample	O
grade	O
bias	O
associated	O
with	O
sample	O
recovery	O
has	O
been	O
noted	O
in	O
previous	O
drilling	O
or	O
in	O
drilling	O
conducted	O
by	O
OZZ.	O

Logging	O
•	O

All	O
holes	O
were	O
logged	O
in	O
full	O
by	O
qualified	O
OZZ	O
staff	O
geologists	O
in	O
line	O
with	O
industry	O
standards	O
and	O
the	O
OZZ	O
logging	O
scheme.	O

•	O

Logging	O
of	O
RC	O
chips	O
records	O
including	O
lithology	O
,	O
mineralogy	O
,	O
mineralisation	O
,	O
weathering	O
,	O
colour	O
and	O
other	O
features	O
of	O
the	O
samples.	O

All	O
samples	O
are	O
wet-sieved	O
and	O
stored	O
in	O
chip	O
trays.	O

These	O
trays	O
were	O
stored	O
off	O
site	O
for	O
future	O
reference.	O

Sub-sampling	O
techniques	O
and	O
sample	O
•	O

Sample	O
preparation	O
and	O
Au	O
analysis	O
is	O
undertaken	O
by	O
a	O
registered	O
laboratory	O
(	O
SGS	O
Laboratories	O
)	O
.	O

preparation	O
Sample	O
preparation	O
by	O
dry	O
pulverisation	O
to	O
85%	O
passing	O
75	O
microns	O
is	O
monitored	O
with	O
pass	O
rates	O
recorded	O
at	O
regular	O
intervals	O
as	O
part	O
of	O
the	O
labs	O
reporting	O
process.	O

Pass	O
rates	O
are	O
monitored	O
on	O
a	O
batch-by-batch	O
basis	O
as	O
part	O
of	O
QAQC	O
conventions.	O

•	O

Sample	O
weights	O
,	O
dryness	O
and	O
recoveries	O
are	O
observed	O
and	O
recorded	O
with	O
sample	O
data	O
by	O
the	O
onsite	O
supervising	O
geologists.	O

•	O

Duplicate	O
samples	O
were	O
taken	O
at	O
a	O
frequency	O
of	O
1	O
:	O
40	O
samples.	O

•	O

The	O
sample	O
sizes	O
were	O
constantly	O
monitored	O
and	O
those	O
collected	O
are	O
considered	O
appropriate	O
for	O
the	O
material	O
being	O
sampled.	O

Quality	O
of	O
assay	O
data	O
and	O
laboratory	O
tests	O
•	O

Au	O
analysis	O
was	O
undertaken	O
by	O
SGS	O
Laboratories	O
(	O
a	O
registered	O
laboratory	O
)	O
,	O
with	O
50g	O
fire	O
assay	O
and	O
MP-AES	O
finish.	O

This	O
method	O
has	O
a	O
detection	O
limit	O
of	O
0.01ppm.	O

•	O

Internal	O
certified	O
laboratory	O
QAQC	O
is	O
undertaken	O
as	O
is	O
industry	O
standard	O
;	O
including	O
check	O
samples	O
,	O
repeats	O
,	O
blanks	O
,	O
and	O
internal	O
standards.	O

•	O

SGS	O
laboratories	O
refire	O
anomalous	O
samples	O
and	O
include	O
their	O
own	O
check	O
samples	O
within	O
each	O
submission	O
(	O
as	O
is	O
industry	O
standard	O
)	O
;	O
including	O
repeats	O
,	O
blanks	O
,	O
and	O
internal	O
standards.	O

•	O

Detection	O
limits	O
and	O
techniques	O
are	O
appropriate	O
for	O
the	O
detection	O
of	O
Au	O
mineralisation	O
in	O
the	O
materials	O
analysed.	O

•	O

Sampling	O
included	O
field	O
duplicates	O
,	O
blind	O
reference	O
standards	O
,	O
field	O
blanks	O
and	O
inter-laboratory	O
checks	O
to	O
confirm	O
assay	O
precision	O
and	O
accuracy	O
with	O
sufficient	O
confidence	O
for	O
the	O
current	O
results	O
,	O
at	O
a	O
frequency	O
of	O
5%	O
(	O
ie	O
1	O
in	O
20	O
)	O
.	O

Verification	O
of	O
sampling	O
and	O
assaying	O
•	O

Assay	O
data	O
was	O
reviewed	O
by	O
the	O
supervising	O
geologist	O
before	O
importing	O
into	O
the	O
database	O
and	O
significant	O
intercepts	O
visually	O
reviewed	O
relative	O
to	O
adjacent	O
data.	O

•	O

Primary	O
data	O
is	O
collated	O
using	O
a	O
standard	O
set	O
of	O
templates.	O

Geological	O
for	O
all	O
sampling	O
data	O
with	O
lithology	O
,	O
colour	O
,	O
weathering	O
,	O
structure	O
,	O
alteration	O
,	O
veining	O
,	O
and	O
mineralisation	O
recorded	O
for	O
each	O
interval.	O

Data	O
is	O
verified	O
before	O
loading	O
into	O
a	O
database.	O

Geological	O
logging	O
of	O
all	O
samples	O
/	O
intervals	O
is	O
undertaken	O
in	O
the	O
field	O
by	O
a	O
qualified	O
and	O
experienced	O
supervising	O
geologist.	O

•	O

Assay	O
data	O
is	O
reported	O
without	O
adjustments	O
or	O
calibrations.	O

For	O
all	O
intercepts	O
,	O
the	O
first	O
received	O
assay	O
result	O
is	O
always	O
reported.	O

•	O

Laboratory	O
assay	O
files	O
are	O
merged	O
directly	O
into	O
the	O
database.	O

The	O
project	O
geologists	O
/	O
contracted	O
database	O
administrators	O
routinely	O
validate	O
data	O
when	O
loading	O
into	O
the	O
database.	O

Location	O
of	O
data	O
points	O
•	O

All	O
maps	O
and	O
locations	O
are	O
presented	O
and	O
referenced	O
using	O
MGA	O
UTM	O
grid	O
(	O
GDA94	O
Z50	O
)	O
.	O

•	O

Drill	O
collars	O
are	O
initially	O
surveyed	O
by	O
hand-held	O
GPS	O
with	O
a	O
precision	O
of	O
+/-	O
5.0m	O
,	O
utilizing	O
GDA94	O
,	O
Zone	O
50.	O

Final	O
drillhole	O
collars	O
are	O
all	O
surveyed	O
by	O
DGPS	O
to	O
a	O
precision	O
of	O
0.05m.	O

•	O

A	O
DTM	O
was	O
created	O
incorporating	O
all	O
available	O
and	O
viable	O
DGPS	O
points	O
–	O

including	O
tenement	O
walk-	O
overs.	O

•	O

In	O
some	O
cases	O
,	O
surface	O
heights	O
were	O
validated	O
against	O
a	O
surface	O
DTM	O
generated	O
from	O
5m	O
by	O
40m	O
spaced	O
spot	O
heights	O
taken	O
during	O
airborne	O
magnetic	O
surveys.	O

Data	O
spacing	O
and	O
distribution	O
•	O

The	O
drill	O
spacing	O
at	O
each	O
prospect	O
was	O
variable	O
,	O
based	O
on	O
previous	O
drilling	O
and	O
the	O
stage	O
of	O
each	O
prospect.	O

Drillhole	O
collar	O
coordinates	O
are	O
as	O
per	O
tabulated	O
in	O
this	O
report.	O

•	O

The	O
drilling	O
at	O
Maguires	O
/	O
Old	O
Prospect	O
has	O
generated	O
intercepts	O
on	O
a	O
25m-30m	O
spacing	O
in	O
some	O
places	O
giving	O
confidence	O
in	O
the	O
geological	O
and	O
grade	O
continuity	O
,	O
potentially	O
suitable	O
for	O
Mineral	O
Resource	O
and	O
Ore	O
Reserve	O
estimation.	O

•	O

Further	O
drilling	O
is	O
required	O
in	O
some	O
areas	O
to	O
test	O
for	O
extensions	O
to	O
the	O
mineralisation	O
•	O

No	O
resource	O
estimates	O
have	O
been	O
reported.	O

Orientation	O
of	O
data	O
in	O
relation	O
to	O
•	O

Historical	O
diamond	O
programs	O
undertaken	O
by	O
BHP	O
(	O
1987-1989	O
)	O
recorded	O
major	O
penetrative	O
foliation	O
geological	O
structure	O
dipping	O
~70o	O
west	O
with	O
carbonate-quartz	O
stockwork	O
dipping	O
35o	O
west.	O

Surface	O
rodding	O
through	O
field	O
mapping	O
returned	O
dip/strikes	O
of	O
~90o/280-300o.	O

The	O
historically	O
recorded	O
mineral	O
elongation	O
lineation	O
plunges	O
80o.	O

•	O

The	O
drill	O
orientation	O
is	O
approximately	O
perpendicular	O
to	O
the	O
main	O
historical	O
mineralised	O
trend	O
supported	O
by	O
public	O
record	O
aeromagnetics	O
and	O
previous	O
drill	O
hole	O
information.	O

•	O

For	O
all	O
prospects	O
,	O
the	O
true	O
width	O
of	O
mineralisation	O
is	O
not	O
yet	O
known.	O

Sample	O
security	O
•	O

Chain	O
of	O
custody	O
is	O
managed	O
by	O
OZZ	O
staff	O
or	O
consultants.	O

•	O

Samples	O
were	O
submitted	O
in	O
numbered	O
polyweave	O
bags	O
(	O
five	O
calico	O
bags	O
per	O
polyweave	O
bag	O
)	O
,	O
sealed	O
and	O
transported	O
to	O
SGS	O
in	O
Perth	O
for	O
assaying.	O

•	O

Samples	O
were	O
transported	O
by	O
a	O
commercial	O
courier	O
direct	O
from	O
the	O
Old	O
Prospect	O
drill	O
site	O
to	O
the	O
Laboratory.	O

When	O
samples	O
arrived	O
at	O
the	O
laboratory	O
,	O
all	O
submitted	O
materials	O
are	O
securely	O
stored	O
prior	O
to	O
being	O
processed	O
and	O
tracked	O
through	O
sample	O
preparation	O
and	O
analysis.	O

Audits	O
or	O
reviews	O
•	O

No	O
formal	O
audits	O
have	O
been	O
completed	O
on	O
sampling	O
techniques	O
and	O
data	O
due	O
to	O
the	O
early-stage	O
nature	O
of	O
the	O
drilling.	O

•	O

QA/QC	O
data	O
is	O
regularly	O
reviewed	O
by	O
OZZ	O
,	O
and	O
results	O
provide	O
confidence	O
in	O
the	O
assay	O
data	O
and	O
laboratory	O
performance.	O

The	O
laboratory	O
is	O
advised	O
of	O
any	O
discrepancies	O
and	O
samples	O
are	O
re-assayed.	O

The	O
Company	O
also	O
intends	O
to	O
submit	O
samples	O
to	O
secondary	O
laboratories	O
as	O
part	O
of	O
the	O
audit	O

•	O

Maguires	O
+	O
Old	O
Prospect	O
-	O

All	O

have	O
