|	O
11	O
JORC	O
Code	O
,	O
2012	O
Edition	O
Table	O
1	O
–	O

Section	O
1	O
Sampling	O
Techniques	O
and	O
Data	O
Item	O
Comments	O
Sampling	O
•	O

Samples	O
were	O
collected	O
by	O
RC	O
drilling.	O

techniques	O
•	O

The	O
rig-mounted	O
in-line	O
cyclone	O
and	O
cone	O
splitter	O
was	O
used	O
to	O
produce	O
a	O
bulk	O
sample	O
and	O
an	O
approximately	O
3kg	O
sample	O
for	O
each	O
1m	O
interval.	O

•	O

All	O
RC	O
samples	O
were	O
submitted	O
to	O
Intertek	O
Minerals	O
Limited	O
(	O
“	O
Intertek	O
”	O
)	O
in	O
Maddington	O
for	O
fire	O
assay.	O

•	O

Samples	O
either	O
comprised	O
a	O
4m	O
composite	O
,	O
collected	O
from	O
the	O
bulk	O
1m	O
samples	O
using	O
a	O
split	O
PVC	O
scoop	O
and	O
then	O
submitted	O
Intertek	O
Genalyis	O
(	O
“	O
Intertek	O
”	O
)	O
in	O
Maddington	O
for	O
fire	O
assay.	O

The	O
3kg	O
1m	O
splits	O
were	O
submitted	O
if	O
the	O
composite	O
sample	O
assay	O
values	O
are	O
equal	O
to	O
or	O
greater	O
than	O
0.2	O
g/t	O
Au.	O

•	O

Alternatively	O
,	O
the	O
3kg	O
1m	O
splits	O
produced	O
from	O
the	O
cone	O
splitter	O
were	O
sent	O
directly	O
to	O
the	O
laboratory	O
bypassing	O
the	O
collection	O
of	O
4m	O
composite	O
samples.	O

Drilling	O
•	O

The	O
RC	O
drilling	O
program	O
used	O
a	O
KWL	O
350	O
drill	O
rig	O
with	O
an	O
onboard	O
1100cfm/350psi	O
compressor	O
and	O
a	O
truck	O
techniques	O
mounted	O
1000cfm	O
auxiliary	O
and	O
1000psi	O
booster.	O

•	O

The	O
face	O
sampling	O
hammer	O
had	O
a	O
nominal	O
140mm	O
hole.	O

•	O

All	O
drill	O
holes	O
were	O
surveyed	O
down	O
hole	O
using	O
a	O
north	O
seeking	O
Gyro	O
at	O
30m	O
intervals.	O

Drill	O
sample	O
•	O

Recovery	O
was	O
estimated	O
for	O
each	O
1m	O
interval	O
as	O
a	O
percentage	O
and	O
recorded	O
on	O
field	O
sheets	O
prior	O
to	O
entry	O
into	O
the	O
recovery	O
database.	O

•	O

Drill	O
rig	O
of	O
sufficient	O
capacity	O
to	O
produce	O
dry	O
,	O
high	O
recovery	O
samples	O
,	O
and	O
face	O
sampling	O
hammer/bit	O
are	O
used	O
to	O
maximise	O
recovery.	O

•	O

The	O
1m	O
RC	O
samples	O
represent	O
fine	O
and	O
coarse	O
material.	O

•	O

RC	O
samples	O
generally	O
had	O
good	O
recovery	O
and	O
there	O
were	O
no	O
reported	O
issues.	O

•	O

There	O
does	O
not	O
appear	O
to	O
be	O
a	O
relationship	O
with	O
sample	O
recovery	O
and	O
grade	O
and	O
there	O
is	O
no	O
indication	O
of	O
sample	O
bias.	O

Logging	O
•	O

RC	O
drill	O
chips	O
were	O
sieved	O
from	O
each	O
1m	O
bulk	O
sample	O
and	O
geologically	O
logged.	O

•	O

Washed	O
drill	O
chips	O
from	O
each	O
1m	O
sample	O
were	O
stored	O
in	O
chip	O
trays.	O

•	O

Geological	O
logging	O
of	O
drillhole	O
intervals	O
was	O
carried	O
out	O
with	O
sufficient	O
detail	O
to	O
meet	O
the	O
requirements	O
of	O
resource	O
estimation.	O

Subsampling	O
•	O

1m	O
RC	O
samples	O
were	O
transported	O
to	O
Intertek	O
located	O
in	O
Maddington	O
,	O
Western	O
Australia	O
,	O
who	O
were	O
responsible	O
techniques	O
for	O
sample	O
preparation	O
and	O
assaying	O
for	O
all	O
RC	O
drill	O
hole	O
samples	O
and	O
associated	O
check	O
assays.	O

and	O
sample	O
•	O

1m	O
RC	O
samples	O
were	O
dried	O
,	O
pulverized	O
and	O
analysed	O
using	O
50g	O
fire	O
assay	O
with	O
AAS	O
finish.	O

preparation	O
•	O

Field	O
duplicates	O
comprised	O
an	O
approximately	O
3kg	O
sample	O
and	O
were	O
collected	O
either	O
by	O
spear	O
(	O
for	O
submission	O
of	O
4m	O
composite	O
samples	O
)	O
or	O
using	O
the	O
rig-mounted	O
in-line	O
cyclone	O
and	O
cone	O
splitter	O
(	O
for	O
submission	O
of	O
direct	O
1m	O
samples	O
)	O
.	O

•	O

The	O
rig	O
mounted	O
cone	O
splitter	O
was	O
routinely	O
cleaned	O
at	O
the	O
end	O
of	O
each	O
rod.	O

•	O

Sample	O
sizes	O
are	O
considered	O
to	O
be	O
appropriate.	O

Quality	O
of	O
assay	O
•	O

1m	O
RC	O
samples	O
were	O
submitted	O
to	O
the	O
laboratory	O
with	O
field	O
duplicates	O
,	O
certified	O
standards	O
and	O
field	O
blank	O
samples	O
data	O
and	O
inserted	O
at	O
a	O
ratio	O
of	O
1	O
:	O
20.	O

laboratory	O
tests	O
•	O

Laboratory	O
Certified	O
Reference	O
Materials	O
and/or	O
in-house	O
controls	O
,	O
blanks	O
,	O
splits	O
and	O
replicates	O
are	O
analysed	O
with	O
each	O
batch	O
of	O
samples	O
by	O
the	O
laboratory.	O

These	O
quality	O
control	O
results	O
are	O
reported	O
along	O
with	O
the	O
sample	O
values	O
in	O
the	O
final	O
report.	O

Selected	O
samples	O
are	O
also	O
re-analysed	O
to	O
confirm	O
anomalous	O
results.	O

•	O

Laboratory	O
and	O
field	O
QA/QC	O
results	O
were	O
reviewed	O
by	O
Alto	O
personnel.	O

of	O
•	O

company	O
personnel.	O

sampling	O

•	O

•	O

Henry	O

other	O

•	O

Troy	O

Lord	O
Henry	O

000	O
ounces	O
of	O

Geology	O
Lord	O
Henry	O
•	O

The	O
Lord	O
Henry	O
deposit	O
occurs	O
at	O
the	O
southern	O
end	O
of	O
the	O
north-south	O
trending	O
Trafalgar	O
shear	O
zone.	O

•	O

The	O
Lord	O
Henry	O
deposit	O
is	O
contained	O
within	O
a	O
granodiorite	O
body	O
bounded	O
to	O
the	O
south	O
and	O
west	O
by	O
a	O
sheared	O
ultramafic	O
contact	O
,	O
forming	O
part	O
of	O
the	O
Trafalgar	O
shear.	O

•	O

Mineralisation	O
comprises	O
a	O
series	O
of	O
stacked	O
,	O
-20	O
°	O

to	O
-30	O
°	O

north	O
dipping	O
lodes	O
characterised	O
by	O
quartz-	O
sericite-chlorite-pyrite	O
alteration	O
within	O
the	O
granodiorite	O
body.	O

•	O

A	O
thin	O
veneer	O
of	O
surficial	O
cover	O
exists	O
and	O
this	O
can	O
also	O
be	O
mineralised	O
where	O
the	O
lodes	O
project	O
to	O
surface.	O

•	O

The	O
overall	O
trend	O
of	O
the	O
mineralised	O
zones	O
is	O
northeast	O
with	O
a	O
defined	O
length	O
of	O
400m.	O

High-grade	O
gold	O
intersections	O
are	O
associated	O
with	O
sulphide	O
rich	O
quartz	O
veins	O
and	O
stringers.	O

•	O

interpreted	O
mineralisation	O
domains	O
for	O
Lord	O
Henry	O
are	O
based	O
on	O
a	O
nominal	O
0.2	O
g/t	O
Au	O
to	O
0.3	O
g/t	O
Au	O
cutoff	O
which	O
appears	O
to	O

break	O
in	O
the	O
grade	O
distribution.	O

Mining	O

that	O

to	O

A$6.1	O

at	O
A$0.065	O
per	O
ordinary	O

million	O

A$0.065	O
per	O

Environmental	O
regulation	O

s	O

was	O

during	O
the	O
financial	O
year	O
and	O

Board	O
is	O
not	O

of	O
any	O

of	O

requirements	O
as	O
they	O

to	O
the	O
Group.	O

A.	O

Remuneration	O
Philosophy	O
The	O
remuneration	O
report	O
details	O
the	O
remuneration	O
arrangements	O
for	O
key	O
management	O
personnel	O
(	O
KMP	O
)	O
who	O
are	O
defined	O
as	O
those	O
having	O
authority	O
and	O
responsibility	O
for	O
planning	O
,	O
directing	O
and	O
controlling	O
the	O
major	O
activities	O
of	O
the	O
Company	O
,	O
directly	O
or	O
indirectly	O
,	O
including	O
any	O
director	O
(	O
whether	O
executive	O
or	O
otherwise	O
)	O
.	O

Key	O
management	O
personnel	O
of	O
the	O
Company	O
comprise	O
the	O
Board	O
of	O
Directors	O
only.	O

The	O
performance	O
of	O
the	O
Company	O
depends	O
upon	O
the	O
quality	O
of	O
its	O
key	O
management	O
personnel.	O

To	O
prosper	O
the	O
Company	O
must	O
attract	O
,	O
motivate	O
and	O
retain	O
appropriately	O
skilled	O
directors	O
and	O
executives.	O

The	O
Company	O
’	O
s	O
broad	O
remuneration	O
policy	O
is	O
to	O
ensure	O
the	O
remuneration	O
package	O
rewards	O
performance	O
,	O
properly	O
reflects	O
the	O
person	O
’	O
s	O
duties	O
and	O
responsibilities	O
and	O
is	O
competitive	O
in	O
attracting	O
,	O
retaining	O
and	O
motivating	O
people	O
of	O
the	O
highest	O
quality.	O

B.	O

Remuneration	O
Structure	O
and	O
Approvals	O
Remuneration	O
is	O
set	O
by	O
the	O
Board	O
of	O
Directors.	O

The	O
Board	O
has	O
established	O
a	O
separate	O
Remuneration	O
Committee	O
to	O
make	O
recommendations	O
to	O
the	O
Board.	O

During	O
the	O
financial	O
year	O
the	O
Board	O
engaged	O
the	O
services	O
of	O
a	O
remuneration	O
consultant	O
to	O
review	O
,	O
provide	O
industry	O
comparisons	O
and	O
independently	O
recommend	O
remuneration	O
levels	O
,	O
for	O
the	O
Remuneration	O
Committee	O
to	O
rely	O
on	O
when	O
making	O
recommendations	O
to	O
the	O
Board	O
for	O
setting	O
Directors	O
’	O
remuneration.	O

Executive	O
Remuneration	O
Structure	O
The	O
Company	O
aims	O
to	O
reward	O
executives	O
with	O
a	O
level	O
and	O
mix	O
of	O
remuneration	O
commensurate	O
with	O
their	O
position	O
and	O
responsibilities	O
within	O
the	O
Company	O
and	O
aligned	O
with	O
market	O
practice.	O

Executive	O
remuneration	O
and	O
incentive	O
policies	O
and	O
practices	O
must	O
:	O
−	O

be	O
aligned	O
with	O
the	O
Company	O
’	O
s	O
vision	O
,	O
values	O
and	O
overall	O
business	O
objectives	O
;	O
−	O

be	O
designed	O
to	O
motivate	O
the	O
executives	O
to	O
pursue	O
the	O
Company	O
’	O
s	O
long-term	O
growth	O
and	O
success	O
;	O
and	O
−	O

demonstrate	O
a	O
clear	O
relationship	O
between	O
the	O
Company	O
’	O
s	O
overall	O
performance	O
and	O
the	O
performance	O
of	O
executives.	O

Vango	O
Mining	O
Limited	O
Annual	O
Report	O
2021	O
21	O
The	O
nature	O
and	O
amount	O
of	O
remuneration	O
of	O
executives	O
are	O
assessed	O
on	O
a	O
periodic	O
basis	O
by	O
the	O
Remuneration	O
Committee	O
for	O
Board	O
approval	O
,	O
with	O
the	O
overall	O
objective	O
of	O
ensuring	O
maximum	O
stakeholder	O
benefit	O
from	O
the	O
retention	O
of	O
high	O
performing	O
executives.	O

The	O
main	O
objectives	O
sought	O
when	O
reviewing	O
executive	O
remuneration	O
is	O
that	O
the	O
Company	O
has	O
:	O
−	O

coherent	O
remuneration	O
policies	O
and	O
practices	O
to	O
attract	O
and	O
retain	O
executives	O
;	O
−	O

executives	O
who	O
will	O
create	O
value	O
for	O
shareholders	O
−	O

competitive	O
remuneration	O
offered	O
benchmarked	O
against	O
the	O
external	O
market	O
;	O
and	O
−	O

fair	O
and	O
responsible	O
rewards	O
to	O
executives	O
having	O
regard	O
to	O
the	O
performance	O
of	O
the	O
Company	O
,	O
the	O
performance	O
of	O
the	O
executives	O
and	O
the	O
general	O
pay	O
environment.	O

There	O
is	O
no	O
predetermined	O
equity	O
compensation	O
element	O
within	O
the	O
remuneration	O
structure	O
nor	O
are	O
there	O
predetermined	O
performance	O
conditions	O
to	O
be	O
satisfied.	O

All	O
directors	O
(	O
subject	O
to	O
members	O
’	O
approval	O
in	O
accordance	O
with	O
the	O
ASX	O
Listing	O
Rules	O
)	O
and	O
executives	O
are	O
entitled	O
to	O
participate	O
in	O
the	O
Company	O
’	O
s	O
“	O
Vango	O
Mining	O
Limited	O
Employee	O
Equity	O
Incentive	O
Plan	O
”	O
approved	O
25	O
November	O
2020.	O

The	O
Company	O
is	O
proposing	O
that	O
members	O
approve	O
,	O
on	O
8	O
October	O
2021	O
,	O
the	O
Company	O
’	O
s	O
“	O
Vango	O
Mining	O
Limited	O

Loan	O
Plan	O

a	O
new	O
“	O
Vango	O

.	O

Non-Executive	O
Remuneration	O
Structure	O
The	O
Company	O
’	O
s	O
non-executive	O
directors	O
are	O
remunerated	O
by	O
way	O
of	O
fees	O
,	O
in	O
the	O
form	O
of	O
cash	O
,	O
non-cash	O
benefits	O
and	O
superannuation	O
contributions.	O

The	O
Board	O
’	O
s	O
intention	O
is	O
to	O
remunerate	O
non-executive	O
directors	O
at	O
market	O
rates	O
for	O
time	O
,	O
commitment	O
and	O
responsibilities.	O

The	O
Board	O
of	O
Directors	O
determines	O
the	O
payments	O
to	O
the	O
non-executive	O
directors	O
and	O
reviews	O
their	O
remuneration	O
annually	O
,	O
based	O
on	O
market	O
price	O
,	O
duties	O
and	O
accountability.	O

Independent	O
external	O
advice	O
is	O
sought	O
when	O
required.	O

The	O
maximum	O
aggregate	O
fee	O
pool	O
to	O
be	O
paid	O
to	O
Directors	O
(	O
excluding	O
executive	O
directors	O
)	O
is	O
set	O
at	O
$250	O
,	O
000	O
per	O
year	O
(	O
in	O
accordance	O
with	O
the	O
Company	O
’	O
s	O
Constitution	O
)	O
and	O
as	O
approved	O
by	O
the	O
shareholders	O
of	O
the	O
Company.	O

Non-executive	O
directors	O
are	O
able	O
to	O
participate	O
in	O
share-based	O
incentive	O
plans	O
and	O
encouraged	O
to	O
hold	O
shares	O
,	O
to	O
align	O
directors	O
’	O
interests	O
with	O
shareholders	O
’	O
interests.	O

Non-executive	O
directors	O
may	O
enter	O
into	O
separate	O
consultancy	O
mandates	O
with	O
the	O
Company	O
for	O
the	O
provision	O
of	O
professional	O
and	O
technical	O
services	O
that	O
fall	O
outside	O
the	O
scope	O
of	O
their	O
directorship	O
role.	O

Under	O
this	O
mandate	O
directors	O
receive	O
a	O
consultancy	O
fee	O
in	O
connection	O
with	O
time	O
spent	O
on	O
Company	O
business	O
,	O
including	O
reasonable	O
expenses	O
incurred	O
by	O
them	O
in	O
carrying	O
out	O
this	O
consultancy	O
role.	O

E.	O

Share-based	O
Compensation	O
The	O
Company	O
rewards	O
Directors	O
for	O
their	O
performance	O
and	O
aligns	O
their	O
remuneration	O
with	O
the	O
creation	O
of	O
shareholder	O
wealth	O
by	O
issuing	O
share	O
options	O
and	O
shares.	O

Share-based	O
compensation	O
is	O
at	O
the	O
discretion	O
of	O
the	O
Board	O
and	O
no	O
individual	O
has	O
a	O
contractual	O
right	O
to	O
participate	O
in	O
any	O
share-based	O
plan	O
or	O
to	O
receive	O
any	O
guaranteed	O
benefits.	O

Options	O

performance	O

18	O

2019	O
to	O
key	O
management	O

as	O

,	O
and	O
as	O
at	O
the	O
date	O
of	O
this	O

,	O

hurdle	O
conditions	O
have	O
not	O

000	O
–	O

Shares	O
At	O
the	O
General	O
Meeting	O
of	O
shareholders	O
held	O
on	O
27	O
August	O
2018	O
,	O
shareholders	O
approved	O
the	O
establishment	O
of	O
the	O
Vango	O
Mining	O
Share	O
Plan	O
(	O
‘	O
Share	O
Plan	O
’	O
)	O
in	O
accordance	O
with	O
ASX	O
Listing	O
Rule	O
7.2	O
and	O
sections	O
259B	O
(	O
2	O
)	O
and	O
260c	O
(	O
4	O
)	O
of	O
the	O
Corporations	O
Act.	O

Under	O
the	O
Share	O
Plan	O
,	O
eligible	O
participants	O
are	O
provided	O
with	O
a	O
non-recourse	O
loan	O
from	O
the	O
Company	O
to	O
fund	O
the	O
subscription	O
price	O
of	O
issued	O
shares	O
in	O
accordance	O
with	O
the	O
terms	O
and	O
conditions	O
of	O
the	O
Share	O
Plan.	O

At	O
the	O
General	O
Meeting	O
of	O
shareholders	O
held	O
on	O
25	O
November	O
2020	O
,	O
shareholders	O
approved	O
the	O
establishment	O
of	O
the	O
Vango	O
Mining	O
Limited	O
Employee	O
Equity	O
Incentive	O
Plan	O
(	O
‘	O
EIP	O
’	O
)	O
in	O
accordance	O
with	O
ASX	O
Listing	O
Rule	O
7.2	O
(	O
exception	O
13	O
)	O
.	O

Eligible	O
participants	O
of	O
the	O
Share	O
Plan	O
may	O
not	O
deal	O
with	O
the	O
shares	O
while	O
the	O
loan	O
remains	O
outstanding.	O

Although	O
the	O
Share	O
Plan	O
shares	O
are	O
shares	O
for	O
legal	O
and	O
taxation	O
purposes	O
,	O
Accounting	O
Standards	O
require	O
they	O
be	O
treated	O
as	O
options	O
for	O
accounting	O
purposes.	O

Their	O
value	O
is	O
the	O
estimated	O
fair	O
value	O
using	O
the	O
Black-Scholes	O
option	O
pricing	O
model	O
which	O
is	O
expensed	O
in	O
the	O
year	O
of	O
issue.	O

In	O
accordance	O
with	O
the	O
terms	O
and	O
conditions	O
of	O
the	O
Share	O
Plan	O
,	O
the	O
shares	O
are	O
under	O
a	O
Company-imposed	O
trading	O
lock	O
until	O
such	O
time	O
as	O
each	O
Director	O
has	O
repaid	O
the	O
loan	O
provided	O
by	O
the	O
Company	O
to	O
fund	O
the	O
subscription	O
price	O
for	O
shares	O
issued	O
to	O
them.	O

It	O
is	O
at	O
the	O
Board	O
’	O
s	O
discretion	O
whether	O
to	O
seek	O
early	O
repayment	O
of	O
the	O
loan	O
should	O
the	O
Director	O
cease	O
to	O
be	O
employed	O
by	O
the	O
Company.	O

26	O
Vango	O
Mining	O
Limited	O
Annual	O
Report	O
2021	O
Directors	O
’	O
Report	O
continued	O

personnel	O

ordinary	O

AUSTRALIA	O
PARTNERS	O
Gary	O

Dated	O

30	O
September	O

29	O
THE	O
POWER	O
OF	O
BEING	O
UNDERSTOOD	O
AUDIT	O
|	O
TAX	O
|	O
CONSULTING	O
RSM	O
Australia	O
Partners	O
is	O
a	O
member	O
of	O
the	O
RSM	O
network	O
and	O
trades	O
as	O
RSM.	O

RSM	O
is	O
the	O
trading	O
name	O
used	O
by	O
the	O
members	O
of	O
the	O
RSM	O
network.	O

Each	O
member	O
of	O
the	O
RSM	O
network	O
is	O
an	O
independent	O
accounting	O
and	O
consulting	O
firm	O
which	O
practices	O
in	O
its	O
own	O
right.	O

The	O
RSM	O
network	O
is	O
not	O
itself	O
a	O
separate	O
legal	O
entity	O
in	O
any	O
jurisdiction.	O

RSM	O
Australia	O
Partners	O
ABN	O
36	O
965	O
185	O
036	O
Liability	O
limited	O
by	O
a	O
scheme	O
approved	O
under	O
Professional	O
Standards	O
Legislation	O
30	O
Vango	O
Mining	O
Limited	O
Annual	O
Report	O
2021	O
Operating	O
and	O
Financial	O
Review	O
Company	O
strategy	O
and	O
operating	O
activities	O
Vango	O
is	O
progressing	O
a	O
deliberate	O
strategy	O
of	O
growing	O
its	O
high-grade	O
gold	O
endowment	O
to	O
support	O
its	O
ambitions	O
of	O
becoming	O
a	O
significant	O
high-grade	O
Western	O
Australian	O
gold	O
miner.	O

Our	O
exploration	O
programme	O
is	O
designed	O
to	O
expand	O
our	O
current	O
1-million-ounce	O
resource	O
,	O
much	O
of	O
which	O
has	O
never	O
been	O
drill	O
tested	O
below	O
200	O
metres.	O

Current	O
drilling	O
is	O
specifically	O
designed	O
to	O
deliver	O
a	O
resource	O
increase	O
(	O
Indicated	O
and	O
Inferred	O
)	O
to	O
the	O
existing	O
Marymia	O
resource	O
base	O
and	O
to	O
enhance	O
the	O
understanding	O
of	O
the	O
mineralised	O
zones	O
within	O
the	O
initial	O
eleven	O
targeted	O
open	O
pits	O
for	O
the	O
benefit	O
of	O
Vango	O
’	O
s	O
mine	O
planning.	O

In	O
the	O
near	O
term	O
,	O
drilling	O
campaigns	O
will	O
be	O
designed	O
to	O
deliver	O
‘	O
critical	O
mass	O
’	O
to	O
increase	O
the	O
mine	O
life	O
of	O
a	O
proposed	O
future	O
mining	O
operation	O
from	O
Marymia	O
’	O
s	O
resource	O
base.	O

They	O
will	O
specifically	O
target	O
increases	O
in	O
total	O
ounces	O
and	O
tonnes	O
to	O
ensure	O
that	O
mill	O
capacity	O
and	O
Project	O
life	O
of	O
mine	O
are	O
maximised.	O

This	O
allows	O
assessment	O
of	O
appropriate	O
financing	O
levels	O
for	O
the	O
Company	O
’	O
s	O
proposed	O
stand-alone	O
mining	O
operation.	O

The	O
Plutonic	O
gold	O
mine	O
has	O
produced	O
in	O
excess	O
of	O
5.5moz	O
of	O
gold	O
and	O
sits	O
along	O
strike	O
,	O
immediately	O
to	O
the	O
southwest	O
of	O
the	O
Marymia	O
Project	O
in	O
a	O

sequence	O

sequence	O

across	O
Marymia	O
and	O
most	O
of	O
it	O
has	O
never	O
been	O

tested	O
to	O
depth.	O

Operating	O
risks	O
The	O
operations	O
of	O
the	O
Company	O
may	O
be	O
affected	O
by	O
various	O
factors	O
,	O
including	O
failure	O
to	O
locate	O
or	O
identify	O
mineral	O
deposits	O
,	O
failure	O
to	O
achieve	O
predicted	O
grades	O
in	O
exploration	O
and	O
mining	O
,	O
operational	O
and	O
technical	O
difficulties	O
encountered	O
in	O
mining	O
,	O
difficulties	O
in	O
commissioning	O
and	O
operating	O
plant	O
and	O
equipment	O
,	O
mechanical	O
failure	O
or	O
plant	O
breakdown	O
,	O
unanticipated	O
metallurgical	O
problems	O
which	O
may	O
affect	O
extraction	O
costs	O
,	O
adverse	O
weather	O
conditions	O
,	O
industrial	O
and	O
environmental	O
accidents	O
,	O
industrial	O
disputes	O
and	O

or	O

in	O

of	O

,	O

Environmental	O
risks	O
The	O
operations	O
and	O
proposed	O
activities	O
of	O
the	O
Company	O
are	O
subject	O
to	O
the	O
laws	O
and	O

of	O
Australia	O
and	O
Laos	O
concerning	O
the	O
environment.	O

As	O
with	O
most	O
exploration	O
projects	O
and	O
mining	O
operations	O
,	O
the	O
Company	O
’	O

Market	O
conditions	O
Share	O

of	O

Company	O
’	O

Share	O

as	O
:	O
i.	O

general	O

;	O

of	O

other	O

;	O

;	O

changes	O
in	O

toward	O
particular	O
market	O
sectors	O
;	O
v.	O

the	O
demand	O
for	O
,	O
and	O
supply	O
of	O
,	O
capital	O
;	O
and	O
vi.	O

terrorism	O
or	O
other	O
hostilities.	O

The	O
market	O
price	O
of	O
securities	O
can	O
fall	O
as	O
well	O
as	O
rise	O
and	O
may	O

to	O

and	O

market	O
for	O

in	O

and	O
resource	O
exploration	O
stocks	O
in	O
particular.	O

Additional	O
requirements	O
for	O
capital	O
The	O
Company	O
’	O
s	O
capital	O
requirements	O
depend	O
on	O
numerous	O
factors.	O

Depending	O
on	O
the	O
Company	O
’	O
s	O
ability	O
to	O
generate	O
income	O
,	O
the	O
Company	O
will	O

Any	O

will	O

,	O
and	O
debt	O
financing	O
,	O
if	O

,	O
may	O

on	O

and	O

If	O

as	O
needed	O
,	O

and	O

back	O
its	O
exploration	O
programmes	O
,	O
as	O
the	O

may	O

Role	O
of	O
the	O
Board	O
and	O
Management	O
The	O
Board	O
is	O
responsible	O
for	O
guiding	O
and	O
monitoring	O
the	O
Company	O
on	O
behalf	O
of	O
shareholders	O
by	O
whom	O
they	O
are	O
elected	O
and	O
to	O
whom	O
they	O
are	O
accountable.	O

The	O
Board	O
is	O
responsible	O
for	O
:	O
−	O

developing	O
,	O
approving	O
and	O
monitoring	O
implementation	O
of	O
corporate	O
policy	O
,	O
strategy	O
and	O
performance	O

;	O
−	O

and	O

of	O
the	O
most	O

;	O
−	O

and	O

,	O

of	O

,	O

,	O

and	O

;	O

The	O

for	O

and	O

of	O

Company	O
to	O

,	O

are	O

the	O
Company	O

of	O
their	O

as	O

The	O

to	O
its	O
stakeholder	O
to	O
ensure	O
it	O
is	O
managed	O
with	O

and	O
that	O

are	O

to	O

and	O

To	O

,	O

,	O

expenditure	O
other	O
commitments	O
are	O

documented	O
and	O
have	O
been	O
authorised	O
by	O
the	O
Board.	O

Composition	O
of	O
the	O
Board	O
The	O
Board	O
determines	O
its	O
size	O
and	O
composition	O
,	O
subject	O
to	O
the	O
terms	O
of	O
the	O
Constitution.	O

The	O
Board	O
does	O
not	O
believe	O
that	O
it	O
should	O
establish	O
a	O
limit	O
on	O
tenure	O
other	O
than	O
stipulated	O
in	O
the	O
Company	O
’	O
s	O
Constitution.	O

While	O
tenure	O
limits	O
can	O
help	O
to	O
ensure	O
fresh	O
ideas	O
and	O
viewpoints	O
available	O
to	O
the	O
Board	O
,	O
they	O
have	O
the	O
disadvantage	O
of	O
losing	O
the	O
contribution	O
of	O
directors	O
who	O
have	O
been	O
able	O
to	O
develop	O
an	O
increasing	O
insight	O
into	O
the	O
Company	O
and	O
its	O
operations.	O

Director	O
Independence	O
The	O
Company	O
recognises	O
that	O
independent	O
Directors	O
are	O
important	O
in	O
verifying	O
to	O
shareholders	O
that	O
the	O
Board	O
is	O
properly	O
fulfilling	O
its	O
role	O
and	O
is	O
diligent	O
in	O
holding	O
senior	O
management	O
accountable	O
for	O
its	O
performance.	O

Where	O
practical	O
,	O
it	O
is	O
intended	O
that	O
the	O
Board	O
should	O
comprise	O
a	O
majority	O
of	O
independent	O
non-executive	O
directors	O
and	O
comprise	O
directors	O
with	O
a	O
broad	O
range	O
of	O
qualifications	O
,	O
skills	O
,	O
expertise	O
and	O
experience	O
from	O
a	O
diverse	O
range	O
of	O
backgrounds.	O

Where	O
practical	O
it	O
is	O
also	O
intended	O
that	O
the	O
Chair	O
be	O
an	O
independent	O
non-executive	O
director.	O

Directors	O
of	O
Vango	O
Mining	O
Limited	O
are	O
considered	O
to	O
be	O
independent	O
when	O
they	O
are	O
independent	O
of	O
management	O
and	O
free	O
from	O
any	O
business	O
or	O
other	O
relationship	O
that	O
could	O
materially	O
interfere	O
with	O
,	O
or	O
could	O
reasonably	O
be	O
perceived	O
to	O
materially	O
interfere	O
with	O
,	O
the	O
exercise	O
of	O
their	O
unfettered	O
and	O
independent	O
judgement.	O

The	O
Board	O
has	O
adopted	O
a	O
definition	O
of	O
independence	O
based	O
on	O
that	O
set	O
out	O
in	O
Principle	O
2	O
of	O
the	O
ASX	O
Corporate	O
Governance	O
Revise	O
Principles	O
and	O
Recommendations.	O

The	O
Board	O
regularly	O

the	O

of	O
each	O
director	O
in	O
light	O
of	O
their	O
interests	O
disclosed	O
to	O

Board.	O

Appointment	O
to	O
the	O
Board	O
The	O
Board	O
undertakes	O
the	O
role	O
of	O
a	O
Nomination	O
Committee	O
which	O
identifies	O
and	O
recommends	O
potential	O
director	O
appointments.	O

Where	O
a	O
casual	O
vacancy	O
arises	O
during	O
the	O
year	O
,	O
the	O
Board	O
has	O
procedures	O
to	O
select	O
the	O
most	O
suitable	O
candidate	O
with	O
the	O
appropriate	O
experience	O
and	O
expertise	O
to	O
ensure	O
a	O
balanced	O
and	O
effective	O
board.	O

Any	O
director	O
appointed	O
during	O
the	O
year	O
to	O
fill	O
a	O
casual	O
vacancy	O
or	O
as	O
an	O
addition	O
to	O
the	O
current	O
Board	O
,	O
holds	O
office	O
until	O
the	O
next	O
Annual	O
General	O
Meeting	O
and	O
is	O
then	O
eligible	O
for	O
re-election	O
by	O
the	O
shareholders.	O

New	O
directors	O
receive	O
a	O
letter	O
of	O
appointment	O
which	O
sets	O
out	O
the	O
terms	O
of	O
their	O
appointment.	O

that	O

with	O
members	O
of	O
the	O
executive	O
team.	O

Mining	O
Limited	O
Annual	O
Report	O

33	O

of	O

Ethical	O
Business	O
Practices	O

for	O

and	O

:	O

the	O
law	O
;	O

)	O

in	O
the	O
best	O

of	O

Company	O

Shareholding	O
and	O
Trading	O
The	O
Board	O

and	O

to	O

of	O

by	O
directors	O
and	O

executives	O
is	O
prohibited	O
under	O

ASX	O

Rules	O
and	O
during	O

of	O

or	O

must	O
not	O

in	O
the	O
Company	O
’	O
s	O

at	O
any	O

when	O
he	O
or	O
she	O
has	O
unpublished	O
information	O
which	O
,	O
if	O
generally	O
available	O
,	O
might	O
affect	O
the	O
share	O
price.	O

or	O

before	O
dealing	O
in	O
the	O
Company	O
’	O
s	O
securities.	O

Risk	O
Management	O
The	O
entire	O
Board	O
is	O
responsible	O
for	O
overseeing	O
the	O
risk	O
management	O
function.	O

The	O
Board	O
is	O

for	O

the	O

and	O
opportunities	O
are	O
identified	O
on	O
a	O

basis.	O

The	O
Board	O
determines	O
the	O
Company	O
’	O
s	O
“	O
risk	O
profile	O
”	O
and	O
is	O

for	O

and	O

risk	O
management	O
strategies	O
and	O
policies	O
,	O

compliance	O
and	O
internal	O
control.	O

’	O
s	O

and	O

with	O
the	O

These	O
include	O
the	O
following	O
:	O
Vango	O
Mining	O

Monitoring	O
Performance	O
The	O

management	O

Company	O
’	O

results.	O

are	O
compared	O
to	O
budgets	O

which	O
have	O
been	O

on	O

basis	O
of	O

results.	O

to	O

Gender	O
Diversity	O
The	O

(	O

reducing	O
the	O
carrying	O
amount	O
directly.	O

Cash	O
flows	O
relating	O
to	O
short-term	O
receivables	O
are	O
not	O
discounted	O
recognised	O
in	O
profit	O
or	O
loss.	O

if	O
the	O
effect	O
of	O
discounting	O
is	O
immaterial.	O

10	O
Vango	O
Mining	O
Limited	O
Annual	O
Report	O
2021	O
61	O
NOTES	O
TO	O
THE	O
CONSOLIDATED	O
FINANCIAL	O
STATEMENT	O
For	O
the	O
year	O
ended	O
30	O
June	O
2021	O
(	O
m	O
)	O
Investment	O
in	O
joint	O
ventures	O
A	O
joint	O
venture	O
is	O
a	O
type	O
of	O
joint	O
arrangement	O
whereby	O
the	O
parties	O
that	O
have	O
joint	O
control	O
of	O
the	O
arrangement	O
have	O
rights	O
to	O
the	O
net	O
assets	O
of	O
the	O
joint	O
venture.	O

Joint	O
control	O
is	O
the	O
contractually	O
agreed	O
sharing	O
of	O
control	O
of	O
an	O
arrangement	O
,	O
which	O
exists	O
only	O
when	O
decisions	O
about	O
the	O
relevant	O
activities	O
require	O
unanimous	O
consent	O
of	O
the	O
parties	O
sharing	O
control.	O

The	O
Group	O
’	O
s	O
investment	O
in	O
joint	O
venture	O
are	O
accounted	O
for	O
using	O
the	O
equity	O
method.	O

Under	O
the	O
equity	O
method	O
,	O
the	O
investment	O
in	O
joint	O
venture	O
is	O
initially	O
recognised	O
at	O
cost.	O

The	O
carrying	O
amount	O
of	O
the	O
investment	O
is	O
adjusted	O
to	O
recognise	O
changes	O
in	O
the	O
Group	O
’	O
s	O
share	O
of	O
net	O
assets	O
of	O
the	O
joint	O
venture	O
since	O
the	O
acquisition	O
date.	O

Goodwill	O
relating	O
to	O
the	O
joint	O
venture	O
is	O
included	O
in	O
the	O
carrying	O
amount	O
of	O
the	O
investment	O
and	O
is	O
not	O
tested	O
for	O
impairment	O
separately.	O

The	O
statement	O
of	O
profit	O
or	O
loss	O
reflects	O
the	O
Group	O
’	O
s	O
share	O
of	O
the	O
results	O
of	O
operations	O
of	O
the	O
joint	O
venture.	O

Any	O
change	O
in	O
OCI	O
of	O
those	O
investees	O
is	O
presented	O
as	O
part	O
of	O
the	O
Group	O
’	O
s	O
OCI.	O

In	O
addition	O
,	O
when	O
there	O
has	O
been	O
a	O
change	O
recognised	O
directly	O
in	O
the	O
equity	O
of	O
the	O
joint	O
venture	O
,	O
the	O
Group	O
recognises	O
its	O
share	O
of	O
any	O
changes	O
,	O
when	O
applicable	O
,	O
in	O
the	O
statement	O
of	O
changes	O
in	O
equity.	O

Unrealised	O
gains	O
and	O
losses	O
resulting	O
from	O
transactions	O
between	O
the	O
Group	O
and	O
the	O
joint	O
venture	O
are	O
eliminated	O
to	O
the	O
extent	O
of	O
the	O
interest	O
in	O
the	O
joint	O
venture.	O

The	O
aggregate	O
of	O
the	O
Group	O
’	O
s	O
share	O
of	O
profit	O
or	O
loss	O
of	O
a	O
joint	O
venture	O
is	O
shown	O
on	O
the	O
face	O
of	O
the	O
statement	O
of	O
profit	O
or	O
loss	O
outside	O
operating	O
profit	O
and	O
represents	O
profit	O
or	O
loss	O
after	O
tax	O
and	O
non-controlling	O
interests	O
in	O
the	O
subsidiaries	O
of	O
the	O
joint	O
venture.	O

The	O
financial	O
statements	O
of	O
the	O
joint	O
venture	O
are	O
prepared	O
for	O
the	O
same	O
reporting	O
period	O
as	O
the	O
Group.	O

When	O
necessary	O
,	O
adjustments	O
are	O
made	O
to	O
bring	O
the	O
accounting	O
policies	O
in	O
line	O
with	O
those	O
of	O
the	O
Group.	O

After	O
application	O
of	O
the	O
equity	O
method	O
,	O
the	O
Group	O
determines	O
whether	O
it	O
is	O
necessary	O
to	O
recognise	O
an	O
impairment	O
loss	O
on	O
its	O
investment	O
in	O
its	O
joint	O
venture.	O

At	O
each	O
reporting	O
date	O
,	O
the	O
Group	O
determines	O
whether	O
there	O
is	O
objective	O
evidence	O
that	O
the	O
investment	O
in	O
joint	O
venture	O
is	O
impaired.	O

If	O
there	O
is	O
such	O
evidence	O
,	O
the	O
Group	O
calculates	O
the	O
amount	O
of	O
impairment	O
as	O
the	O
difference	O
between	O
the	O
recoverable	O
amount	O
of	O
the	O
joint	O
venture	O
and	O
its	O
carrying	O
value	O
,	O
and	O
then	O
recognises	O
the	O
loss	O
within	O
‘	O
Share	O
of	O
profit	O
of	O
a	O
joint	O
venture	O
’	O
in	O
the	O
statement	O
of	O
profit	O
or	O
loss.	O

Upon	O
loss	O
of	O
significant	O
influence	O
over	O
the	O
joint	O
venture	O
,	O
the	O
Group	O
measures	O
and	O
recognises	O
any	O
retained	O
investment	O
at	O
its	O
fair	O
value.	O

Any	O
difference	O
between	O
the	O
carrying	O
amount	O
of	O
the	O
associate	O
or	O
joint	O
venture	O
upon	O
loss	O
of	O
significant	O
influence	O
or	O
joint	O
control	O
and	O
the	O
fair	O
value	O
of	O
the	O
retained	O
investment	O
and	O
proceeds	O
from	O
disposal	O
is	O
recognised	O
in	O
profit	O
or	O
loss.	O

(	O
n	O
)	O
Investments	O
and	O
other	O
financial	O
assets	O
Investments	O
and	O
other	O
financial	O
assets	O
are	O
initially	O
measured	O
at	O
fair	O
value.	O

Transaction	O
costs	O
are	O
included	O
as	O
part	O
of	O
the	O
initial	O
measurement	O
,	O
except	O
for	O
financial	O
assets	O
at	O
fair	O
value	O
through	O
profit	O
or	O
loss.	O

Such	O
assets	O
are	O
subsequently	O
measured	O
at	O
either	O
amortised	O
cost	O
or	O
fair	O
value	O
depending	O
on	O
their	O
classification.	O

Classification	O
is	O
determined	O
based	O
on	O
both	O
the	O
business	O
model	O
within	O
which	O
such	O
assets	O
are	O
held	O
and	O
the	O
contractual	O
cash	O
flow	O
characteristics	O
of	O
the	O
financial	O
asset	O
unless	O
an	O
accounting	O
mismatch	O
is	O
being	O
avoided.	O

Financial	O
assets	O
are	O
derecognised	O
when	O
the	O
rights	O
to	O
receive	O
cash	O
flows	O
have	O
expired	O
or	O
have	O
been	O
transferred	O
and	O
the	O
consolidated	O
entity	O
has	O
transferred	O
substantially	O
all	O
the	O
risks	O
and	O
rewards	O
of	O
ownership.	O

When	O
there	O
is	O
no	O
reasonable	O
expectation	O
of	O
recovering	O
part	O
or	O
all	O
of	O
a	O
financial	O
asset	O
,	O
it's	O
carrying	O
value	O
is	O
written	O
off.	O

Financial	O
assets	O
at	O
fair	O
value	O
through	O
profit	O
or	O
loss	O
Financial	O
assets	O
not	O
measured	O
at	O
amortised	O
cost	O
or	O
at	O
fair	O
value	O
through	O
other	O
comprehensive	O
income	O
are	O
classified	O
as	O
financial	O
assets	O
at	O
fair	O
value	O
through	O
profit	O
or	O
loss.	O

Typically	O
,	O
such	O
financial	O
assets	O
will	O
be	O
either	O
:	O
(	O
i	O
)	O
held	O
for	O
trading	O
,	O
where	O
they	O
are	O
acquired	O
for	O
the	O
purpose	O
of	O
selling	O
in	O
the	O
short-term	O
with	O
an	O
intention	O
of	O
making	O
a	O
profit	O
,	O
or	O
a	O
derivative	O
;	O
or	O
(	O
ii	O
)	O
designated	O
as	O
such	O
upon	O
initial	O
recognition	O
where	O
permitted.	O

Fair	O
value	O
movements	O
are	O
recognised	O
in	O
profit	O
or	O
loss.	O

TO	O

CONSOLIDATED	O
FINANCIAL	O
STATEMENT	O
For	O
the	O
year	O
ended	O
30	O
June	O
2021	O
Impairment	O
of	O
financial	O
assets	O
The	O
consolidated	O
entity	O
recognises	O
a	O
loss	O
allowance	O
for	O
expected	O
credit	O
losses	O
on	O
financial	O
assets	O
which	O
are	O
either	O
measured	O
at	O
amortised	O
cost	O
or	O
fair	O
value	O
through	O
other	O
comprehensive	O
income.	O

The	O
measurement	O
of	O
the	O
loss	O
allowance	O
depends	O
upon	O
the	O
consolidated	O
entity's	O
assessment	O
at	O
the	O
end	O
of	O
each	O
reporting	O
period	O
as	O
to	O
whether	O
the	O
financial	O
instrument's	O
credit	O
risk	O
has	O
increased	O
significantly	O
since	O
initial	O
recognition	O
,	O
based	O
on	O
reasonable	O
and	O
supportable	O
information	O
that	O
is	O
available	O
,	O
without	O
undue	O
cost	O
or	O
effort	O
to	O
obtain.	O

Where	O
there	O
has	O
not	O
been	O
a	O
significant	O
increase	O
in	O
exposure	O
to	O
credit	O
risk	O
since	O
initial	O
recognition	O
,	O
a	O
12-month	O
expected	O
credit	O
loss	O
allowance	O
is	O
estimated.	O

This	O
represents	O
a	O
portion	O
of	O
the	O
asset's	O
lifetime	O
expected	O
credit	O
losses	O
that	O
is	O
attributable	O
to	O
a	O
default	O
event	O
that	O
is	O
possible	O
within	O
the	O
next	O
12	O
months.	O

Where	O
a	O
financial	O
asset	O
has	O
become	O
credit	O
impaired	O
or	O
where	O
it	O
is	O
determined	O
that	O
credit	O
risk	O
has	O
increased	O
significantly	O
,	O
the	O
loss	O
allowance	O
is	O
based	O
on	O
the	O
asset's	O
lifetime	O
expected	O
credit	O
losses.	O

The	O
amount	O
of	O
expected	O
credit	O
loss	O
recognised	O
is	O
measured	O
on	O
the	O
basis	O
of	O
the	O
probability	O
weighted	O
present	O
value	O
of	O
anticipated	O
cash	O
shortfalls	O
over	O
the	O
life	O
of	O
the	O
instrument	O
discounted	O
at	O
the	O
original	O
effective	O
interest	O
rate.	O

(	O
o	O

)	O
Property	O
,	O
plant	O
and	O
equipment	O
Plant	O
and	O
equipment	O
is	O
stated	O
at	O
historical	O
cost	O
less	O
accumulated	O
depreciation	O
and	O
impairment.	O

Historical	O
cost	O
includes	O
expenditure	O
that	O
is	O
directly	O
attributable	O
to	O
the	O
acquisition	O
of	O
the	O
items.	O

Depreciation	O
is	O
calculated	O
on	O
a	O
reducing	O
balance	O
basis	O
to	O
write	O
down	O
the	O
net	O
cost	O
of	O
each	O
item	O
of	O
property	O
,	O
plant	O
and	O
equipment	O
(	O
excluding	O
land	O
)	O
over	O
their	O
expected	O
useful	O
lives	O
as	O
follows	O
:	O
Field	O
equipment	O
10-20	O
years	O
Office	O
equipment	O
10	O
years	O
Motor	O
Vehicles	O
10	O
years	O
Software	O
10	O
years	O
The	O
residual	O
values	O
,	O
useful	O
lives	O
and	O
depreciation	O
methods	O
are	O
reviewed	O
,	O
and	O
adjusted	O
if	O
appropriate	O
,	O
at	O
each	O
reporting	O
date.	O

An	O
item	O
of	O
property	O
,	O
plant	O
and	O
equipment	O
is	O
de-recognised	O
upon	O
disposal	O
or	O
when	O
there	O
is	O
no	O
future	O
economic	O
benefit	O
to	O
the	O
Group.	O

Any	O
gains	O
and	O
losses	O
between	O
the	O
carrying	O
amount	O
and	O
the	O
disposal	O
proceeds	O
are	O
taken	O
to	O
profit	O
or	O
loss.	O

Any	O
revaluation	O
surplus	O
reserve	O
relating	O
to	O
the	O
item	O
disposed	O
of	O
is	O
transferred	O
directly	O
to	O
retained	O
profits.	O

(	O
p	O
)	O
Leases	O
The	O
consolidated	O
entity	O
has	O
elected	O
not	O
to	O
recognise	O
a	O
right-of-use	O
asset	O
and	O
corresponding	O
lease	O
liability	O
for	O
short-	O
term	O
leases	O
with	O
terms	O
of	O
12	O
months	O
or	O
less	O
and	O
leases	O
of	O
low-value	O
assets.	O

Lease	O
payments	O
on	O
these	O
assets	O
are	O
expensed	O
to	O
profit	O
or	O
loss	O
as	O
incurred.	O

(	O
q	O
)	O
Exploration	O
and	O
evaluation	O
assets	O
Exploration	O
and	O
evaluation	O
expenditure	O
in	O
relation	O
to	O
separate	O
areas	O
of	O
interest	O
for	O
which	O
rights	O
of	O
tenure	O
are	O
current	O
is	O
carried	O
forward	O
as	O
an	O
asset	O
in	O
the	O
statement	O
of	O
financial	O
position	O
where	O
it	O
is	O
expected	O
that	O
the	O
expenditure	O
will	O
be	O
recovered	O
through	O
the	O
successful	O
development	O
and	O

of	O
an	O
area	O
of	O
interest	O
,	O
or	O
by	O
its	O
sale	O
;	O
or	O
exploitation	O
activities	O
are	O
continuing	O
in	O
an	O
area	O
and	O
activities	O
have	O
not	O
reached	O
a	O
stage	O
which	O
permits	O
a	O
reasonable	O
estimate	O
of	O
the	O
existence	O
or	O
otherwise	O
of	O

reserves.	O

Indirect	O

and	O

of	O
interest	O
are	O

A	O

of	O
interest	O
to	O
determine	O
the	O

of	O

to	O

forward	O
costs.	O

Where	O
a	O
project	O
or	O
an	O
area	O
of	O
interest	O
has	O
been	O
abandoned	O
,	O
the	O

incurred	O
thereon	O
is	O
written	O
off	O
in	O
the	O
year	O
in	O
which	O
the	O
decision	O
is	O
made.	O

The	O
Company	O
as	O

of	O
its	O

has	O

Mining	O
Limited	O
Annual	O
Report	O
2021	O
63	O
NOTES	O
TO	O
THE	O
CONSOLIDATED	O
FINANCIAL	O
STATEMENT	O
For	O
the	O
year	O
ended	O
30	O
June	O
2021	O
When	O
the	O
Company	O
is	O
acting	O
as	O
the	O
farmee	O
its	O
expenditure	O
is	O
recognised	O
under	O
the	O
arrangement	O
in	O
respect	O
of	O
its	O
own	O
interest	O
and	O
that	O
retained	O
by	O
the	O
farmor	O
,	O
as	O
and	O
when	O
the	O
costs	O
are	O
incurred.	O

The	O
farmee	O
accounts	O
for	O
its	O
expenditures	O
under	O
a	O
farm-in	O
arrangement	O
in	O
the	O
same	O
way	O
as	O
directly	O
incurred	O
E&E	O
expenditure.	O

For	O
the	O
arrangements	O
of	O
which	O
the	O
Company	O
is	O
the	O
farmor	O
it	O
accounts	O
for	O
the	O
farm-out	O
arrangement	O
as	O
follows	O
:	O
•	O

The	O
farmor	O
does	O
not	O
record	O
any	O
expenditure	O
made	O
by	O
the	O
farmee	O
on	O
its	O
behalf	O
•	O

The	O
farmor	O
does	O
not	O
recognise	O
a	O
gain	O
or	O
loss	O
on	O
the	O
farm-out	O
arrangement	O
but	O
rather	O
,	O
redesignates	O
any	O
costs	O
previously	O
capitalised	O
in	O
relation	O
to	O
the	O
whole	O
interest	O
as	O

to	O
the	O

interest	O

Any	O

is	O

against	O
costs	O
previously	O
capitalised	O
in	O
relation	O
to	O
the	O
whole	O
interest	O

excess	O
accounted	O
for	O
by	O
the	O
farmor	O
as	O

on	O

(	O
r	O
)	O
Impairment	O
of	O
non-financial	O
assets	O
At	O
each	O
reporting	O
date	O
,	O
the	O
Company	O
reviews	O
the	O
carrying	O
values	O
of	O
its	O
assets	O
to	O
determine	O
whether	O
there	O
is	O
any	O
indication	O
that	O
those	O
assets	O
have	O
been	O
impaired.	O

If	O
such	O
an	O
indication	O
exists	O
,	O
the	O
recoverable	O
amount	O
of	O
the	O
asset	O
,	O
being	O
the	O
higher	O
of	O
the	O
asset	O
’	O
s	O
fair	O
value	O
less	O
costs	O
to	O
sell	O
and	O
value	O
in	O
use	O
,	O
is	O
compared	O
to	O
the	O
asset	O
’	O
s	O
carrying	O
value.	O

When	O
the	O
carrying	O
amount	O
of	O
an	O
asset	O
exceeds	O
its	O
carrying	O
amount	O
,	O
the	O
asset	O
is	O
considered	O
impaired	O
and	O
written	O
down	O
to	O
its	O
recoverable	O
amount.	O

Where	O

is	O
not	O
possible	O
to	O
estimate	O
the	O
recoverable	O
amount	O
of	O
an	O
individual	O
asset	O

the	O
Group	O
estimates	O
the	O
recoverable	O
amount	O
of	O
the	O
cash-generating	O
unit	O
to	O
which	O
the	O
asset	O
belongs.	O

In	O
assessing	O
value	O
in	O
use	O
,	O
the	O
estimated	O
future	O

are	O
discounted	O
to	O
their	O
present	O

using	O
a	O

rate	O
that	O
reflects	O
current	O
market	O

of	O
the	O
time	O
value	O
of	O
money	O
and	O
the	O
risks	O
specific	O
to	O
the	O
asset.	O

of	O
disposal	O

When	O

asset	O
or	O
liability	O

that	O

an	O

of	O

between	O

participants	O
at	O
the	O
measurement	O
date	O
;	O
and	O
assumes	O
that	O
the	O
transaction	O
will	O
take	O
place	O
either	O
:	O
in	O
the	O
principal	O
market	O
;	O
or	O
in	O
the	O
absence	O
of	O
a	O

market	O
,	O
in	O
the	O
most	O

market.	O

when	O

,	O

’	O

obligations	O
are	O

,	O
cancelled	O
or	O
they	O
expire.	O

Fair	O
value	O
is	O
measured	O
using	O
the	O
assumptions	O
that	O
market	O
participants	O
would	O
use	O
when	O
pricing	O
the	O
asset	O
or	O
liability	O
,	O
assuming	O
they	O
act	O
in	O
their	O
economic	O
best	O
interests.	O

For	O
non-financial	O
assets	O
,	O
the	O
fair	O
value	O
measurement	O
is	O
based	O
on	O
its	O
highest	O
and	O
best	O
use.	O

Valuation	O
techniques	O
that	O
are	O
appropriate	O
in	O
the	O
circumstances	O
and	O
for	O
which	O
sufficient	O
data	O
are	O
available	O
to	O
measure	O
fair	O
value	O
,	O
are	O
used	O
,	O
maximising	O
the	O
use	O
of	O
relevant	O
observable	O
inputs	O
and	O
minimising	O
the	O
use	O
of	O
unobservable	O
inputs.	O

Assets	O
and	O
liabilities	O
measured	O
at	O
fair	O
value	O
are	O
classified	O
into	O
three	O
levels	O
,	O
using	O
a	O
fair	O
value	O
hierarchy	O
that	O
reflects	O
the	O
significance	O
of	O
the	O
inputs	O
used	O
in	O
making	O
the	O
measurements.	O

Classifications	O
are	O
reviewed	O
at	O
each	O
reporting	O
date	O
and	O
transfers	O
between	O
levels	O
are	O
determined	O
based	O
on	O
a	O
reassessment	O
of	O
the	O
lowest	O
level	O
of	O
input	O
that	O
is	O
significant	O
to	O
the	O
fair	O
value	O
measurement.	O

For	O
recurring	O
and	O
non-recurring	O
fair	O
value	O
measurements	O
,	O
external	O
valuers	O
may	O
be	O
used	O
when	O
internal	O
expertise	O
is	O
either	O
not	O
available	O
or	O
when	O
the	O
valuation	O
is	O
deemed	O
to	O
be	O
significant.	O

External	O
valuers	O
are	O
selected	O
based	O
on	O
market	O
knowledge	O
and	O
reputation.	O

Where	O
there	O
is	O
a	O
significant	O
change	O
in	O
fair	O
value	O
of	O
an	O
asset	O
or	O
liability	O
from	O
one	O
period	O
to	O
another	O
,	O
an	O
analysis	O
is	O
undertaken	O
,	O
which	O
includes	O
a	O
verification	O
of	O
the	O
major	O
inputs	O
applied	O
in	O
the	O
latest	O
valuation	O
and	O
a	O
comparison	O
,	O
where	O
applicable	O
,	O
with	O
external	O
sources	O
of	O
data.	O

y	O
)	O

per	O
share	O

economicextraction.Thelocation	O
,	O

(	O

)	O
,	O
continuityandother	O
geologicalcharacteristicsofa	O
mineralresourceareknown	O

sampling.Orereserves	O

from	O

’	O

current	O

The	O
Group	O
estimates	O
its	O
ore	O
reserves	O
based	O
on	O
information	O
compiled	O
by	O
appropriately	O
qualified	O
persons	O
able	O
to	O
interpret	O
the	O
geological	O
data.	O

The	O
estimation	O
of	O
recoverable	O
reserves	O
is	O
based	O
on	O
factors	O
such	O
as	O
estimates	O
of	O

,	O

requirements	O
,	O
and	O
production	O

assumptions	O
and	O
judgements	O

in	O
estimatingthe	O
sizeand	O
gradeof	O
the	O
orebody.Changesinthereservesorresource	O
estimatesmay	O
impacton	O
the	O
valueofexplorationandevaluation	O
assets	O
,	O
mine	O
properties	O
,	O
property	O

and	O

,	O

(	O
iii	O
)	O
Note	O
20	O
–	O

Provision	O
forsite	O
rehabilitation	O
(	O
Key	O
Estimate	O
)	O
In	O
accordance	O
with	O
the	O
Group	O
’	O
s	O
legal	O
requirements	O
,	O
provision	O
is	O
made	O
for	O

costs	O
of	O
future	O
restoration	O
and	O
rehabilitation	O
of	O
areas	O
from	O
which	O
natural	O
resources	O
have	O
been	O

The	O
provision	O
has	O
been	O
based	O
upon	O

levies	O
in	O
accordance	O
with	O
the	O
requirements	O
of	O
the	O
Government	O
of	O
Western	O
Australia	O
under	O
the	O
Mining	O
Rehabilitation	O

Act	O
2012	O
and	O
used	O
to	O
rehabilitate	O
abandoned	O
mines.	O

Management	O
in	O
consultation	O
with	O
independent	O
external	O
advisors	O
has	O
concluded	O
that	O
this	O
basis	O
is	O
an	O
appropriate	O
basis	O
to	O
estimate	O
the	O
likely	O
actual	O
costs	O
to	O
rehabilitate	O
its	O
sites.	O

change	O
in	O
the	O
restoration	O
provision	O
is	O
recorded	O
against	O

carrying	O
value	O
of	O
the	O
provision	O
and	O
the	O
related	O
asset	O
,	O
only	O
to	O
the	O
extent	O
that	O
it	O
is	O
probable	O
that	O
future	O
economic	O
benefits	O
associated	O
with	O
the	O
restoration	O
expenditure	O
will	O
flow	O
tothe	O
entity	O
,	O
with	O
theeffectbeing	O
recognised	O
in	O
the	O
incomestatement	O
on	O
a	O
prospective	O
basis	O
over	O
the	O

life	O
of	O
the	O
relevant	O
operation.	O

Capital	O
risk	O
management	O
The	O
consolidated	O
entity's	O
objectives	O
when	O
managing	O
capital	O
is	O
to	O
safeguard	O
its	O
ability	O
to	O
continue	O
as	O
a	O
going	O
concern	O
,	O
so	O
that	O
it	O
can	O
provide	O
returns	O
for	O
shareholders	O
and	O
benefits	O
for	O
other	O
stakeholders	O
and	O
to	O
maintain	O
an	O
optimum	O
capital	O
structure	O
to	O
reduce	O
the	O
cost	O
of	O
capital.	O

24.	O

Financial	O
instruments	O
Capital	O
is	O
regarded	O
as	O
total	O
equity	O
,	O
as	O
recognised	O
in	O
the	O
statement	O
of	O
financial	O
position	O
,	O
plus	O
net	O
debt.	O

Net	O
debt	O
is	O
calculated	O
as	O
total	O
borrowings	O
less	O
cash	O
and	O
cash	O
equivalents.	O

Financial	O
risk	O
management	O
In	O
order	O
to	O
maintain	O
or	O
adjust	O
the	O
capital	O
structure	O
,	O
the	O
consolidated	O
entity	O
may	O
adjust	O
the	O
amount	O
of	O
dividends	O
The	O
Group	O
’	O
s	O
activities	O
expose	O
it	O
to	O
a	O
variety	O
of	O
financial	O
risks	O
:	O
(	O
including	O
interest	O
rate	O
risk	O
and	O
price	O
risk	O
)	O
,	O
credit	O
risk	O
paid	O
to	O
shareholders	O
,	O
return	O
capital	O
to	O
shareholders	O
,	O
issue	O
new	O
shares	O
or	O
sell	O
assets	O
to	O
reduce	O
debt.	O

and	O
liquidity	O
risk.	O

The	O
Group	O
’	O
s	O
overall	O
risk	O
in	O
these	O
areas	O
is	O
not	O
significant	O
enough	O
to	O
warrant	O
a	O
formalised	O
specific	O
risk	O
management	O
program.	O

Risk	O

out	O
by	O
the	O
Board	O
of	O

in	O
their	O

to	O

financial	O
report	O
,	O
our	O
responsibility	O
is	O
to	O
read	O
the	O
other	O
information	O
and	O
,	O
in	O
doing	O
so	O
,	O
consider	O
whether	O
the	O
other	O
information	O
is	O
materially	O
inconsistent	O
with	O
the	O
financial	O
report	O
or	O
our	O
knowledge	O
obtained	O
in	O
the	O
audit	O
or	O
otherwise	O
appears	O
to	O
be	O
materially	O
misstated.	O

If	O
,	O
based	O
on	O
the	O
work	O
we	O
have	O
performed	O
,	O
we	O
conclude	O
that	O
there	O
is	O
a	O
material	O
misstatement	O
of	O
this	O
other	O
information	O
,	O
we	O
are	O
required	O
to	O
report	O
that	O
fact.	O

We	O
have	O
nothing	O
to	O
report	O
in	O
this	O
regard.	O

Responsibilities	O
of	O
the	O
Directors	O
for	O
the	O
Financial	O
Report	O
The	O
directors	O
of	O
the	O
Company	O
are	O
responsible	O
for	O
the	O
preparation	O
of	O
the	O
financial	O
report	O
that	O
gives	O
a	O
true	O
and	O
fair	O
view	O
in	O
accordance	O
with	O
Australian	O
Accounting	O
Standards	O
and	O
the	O
Corporations	O
Act	O
2001	O
and	O
for	O
such	O
internal	O
control	O
as	O
the	O
directors	O
determine	O
is	O
necessary	O
to	O
enable	O
the	O
preparation	O
of	O
the	O
financial	O
report	O
that	O
gives	O
a	O
true	O
and	O
fair	O
view	O
and	O
is	O
free	O
from	O
material	O
misstatement	O
,	O
whether	O
due	O
to	O
fraud	O
or	O
error.	O

In	O
preparing	O
the	O
financial	O
report	O
,	O
the	O
directors	O
are	O
responsible	O
for	O
assessing	O
the	O
ability	O
of	O
the	O
Group	O
to	O
continue	O
as	O
a	O
going	O
concern	O
,	O
disclosing	O
,	O
as	O
applicable	O
,	O
matters	O
related	O
to	O
going	O
concern	O
and	O
using	O
the	O
going	O
concern	O
basis	O
of	O
accounting	O
unless	O
the	O
directors	O
either	O
intend	O
to	O
liquidate	O
the	O
Group	O
or	O
to	O
cease	O
operations	O
,	O
or	O
have	O
no	O
realistic	O
alternative	O
but	O
to	O
do	O
so.	O

93	O
94	O
Vango	O
Mining	O
Limited	O
Annual	O
Report	O
2020	O
Independent	O
Auditor	O
’	O
s	O
Report	O
continued	O
Auditor's	O
Responsibilities	O
for	O
the	O
Audit	O
of	O
the	O
Financial	O
Report	O
Our	O
objectives	O
are	O
to	O
obtain	O
reasonable	O
assurance	O
about	O
whether	O
the	O
financial	O
report	O
as	O
a	O
whole	O
is	O
free	O
from	O
material	O
misstatement	O
,	O
whether	O
due	O
to	O
fraud	O
or	O
error	O
,	O
and	O
to	O
issue	O
an	O
auditor's	O
report	O
that	O
includes	O
our	O
opinion.	O

Reasonable	O
assurance	O
is	O
a	O
high	O
level	O
of	O
assurance	O
,	O
but	O
is	O
not	O
a	O
guarantee	O
that	O
an	O
audit	O
conducted	O
in	O
accordance	O
with	O
the	O
Australian	O
Auditing	O
Standards	O
will	O
always	O
detect	O
a	O
material	O
misstatement	O
when	O
it	O
exists.	O

Misstatements	O
can	O
arise	O
from	O
fraud	O
or	O
error	O
and	O
are	O
considered	O
material	O
if	O
,	O
individually	O
or	O
in	O
the	O
aggregate	O
,	O
they	O
could	O
reasonably	O
be	O
expected	O
to	O
influence	O
the	O
economic	O
decisions	O
of	O
users	O
taken	O
on	O
the	O
basis	O
of	O
this	O
financial	O
report.	O

A	O
further	O
description	O
of	O
our	O
responsibilities	O
for	O
the	O
audit	O
of	O
the	O
financial	O
report	O
is	O
located	O
at	O
the	O
Auditing	O
and	O
Assurance	O
Standards	O
Board	O
website	O
at	O
:	O
https	O
:	O
This	O
description	O
forms	O
part	O
of	O
our	O
auditor's	O
report.	O

Report	O
on	O
the	O
Remuneration	O
Report	O
Opinion	O
on	O
the	O
Remuneration	O
Report	O
We	O
have	O
audited	O
the	O
Remuneration	O
Report	O
included	O
in	O
pages	O
20	O
to	O
26	O
of	O
the	O
directors'	O
report	O
for	O
the	O
year	O
ended	O
30	O
June	O
2021.	O

In	O
our	O
opinion	O
,	O
the	O
Remuneration	O
Report	O
of	O
Vango	O
Mining	O
Limited.	O

,	O
for	O
the	O
year	O
ended	O
30	O
June	O
2021	O
complies	O
with	O
section	O
300A	O
of	O
the	O
Corporations	O
Act	O
2001.	O

Responsibilities	O
The	O
directors	O
of	O
the	O
Company	O
are	O
responsible	O
for	O
the	O
preparation	O
and	O
presentation	O
of	O
the	O
Remuneration	O
Report	O
in	O
accordance	O
with	O
section	O
300A	O
of	O
the	O
Corporations	O
Act	O
2001.	O

Our	O
responsibility	O
is	O
to	O
express	O
an	O
opinion	O
on	O
the	O
Remuneration	O
Report	O
,	O
based	O
on	O
our	O
audit	O

in	O

with	O
Australian	O
Auditing	O
Standards.	O

95	O
Shareholder	O
and	O
Investor	O
Information	O
Quoted	O
Shares	O
Subject	O
to	O
any	O
rights	O
or	O
restrictions	O
for	O
the	O
time	O
being	O
attached	O
to	O
any	O
class	O
or	O
classes	O
of	O
shares	O
,	O
at	O
meetings	O
of	O
shareholders	O
or	O
classes	O
of	O
shareholders	O
:	O
a.	O

each	O
shareholder	O
entitled	O
to	O
vote	O
may	O
vote	O
in	O
person	O
or	O
by	O
proxy	O
,	O
attorney	O
or	O
representative	O
;	O
b.	O

on	O
a	O
show	O
of	O
hands	O
,	O
every	O
person	O
present	O
who	O
is	O
a	O
shareholder	O
or	O
a	O
proxy	O
,	O
attorney	O
or	O
representative	O
of	O
a	O
Shareholder	O
has	O
one	O
vote	O
(	O
even	O
though	O
he	O
or	O
she	O
may	O
represent	O
more	O
than	O
one	O
member	O
)	O
;	O
and	O
c.	O

on	O
a	O
poll	O
,	O
every	O
person	O
present	O
who	O
is	O
a	O
shareholder	O
or	O
a	O
proxy	O
,	O
attorney	O
or	O
representative	O
of	O
a	O
shareholder	O
shall	O
,	O
in	O
respect	O
of	O
each	O
fully	O
paid	O
share	O
held	O
by	O
him	O
,	O
or	O
in	O
respect	O
of	O
which	O
he	O
is	O
appointed	O
a	O
proxy	O
,	O
attorney	O
or	O
representative	O
,	O
have	O
one	O
vote	O
for	O
the	O
share	O
,	O
but	O
in	O
respect	O
of	O
partly	O
paid	O
shares	O
,	O
shall	O
have	O
such	O
number	O
of	O
votes	O
being	O
equivalent	O
to	O
the	O
proportion	O
which	O
the	O
amount	O
paid	O
(	O
not	O
credited	O
)	O
is	O
of	O
the	O
total	O
amounts	O
paid	O
and	O
payable	O
in	O
respect	O
of	O
those	O
shares	O
(	O
excluding	O
amounts	O
credited	O
)	O
.	O

Options	O

the	O
right	O
for	O
the	O
option	O

to	O
be	O

paid	O
share	O

Company	O

of	O

JORC	O

)	O
Section	O
1	O
Sampling	O
Techniques	O
and	O
Data	O
(	O

)	O
Item	O
Comments	O
Sampling	O
•	O

2020	O
RC	O
drilling	O
by	O
Alto	O
Metals	O
Ltd	O
used	O
similar	O
sampling	O
techniques	O
as	O
Troy	O
Resources	O
,	O
except	O
a	O
techniques	O
for	O
a	O
4	O
metre	O
composite	O
sample	O
being	O
collected	O
for	O
laboratory	O
assay.	O

•	O

From	O
the	O
bulk	O
1m	O
sample	O
,	O
a	O
4	O
metre	O
composite	O
sample	O
was	O
collected	O
using	O
a	O
split	O
PVC	O
scoop	O
and	O
then	O
submitted	O
to	O
the	O
laboratory	O
for	O
analysis.	O

•	O

RC	O
1m	O
splits	O
were	O
submitted	O
(	O
2016	O
and	O
2019	O
RC	O
program	O
)	O
or	O
are	O
to	O
be	O
submitted	O
(	O
the	O
current	O
2020	O
RC	O
program	O
)	O
to	O
the	O
laboratory	O
if	O
the	O
composite	O
sample	O
assay	O
values	O
are	O
equal	O
to	O
or	O
greater	O
than	O
0.2g/t	O
Au.	O

•	O

All	O
drilling	O
up	O
to	O
2010	O
was	O
carried	O
out	O
by	O
Troy	O
Resources	O
NL	O
(	O
Troy	O
)	O
.	O

•	O

Troy	O
’	O
s	O
RC	O
samples	O
were	O
passed	O
directly	O
from	O
the	O
in-line	O
cyclone	O
through	O
a	O
rig	O
mounted	O
multi-tier	O
riffle	O
splitter.	O

Samples	O
were	O
collected	O
in	O
1	O
m	O
intervals	O
into	O
bulk	O
plastic	O
bags	O
and	O
1	O
m	O
calico	O
splits	O
(	O
which	O
were	O
retained	O
for	O
later	O
use	O
)	O
.	O

•	O

From	O
the	O
bulk	O
sample	O
,	O
a	O
5	O
m	O
composite	O
sample	O
was	O
collected	O
using	O
a	O
split	O
PVC	O
scoop	O
and	O
then	O
submitted	O
to	O
the	O
laboratory	O
for	O
analysis.	O

The	O
1	O
m	O
calico	O
splits	O
were	O
submitted	O
to	O
the	O
laboratory	O
if	O
the	O
composite	O
sample	O
returned	O
assay	O
values	O
equal	O
to	O
or	O
greater	O
than	O
0.2	O
g/t	O
Au.	O

In	O
certain	O
cases	O
,	O
selected	O
samples	O
from	O
some	O
holes	O
were	O
passed	O
from	O
the	O
cyclone	O
through	O
a	O
rig	O
mounted	O
multi-tier	O
riffle	O
splitter	O
,	O
and	O
samples	O
collected	O
into	O
calico	O
bags	O
at	O
1	O
m	O
intervals	O
were	O
submitted	O
directly	O
for	O
analyses.	O

The	O
remaining	O
bulk	O
sample	O
was	O
placed	O
on	O
the	O
ground	O
in	O
1	O
m	O
intervals.	O

•	O

Diamond	O
cores	O
were	O
marked	O
on	O
the	O
core	O
by	O
the	O
geologist	O
according	O
to	O
geological	O
intervals.	O

The	O
core	O
was	O
cut	O
in	O
half	O
by	O
Troy	O
field	O
technicians	O
,	O
with	O
half	O

pre-numbered	O
calico	O
bag	O
and	O
the	O
other	O
half	O
returned	O
to	O
the	O
core	O
tray.	O

For	O
duplicate	O
samples	O
the	O
core	O
to	O
be	O
submitted	O
for	O
analysis	O
is	O
quartered.	O

•	O

’	O
s	O

350	O

rig	O

onboard	O
1100/350	O
compressor	O
techniques	O
using	O
a	O
sampling	O
hammer	O
of	O
nominal	O
140mm	O
hole.	O

•	O

The	O
2017	O
Mineral	O
Resource	O
Estimate	O
for	O
Lord	O
Nelson	O
was	O
based	O
on	O
260	O
reverse	O

(	O

)	O
and	O
18	O

(	O

18	O

air	O

(	O

)	O
drill	O
holes.	O

RAB	O
drill	O
holes	O
were	O
used	O
to	O
guide	O
mineralisation	O
interpretation	O
and	O
excluded	O
for	O
estimation	O
purposes.	O

•	O

For	O
diamond	O
drilling	O
,	O
triple	O
tube	O
coring	O
was	O
used	O
due	O
to	O
the	O
friable	O
nature	O
of	O
the	O
oxide	O
zone	O
lithologies	O
being	O
drilled.	O

The	O
angled	O
core	O
holes	O
were	O
orientated	O
where	O
possible	O
using	O
a	O
crayon	O
marker	O

tool	O
and	O
the	O
holes	O
were	O
regularly	O
surveyed	O
using	O
an	O
Eastman	O
downhole	O
camera.	O

Due	O
to	O
the	O
deeply	O
weathered	O
,	O
soft	O
and	O
friable	O
nature	O
of	O
the	O
core	O

failed	O
or	O
could	O
not	O
be	O
pieced	O
together	O
over	O
any	O

3kg	O
4m	O

in	O

•	O

Alto	O
’	O
s	O
4m	O
RC	O
samples	O
(	O
2020	O
current	O
RC	O
program	O
)	O
Samples	O
submitted	O
for	O
analysis	O
via	O
Photon	O
assay	O
technique	O
were	O
dried	O
,	O
crushed	O
to	O
nominal	O
0.85	O
passing	O
2mm	O
,	O
linear	O
split	O
and	O
a	O
nominal	O
500g	O
sub	O
sample	O
taken	O
(	O
method	O
code	O
PAP3512R	O
)	O
•	O

The	O
500g	O
sample	O
is	O
assayed	O
for	O
gold	O
by	O
PhotonAssay	O
(	O
method	O
code	O
PAAU2	O
)	O
along	O
with	O
quality	O
control	O
samples	O
including	O
certified	O
reference	O
materials	O
,	O
blanks	O
and	O
sample	O
duplicates.	O

•	O

About	O
the	O
MinAnalytical	O
Photon	O
Assay	O
Analysis	O
Technique	O
:	O
Developed	O
by	O
CSIRO	O
and	O
the	O
Chrysos	O
Corporation	O
,	O
the	O
Photon	O
Assay	O
technique	O
is	O
a	O
fast	O
o	O

and	O
chemical	O
free	O
alternative	O
to	O
the	O
traditional	O
fire	O
assay	O
process	O
and	O
utilizes	O
high	O
energy	O
x-rays.	O

The	O
process	O
is	O
nondestructive	O
on	O
and	O
utilises	O
a	O
significantly	O
larger	O
sample	O
than	O
the	O
conventional	O
50g	O
fire	O
assay.	O

MinAnalytical	O
has	O
thoroughly	O
tested	O
and	O
validated	O
the	O
Photon	O
Assay	O
process	O
with	O
o	O

results	O
benchmarked	O
against	O
conventional	O
fire	O
assay.	O

The	O
National	O
Association	O
of	O
Testing	O
Authorities	O
(	O
NATA	O
)	O
,	O
Australia	O
’	O
s	O
national	O
o	O

accreditation	O
body	O
for	O
laboratories	O
,	O
has	O
issued	O
MinAnalytical	O
with	O
accreditation	O
for	O
the	O
technique	O
in	O
compliance	O
with	O
ISO/IEC	O
17025	O
:	O
2018-Testing.	O

•	O

Subsequently	O
,	O
intervals	O
of	O
4m	O
composite	O
samples	O
reporting	O
greater	O
than	O
0.2g/t	O
Au	O
were	O
selected	O
for	O
re-assay	O
,	O
and	O
1m	O
re-split	O
samples	O
were	O
submitted	O
(	O
2016	O
and	O
2019	O
RC	O
program	O
)	O
for	O
50gm	O
fire	O
assay.	O

Laboratory	O

and/or	O

results.	O

(	O

)	O

used	O
for	O
RAB	O

•	O

(	O

)	O

•	O

work	O

one	O

QC	O

was	O
submitted	O
with	O

of	O

•	O

Standards	O
were	O
purchased	O
from	O
Gannet	O
Holdings	O
Pty	O
Ltd	O
(	O
Gannet	O
)	O
in	O
Perth	O
,	O
WA.	O

was	O

on	O
the	O
expected	O
assay	O
results	O
and	O

being	O

.	O

(	O

)	O

and	O

expected	O

of	O

Location	O
of	O
•	O

The	O
Lord	O
Nelson	O
grid	O
is	O

is	O

for	O

•	O

There	O
is	O
no	O

on	O

or	O

has	O

DDH	O
and	O

to	O
the	O
AC	O
and	O
RAB	O
drill	O
holes	O
and	O

is	O
the	O
potential	O
for	O
some	O
error	O
here.	O

•	O

The	O
angled	O
diamond	O
core	O
holes	O
were	O
orientated	O
where	O
possible	O
using	O
a	O
crayon	O
marker	O

Geology	O
•	O

The	O
Lord	O
Nelson	O
deposit	O
occurs	O
along	O
the	O
north-south	O
trending	O
Trafalgar	O
shear	O
zone.	O

•	O

The	O
Lord	O
Nelson	O
deposit	O
is	O
hosted	O
within	O
a	O
zone	O
of	O
intermixed	O
high-magnesium	O
basalt	O
and	O
granodiorite	O
intrusive	O
rocks	O
above	O
a	O
footwall	O
ultramafic	O
unit.	O

The	O
mineralisation	O
trends	O
north-	O
north-west	O
,	O
dipping	O
approximately	O
50	O
°	O

to	O
the	O
west	O
increasing	O
to	O
70	O
°	O

with	O
depth.	O

The	O
main	O
eastern	O
lode	O
is	O
a	O
zone	O
of	O
pyrite	O
+	O
silica	O
+	O
biotite	O
+/-	O
quartz	O
veining	O
that	O
follows	O
the	O
ultramafic	O
footwall	O
contact.	O

West-northwest	O
striking	O
veins	O
and	O
a	O
sheeted	O
swarm	O
of	O
granodiorite	O
intrusions	O
at	O
Lord	O
Nelson	O
are	O
oblique	O
to	O
the	O
north-northwest	O
trend	O
of	O
the	O
ore	O
envelope	O
inferred	O
from	O
drilling.	O

This	O
suggests	O
that	O
within	O
the	O
ore	O
zone	O
the	O
sheeted	O
veins	O
may	O
produce	O
sub-horizontal	O
shoots	O
oriented	O
west	O
northwest.	O

•	O

interpreted	O
mineralisation	O
domains	O
are	O
based	O
on	O
a	O
nominal	O
0.2	O
g/t	O
Au	O
to	O
0.3	O
g/t	O
Au	O
cut-	O
off	O

grade	O

Au	O

ABOUT	O
MEEKA	O
GOLD	O
LIMITED	O
Meeka	O
Gold	O
(	O
ASX	O
:	O
MEK	O
)	O
is	O
a	O
junior	O
gold	O
explorer	O
with	O
a	O
portfolio	O
of	O
exploration	O
projects	O
across	O
Western	O
Australia.	O

Meeka	O
’	O
s	O
flagship	O
Murchison	O
Gold	O
Project	O
has	O
a	O
combined	O
343km	O
²	O

landholding	O
in	O
the	O
prolific	O
Murchison	O
Gold	O
Fields	O
of	O
Western	O
Australia	O
and	O
hosts	O
a	O
large	O
high	O
grade	O
1.1Moz	O
Mineral	O
Resource.	O

The	O
Company	O
is	O
actively	O
exploring	O
on	O
this	O
tenure	O
while	O
also	O
progressing	O
toward	O
production	O
with	O
the	O
release	O
of	O
the	O
Murchison	O
Gold	O
Project	O
Scoping	O
Study	O
in	O
December	O
2021	O
outlining	O
a	O
robust	O
Project	O
that	O
produces	O
over	O
420koz	O
of	O
gold	O
and	O
delivers	O
significant	O
free	O
cashflow.	O

In	O
addition	O
to	O
the	O
Murchison	O
Gold	O
Project	O
,	O
the	O
Company	O
owns	O
the	O
Circle	O
Valley	O
Gold	O
Project	O
in	O
southern	O
WA.	O

Circle	O
Valley	O
sits	O
in	O
the	O
Albany	O
Fraser	O
Mobile	O
Belt	O
which	O
hosts	O
the	O
Tropicana	O
gold	O
mine	O
(	O
3Moz	O
past	O
production	O
)	O
.	O

in	O

to	O

FORWARD	O
LOOKING	O
STATEMENTS	O
Certain	O
statements	O
in	O
this	O
report	O
relate	O
to	O
the	O
future	O
,	O
including	O
forward	O
looking	O
statements	O
relating	O
to	O
the	O
Company	O
’	O
s	O
financial	O
position	O
,	O
strategy	O
and	O
expected	O
operating	O
results.	O

These	O
forward-looking	O
statements	O
involve	O
known	O
and	O
unknown	O
risks	O
,	O
uncertainties	O
,	O
assumptions	O
and	O
other	O
important	O
factors	O
that	O
could	O
cause	O
the	O
actual	O
results	O
,	O
performance	O
or	O
achievements	O
of	O
the	O
Company	O
to	O
be	O
materially	O
different	O
from	O
future	O
results	O
,	O
performance	O
or	O
achievements	O
expressed	O
or	O
implied	O
by	O
such	O
statements.	O

Actual	O
events	O
or	O
results	O
may	O
differ	O
materially	O
from	O
the	O
events	O
or	O
results	O
expressed	O
or	O
implied	O
in	O
any	O
forward-looking	O
statement	O
and	O
deviations	O
are	O
both	O
normal	O
and	O
to	O
be	O
expected.	O

Other	O
than	O
required	O
by	O
law	O
,	O
neither	O
the	O
Company	O
,	O
their	O
officers	O
nor	O
any	O
other	O
person	O
gives	O
any	O
representation	O
,	O
assurance	O
or	O
guarantee	O
that	O
the	O
occurrence	O
of	O
the	O
events	O
expressed	O
or	O
implied	O
in	O
any	O
forward-looking	O
statements	O
will	O
actually	O
occur.	O

You	O
are	O
cautioned	O
not	O
to	O
place	O
undue	O
reliance	O
on	O
those	O
statements.	O

COSMOMETALS.COM.AU	O
6	O
ASX	O
RELEASE	O
|	O
WIDE	O
COPPER	O
INTERSECTIONS	O
AT	O
MT	O
VENN	O
FURTHER	O
WORK	O
The	O
Company	O
is	O
engaging	O
a	O
well-credentialled	O
resource	O
consulting	O
group	O
to	O
define	O
an	O
initial	O
Exploration	O
Target	O
at	O
Mt	O
Venn	O
in	O
line	O
with	O
the	O
JORC	O
Code	O
(	O
2012	O
)	O
.	O

According	O
to	O
the	O
JORC	O
Code	O
an	O
Exploration	O
Target	O
is	O
defined	O
as	O
:	O
“	O
…	O

a	O
statement	O
or	O
estimate	O
of	O
the	O
exploration	O
potential	O
of	O
a	O
mineral	O
deposit	O
in	O
a	O
defined	O
geological	O
setting	O
where	O
the	O
statement	O
or	O
estimate	O
,	O
quoted	O
as	O
a	O
range	O
of	O
tonnes	O
and	O
a	O
range	O
of	O
grade	O
(	O
or	O
quality	O
)	O
,	O
relates	O
to	O
mineralisation	O
for	O
which	O
there	O
has	O
been	O
insufficient	O
exploration	O
to	O
estimate	O
a	O
Mineral	O
Resource.	O

”	O
The	O
definition	O
of	O
this	O
Exploration	O
Target	O
,	O
planned	O
for	O
completion	O
late	O
this	O
quarter	O
,	O
will	O
be	O
fundamental	O
to	O
planning	O
further	O
drilling	O
required	O
to	O
upgrade	O
Mt	O
Venn	O
to	O
a	O
JORC	O
compliant	O
resource	O
as	O
well	O
as	O
testing	O
the	O
mineralisation	O
potential	O
beyond	O
the	O
current	O
drilling	O
limits.	O

A	O
drilling	O
contractor	O
has	O
been	O
sourced	O
to	O
commence	O
this	O
program	O
in	O
March	O
to	O
avoid	O
potential	O
weather-	O
related	O
delays	O
in	O
the	O
current	O
fire	O
season.	O

Company	O
also	O
looks	O
forward	O
to	O
gaining	O
approvals	O
to	O
commence	O
exploration	O
works	O
at	O
Mt	O
Venn	O
North	O
,	O
including	O
MVRC010	O

the	O
best	O
nickel	O

About	O
Cosmo	O

Ltd	O
Cosmo	O
Metals	O
Ltd	O
(	O
Cosmo	O
;	O
ASX	O
:	O
CMO	O
)	O
is	O
an	O
ASX-listed	O
,	O
base	O
metals	O
exploration	O
company	O
focused	O
on	O
the	O
advancement	O
of	O
its	O
flagship	O
Mt	O
Venn	O
,	O
Winchester	O
and	O
Eastern	O
Mafic	O
projects	O
in	O
the	O
underexplored	O
Yamarna	O
Belt	O
,	O
in	O
the	O
Eastern	O
Goldfields	O
region	O
of	O
Western	O
Australia.	O

The	O
Yamarna	O
Belt	O
is	O
considered	O
highly	O
prospective	O
for	O
copper-nickel-cobalt	O
(	O
Cu-Ni-Co	O
)	O
and	O
platinum	O
group	O
elements	O
(	O
PGE	O
)	O
and	O
Cosmo	O
’	O
s	O
well	O
regarded	O
technical	O
team	O
is	O
advancing	O
exploration	O
on	O
multiple	O
fronts	O
to	O
unlock	O
the	O
potential	O
of	O
the	O
region.	O

With	O
previous	O
drilling	O
having	O
identified	O
sulphide	O
based	O
Cu-Ni-Co	O
mineralisation	O
at	O
Cosmo	O
’	O
s	O
key	O
projects	O
,	O
the	O
company	O
has	O
a	O
unique	O
opportunity	O
to	O
add	O
value	O
from	O
this	O
460km2	O
landholding	O
Competent	O
Persons	O

information	O
in	O

that	O

to	O

Forward-Looking	O
Statements	O
This	O
document	O
may	O
include	O
forward-looking	O
statements.	O

Forward-looking	O
statements	O
include	O
,	O
but	O
are	O
not	O
limited	O
to	O
,	O
statements	O
concerning	O
Cosmo	O
’	O
s	O
planned	O
exploration	O
program	O
and	O
other	O
statements	O
that	O
are	O
not	O
historical	O
facts.	O

When	O
used	O
in	O
this	O
document	O
,	O
the	O
words	O
such	O
as	O
"could	O
,	O
"	O
"plan	O
,	O
"	O
"estimate	O
,	O
"	O
"expect	O
,	O
"	O
"intend	O
,	O
"	O
"may	O
”	O
,	O
"potential	O
,	O
"	O
"should	O
,	O
"	O
and	O
similar	O
expressions	O
are	O
forward-looking	O
statements.	O

Although	O
Cosmo	O
believes	O
that	O
its	O
expectations	O
reflected	O
in	O
these	O
forward-looking	O
statements	O
are	O
reasonable	O
,	O
such	O
statements	O
involve	O
risks	O
and	O
uncertainties	O
and	O
no	O
assurance	O
can	O
be	O
given	O
that	O
actual	O
results	O
will	O
be	O

with	O
these	O
forward-looking	O
statements.	O

ASX	O

WIDE	O

INTERSECTIONS	O
AT	O
MT	O
VENN	O
APPENDIX	O
B	O
JORC	O
CODE	O
,	O
2012	O
EDITION	O
–	O

TABLE	O
1	O
SECTION	O
1	O
-	O

SAMPLING	O
TECHNIQUES	O
AND	O
DATA	O
(	O
Criteria	O
in	O
this	O
section	O
apply	O
to	O
all	O
succeeding	O
sections	O
)	O
CRITERIA	O
COMMENTARY	O
Sampling	O
RC	O
samples	O
were	O
collected	O
into	O
calico	O
bags	O
over	O
1m	O
intervals	O
using	O
a	O
cyclone	O
splitter.	O

The	O
residual	O
bulk	O
techniques	O
samples	O
are	O
placed	O
in	O
piles	O
on	O
the	O
ground.	O

Two	O
cone	O
splits	O
are	O
taken	O
off	O
the	O
rig	O
splitter	O
for	O
RC	O
drilling.	O

Visually	O
prospective	O
zones	O
were	O
sampled	O
over	O
1m	O
intervals	O
and	O
sent	O
for	O
analysis	O
while	O
the	O
rest	O
of	O
the	O
hole	O
was	O
composited	O
over	O
4m	O
intervals	O
by	O
taking	O
a	O
spear	O
sample	O
from	O
each	O
1m	O
bag.	O

A	O
quality	O
assurance	O
/quality	O
control	O
(	O
QAQC	O
)	O
system	O
comprising	O
internal	O
and	O
laboratory	O
standards	O
,	O
blanks	O
and	O
duplicates	O
were	O
used	O
to	O
evaluate	O
analytical	O
results.	O

Drilling	O
Industry	O
standard	O
drilling	O
methods	O
and	O
equipment	O
were	O
utilised.	O

techniques	O
Reverse	O
Circulation	O
(	O
RC	O
)	O
Drilling	O
was	O
undertaken	O
by	O
Challenge	O
Drilling	O
using	O
130	O
to	O
140mm	O
diameter	O
drill	O
bits.	O

RC	O
drilling	O
employed	O
face	O
sampling	O
hammers	O
ensuring	O
contamination	O
during	O
sample	O
extraction	O
is	O
minimised.	O

Drill	O
sample	O
Sample	O
recovery	O
data	O
is	O
noted	O
qualitatively	O
in	O
geological	O
comments	O
as	O
part	O
of	O
the	O
logging	O
process.	O

Sample	O
recovery	O
condition	O
has	O
been	O
logged	O
for	O
every	O
geological	O
interval	O
as	O
part	O
of	O
the	O
logging	O
process.	O

No	O
quantitative	O
twinned	O
drilling	O
analysis	O
has	O
been	O
undertaken	O
and	O
no	O
information	O
is	O
available	O
to	O
assess	O
the	O
relationship	O
between	O
sample	O
recovery	O
and	O
grade.	O

Logging	O
Geological	O
logging	O
of	O
drilling	O
followed	O
established	O
company	O
procedures.	O

Qualitative	O
logging	O
of	O
samples	O
includes	O
lithology	O
,	O
mineralogy	O
,	O
alteration	O
,	O
veining	O
and	O
weathering.	O

Abundant	O
geological	O
comments	O
supplement	O
logged	O
intervals.	O

Sub-sampling	O
1m	O
cyclone	O
splits	O
and	O
4m	O
speared	O
composite	O
samples	O
were	O
taken	O
in	O
the	O
field.	O

Samples	O
were	O
prepared	O
and	O
techniques	O
and	O
analysed	O
at	O
ALS	O
Laboratories	O
Perth.	O

sample	O
All	O
samples	O
were	O
submitted	O
to	O
ALS	O
Laboratory	O
(	O
Perth	O
)	O
for	O
analyses.	O

:	O
preparation	O

µ	O

m	O

Geology	O
Cosmo	O
Metals	O
’	O
Yamarna	O
Project	O
hosts	O
the	O
southern	O
extension	O
of	O
the	O
Mt	O
Venn	O
igneous	O
complex.	O

This	O
complex	O
is	O
immediately	O
west	O
of	O
the	O
Yamarna	O
greenstone	O
belt.	O

The	O
mineralisation	O
encountered	O
in	O
the	O
Mt	O
Venn	O
drilling	O
suggests	O
that	O
sulphide	O
mineralisation	O
is	O
defined	O
by	O
a	O
prominent	O
long	O
EM	O
conductor	O
trend	O
and	O
shows	O
a	O
highly	O
sulfur-saturated	O
system	O
within	O
a	O
metamorphosed	O
dolerite	O
and	O
gabbro	O
sequence.	O

Visual	O
logging	O
of	O
sulphide	O
mineralogy	O
shows	O
pyrrhotite	O
dominant	O
with	O
chalcopyrite.	O

Drill	O
hole	O
A	O
list	O
of	O
drill	O
hole	O
coordinates	O
,	O
orientations	O
and	O
intersections	O
reported	O
in	O
this	O
announcement	O
are	O
provided	O
Information	O
in	O
the	O
body	O
and	O
appendices	O
within	O
this	O
announcement.	O

Data	O
Results	O
were	O
reported	O
using	O
cut-off	O
levels	O
relevant	O
to	O
the	O
sample	O
type.	O

For	O
single	O
metre	O
splits	O
,	O
significant	O
aggregation	O
intercepts	O
were	O
reported	O
for	O
grades	O
greater	O
than	O
0.18%	O
Cu	O
with	O
a	O
maximum	O
dilution	O
of	O
2m.	O

High	O
grade	O
methods	O
intervals	O
are	O
quoted	O
using	O
a	O
>1%	O
Cu	O
cut-off	O
with	O
a	O
maximum	O
of	O
2m	O
internal	O
dilution.	O

No	O
maximum	O
or	O
minimum	O
grade	O
truncations	O
have	O
been	O
applied.	O

A	O
weighted	O
average	O
calculation	O
was	O
used	O
to	O
allow	O
for	O
bottom	O
of	O
hole	O
composites	O
that	O
were	O
less	O
than	O
the	O
standard	O
4m	O
and	O
when	O
intervals	O
contain	O
composited	O
samples	O
plus	O
1m	O
split	O
samples.	O

No	O
metal	O
equivalents	O
are	O
used.	O

orientation	O
of	O
structures	O
and	O
mineralisation	O
is	O
not	O
known	O
with	O
certainty	O
;	O
however	O
drill	O
holes	O
were	O
between	O
oriented	O
perpendicular	O
to	O
interpreted	O
mineralisation.	O

mineralisation	O
widths	O
and	O
intercept	O
lengths	O
